adapter sequence data: Adapter sequence data refers to the nucleotide sequences that are artificially added to DNA or RNA fragments during library preparation for sequencing, which facilitate the binding of the fragments to sequencing platforms and may need to be removed during data analysis.
adapter-sequence trimming: Adapter-sequence trimming is the process of removing non-biological sequences, known as adapters, from the ends of DNA or RNA reads in high-throughput sequencing data to ensure accurate downstream analysis.
adapter-trimmed sequence data: Adapter-trimmed sequence data refers to DNA or RNA sequence reads from which artificial adapter sequences, added during library preparation, have been computationally removed to ensure accurate downstream analysis.
adaptive immune effector function: Adaptive immune effector function refers to the specific actions carried out by immune cells, such as T cells and B cells, to eliminate pathogens or infected cells as part of the adaptive immune response.
adaptive immune receptor: An adaptive immune receptor is a specialized protein, such as a T-cell receptor or an antibody, that is generated by the immune system to specifically recognize and bind to foreign antigens, enabling a targeted immune response.
adaptive immune response: The adaptive immune system (AIS), also known as the acquired immune system, or specific immune system is a subsystem of the immune system that is composed of specialized cells, organs, and processes that eliminate pathogens specifically. The acquired immune system is one of the two main immunity strategies found in vertebrates.
adding a material entity into a target: "Adding a material entity into a target" refers to the process of introducing a substance or material into a specific location or system for a particular purpose, such as treatment, experimentation, or enhancement.
adding material objective: The term "adding material objective" in a biomedical context typically refers to the goal of incorporating additional substances or materials into a biological system or device to enhance its function, performance, or compatibility.
adding substance to cell culture: "Adding substance to cell culture" refers to the process of introducing specific compounds or nutrients into a cell culture environment to support cell growth, differentiation, or to study cellular responses.
addition of molecular label: The "addition of molecular label" refers to the process of attaching a detectable marker, such as a fluorescent dye or radioactive isotope, to a molecule to facilitate its identification, tracking, or quantification in biological research.
addition of molecular tracer function: The "addition of molecular tracer function" refers to the incorporation of a detectable marker into a molecule to track its distribution, interaction, or activity within a biological system.
adiponectin: Adiponectin is a protein hormone and adipokine, which is involved in regulating glucose levels and fatty acid breakdown. In humans, it is encoded by the ADIPOQ gene and is produced primarily in adipose tissue, but also in muscle and even in the brain.
adiponectin assay: An adiponectin assay is a laboratory test used to measure the levels of adiponectin, a protein hormone involved in regulating glucose levels and fatty acid breakdown, in a biological sample.
adiponectin concentration assay: An adiponectin concentration assay is a laboratory test used to measure the levels of adiponectin, a protein hormone involved in regulating glucose levels and fatty acid breakdown, in a biological sample.
adipose tissue: Adipose tissue is a loose connective tissue composed mostly of adipocytes. It also contains the stromal vascular fraction (SVF) of cells including preadipocytes, fibroblasts, vascular endothelial cells and a variety of immune cells such as adipose tissue macrophages. Its main role is to store energy in the form of lipids, although it also cushions and insulates the body.
adipose tissue specimen: An adipose tissue specimen is a sample of body fat collected for medical examination or research purposes.
adjuvant role: An "adjuvant role" in biomedicine refers to the use of an additional treatment or substance to enhance the effectiveness of a primary therapy, often in the context of cancer treatment to improve outcomes.
administering substance in vivo: Administering substance in vivo refers to the process of delivering a substance, such as a drug or compound, directly into a living organism to study its effects within the natural biological context.
administering substance in vivo to cause: "Administering substance in vivo to cause disease" refers to the intentional introduction of a substance into a living organism to induce a disease state for research or experimental purposes.
administering substance in vivo to reduc: Administering a substance in vivo to reduce or prevent disease refers to the process of delivering a therapeutic agent directly into a living organism to decrease the risk or severity of a disease.
administration in vivo with infectious a: "Administration in vivo with infectious agent" refers to the process of introducing a pathogen or microorganism into a living organism to study its effects, typically for research or therapeutic purposes.
administration of material to specimen: "Administration of material to specimen" refers to the process of introducing a substance or material into a biological specimen for experimental, diagnostic, or therapeutic purposes.
adrenal gland: In mammals, either of a pair of complex endocrine glands, situated above each kidney, secreting hormones which control the heart rate, blood pressure, and metabolism.
adrenal gland specimen: An adrenal gland specimen is a sample of tissue or cells taken from one of the adrenal glands, which are small glands located above the kidneys that produce hormones such as cortisol, adrenaline, and aldosterone.
adult arthropod specimen collection proc: The adult arthropod specimen collection process refers to the systematic method of gathering adult arthropods from various environments for study, research, or documentation purposes.
adverse event trigger: An "adverse event trigger" is a specific clinical sign, symptom, or laboratory result that indicates the potential occurrence of an adverse event, prompting further investigation or intervention.
affinity column: An affinity column is a type of chromatography column used to purify biomolecules based on specific binding interactions between the target molecule and a ligand attached to the stationary phase.
agar stab specimen: An agar stab specimen is a sample obtained by inserting a sterile instrument into a solid agar medium to culture and isolate microorganisms for laboratory analysis.
agar stab storage: Agar stab storage is a method of preserving microbial cultures by inoculating them into a solid agar medium within a test tube, allowing for long-term maintenance of the organisms at low metabolic activity.
agarose gel: Agarose gel electrophoresis is a method of gel electrophoresis used in biochemistry, molecular biology, genetics, and clinical chemistry to separate a mixed population of macromolecules such as DNA or proteins in a matrix of agarose, one of the two main components of agar. The proteins may be separated by charge and/or size, and the DNA and RNA fragments by length. Biomolecules are separated by applying an electric field to move the charged molecules through an agarose matrix, and the biomolecules are separated by size in the agarose gel matrix.
agarose gel electrophoresis system: An agarose gel electrophoresis system is a laboratory technique used to separate and analyze DNA, RNA, or proteins based on their size and charge by applying an electric field to a gel matrix.
age determination assay: An age determination assay is a scientific test or procedure used to estimate the age of an organism or biological sample based on specific biological markers or characteristics.
age group inclusion criterion: An "age group inclusion criterion" refers to a specific age range that participants must fall within to be eligible for inclusion in a biomedical study or clinical trial.
age measurement datum: An "age measurement datum" refers to a specific data point or recorded value that indicates the age of an individual or biological sample, often used in biomedical research and analysis.
age of majority inclusion criterion: The "age of majority inclusion criterion" refers to a requirement in clinical research that participants must be at or above the legal age of adulthood, typically 18 years, to be eligible for inclusion in a study.
age since birth at time of enrollment: "Age since birth at time of enrollment" refers to the chronological age of an individual, measured in units such as years or months, at the specific point when they are enrolled in a study or clinical trial.
age since birth at time of visit: "Age since birth at time of visit" refers to the amount of time that has elapsed from an individual's birth to the moment they attend a specific medical appointment or visit.
age since birth measurement datum: "Age since birth measurement datum" refers to the quantifiable data representing the amount of time that has elapsed since an individual's birth.
age since coitus measurement datum: "Age since coitus measurement datum" refers to the recorded time interval or data point indicating the duration that has elapsed since the last occurrence of sexual intercourse.
age since culture seeding measurement da: "Age since culture seeding measurement datum" refers to the recorded time elapsed since the initial seeding or establishment of a cell culture in a laboratory setting, used to track and analyze the development and growth of the culture over time.
age since eclosion measurement datum: "Age since eclosion measurement datum" refers to the recorded time interval or data point indicating the duration since an organism, typically an insect, has emerged from its pupal case or egg.
age since egg laying measurement datum: "Age since egg laying measurement datum" refers to the recorded time interval or data point indicating the duration that has elapsed since an egg was laid.
age since fertilization measurement datu: "Age since fertilization measurement datum" refers to a specific data point indicating the amount of time that has elapsed since the fertilization of an egg, typically used to assess developmental stages in embryology.
age since germination measurement datum: "Age since germination measurement datum" refers to the recorded data point indicating the amount of time that has elapsed since a seed has successfully germinated and begun to grow.
age since hatching measurement datum: "Age since hatching measurement datum" refers to the recorded data indicating the time elapsed since an organism emerged from its egg.
age since planting measurement datum: "Age since planting measurement datum" refers to the recorded data point indicating the amount of time that has elapsed since a plant was initially planted, typically used to assess growth stages or agricultural timelines.
age since sowing measurement datum: "Age since sowing measurement datum" refers to the recorded time interval or age of a plant calculated from the date its seeds were sown.
age when gave birth to first child: The "age when gave birth to first child" refers to the age at which a person delivers their first live-born child.
agglomerative hierarchical clustering: In data mining and statistics, hierarchical clustering is a method of cluster analysis that seeks to build a hierarchy of clusters. Strategies for hierarchical clustering generally fall into two categories:Agglomerative: Agglomerative: Agglomerative clustering, often referred to as a "bottom-up" approach, begins with each data point as an individual cluster. At each step, the algorithm merges the two most similar clusters based on a chosen distance metric and linkage criterion. This process continues until all data points are combined into a single cluster or a stopping criterion is met. Agglomerative methods are more commonly used due to their simplicity and computational efficiency for small to medium-sized datasets. Divisive: Divisive clustering, known as a "top-down" approach, starts with all data points in a single cluster and recursively splits the cluster into smaller ones. At each step, the algorithm selects a cluster and divides it into two or more subsets, often using a criterion such as maximizing the distance between resulting clusters. Divisive methods are less common but can be useful when the goal is to identify large, distinct clusters first.
alanine aminotransferase: Alanine aminotransferase, formerly alanine transaminase (ALT), and even earlier referred to as serum glutamate-pyruvate transaminase (GPT) or serum glutamic-pyruvic transaminase (SGPT), is a transaminase enzyme that was first characterized in the mid-1950s by Arthur Karmen and colleagues. ALT is found in plasma and in various body tissues but is most common in the liver. It catalyzes the two parts of the alanine cycle. Serum ALT level, serum AST level, and their ratio are routinely measured clinically as biomarkers for liver health.
alanine aminotransferase activity level: An alanine aminotransferase activity level assay is a biochemical test used to measure the activity level of the enzyme alanine aminotransferase in the blood, which can help assess liver function and detect liver damage.
alanine aminotransferase assay: An alanine aminotransferase assay is a laboratory test used to measure the level of the enzyme alanine aminotransferase in the blood, which can help assess liver function and detect liver damage.
albumin: Albumin is a family of globular proteins, the most common of which are the serum albumins. All of the proteins of the albumin family are water-soluble, moderately soluble in concentrated salt solutions, and experience heat denaturation. Albumins are commonly found in blood plasma and differ from other blood proteins in that they are not glycosylated. Substances containing albumins are called albuminoids.
albumin assay: An albumin assay is a laboratory test used to measure the concentration of albumin, a protein produced by the liver, in a blood or urine sample to assess liver function, nutritional status, or kidney health.
albumin concentration assay: An albumin concentration assay is a laboratory test used to measure the amount of albumin, a key protein, in a biological sample, typically blood, to assess liver and kidney function or nutritional status.
albumin-free serum: Albumin-free serum is a blood serum from which albumin, a major protein responsible for maintaining osmotic pressure and transporting substances, has been removed, often used in laboratory settings to study cellular processes without the influence of albumin.
aligned sequence data: Aligned sequence data refers to a set of biological sequences, such as DNA, RNA, or protein sequences, that have been arranged to identify regions of similarity, which may indicate functional, structural, or evolutionary relationships among the sequences.
alignment counting algorithm: An alignment counting algorithm is a computational method used to quantify the number of alignments or matches between sequences, such as DNA, RNA, or proteins, in bioinformatics.
alignment counting application: An alignment counting application is a software tool used in bioinformatics to quantify the number of sequence alignments, often for the purpose of analyzing genetic or protein sequence data.
alkaline phosphatase (human): Alkaline phosphatase (human) is an enzyme found in various tissues throughout the body, including the liver, bones, kidneys, and bile ducts, that plays a crucial role in breaking down proteins and is often measured to assess liver and bone health.
alkaline phosphatase (human) assay: An alkaline phosphatase (human) assay is a laboratory test used to measure the activity or concentration of the enzyme alkaline phosphatase in human biological samples, often to assess liver or bone health.
alkaline phosphatase activity: Alkaline phosphatase activity refers to the enzymatic process by which alkaline phosphatase catalyzes the removal of phosphate groups from molecules, typically functioning optimally at an alkaline pH.
alkaline phosphatase activity level assa: An alkaline phosphatase activity level assay is a biochemical test used to measure the activity of the enzyme alkaline phosphatase in a biological sample, often to assess liver or bone health.
all pairs design: An all pairs design is a statistical experimental design in which every possible pair of treatments is compared, allowing for the evaluation of the effects of each treatment relative to every other treatment.
allele information: Allele information refers to the specific details about the variants of a gene present at a particular locus on a chromosome, which can influence an organism's traits or susceptibility to certain conditions.
allergen: An allergen is an otherwise harmless substance that triggers an allergic reaction in sensitive individuals by stimulating an immune response.
allergic reaction: Allergies, also known as allergic diseases, are various conditions caused by hypersensitivity of the immune system to typically harmless substances in the environment. These diseases include hay fever, food allergies, atopic dermatitis, allergic asthma, and anaphylaxis. Symptoms may include red eyes, an itchy rash, sneezing, coughing, a runny nose, shortness of breath, or swelling. Note that food intolerances and food poisoning are separate conditions.
allergy: Allergies, also known as allergic diseases, are various conditions caused by hypersensitivity of the immune system to typically harmless substances in the environment. These diseases include hay fever, food allergies, atopic dermatitis, allergic asthma, and anaphylaxis. Symptoms may include red eyes, an itchy rash, sneezing, coughing, a runny nose, shortness of breath, or swelling. Note that food intolerances and food poisoning are separate conditions.
allotransplantation: Allotransplant is the transplantation of cells, tissues, or organs to a recipient from a genetically non-identical donor of the same species. The transplant is called an allograft, allogeneic transplant, or homograft. Most human tissue and organ transplants are allografts.
alpha mating type (yeast): The alpha mating type in yeast refers to one of the two mating types in Saccharomyces cerevisiae, characterized by the expression of specific genes that enable it to mate with the opposite 'a' mating type to form a diploid cell.
alpha-beta T cell: An alpha-beta T cell is a type of T lymphocyte characterized by the presence of T-cell receptors composed of alpha and beta chains, playing a crucial role in the adaptive immune response by recognizing antigens presented by major histocompatibility complex molecules.
altitude measurement datum: Altitude measurement datum refers to a reference point or surface used as a baseline for measuring elevation or altitude, often used in geographical and aviation contexts to ensure consistent and accurate altitude readings.
ambidextrous handedness: Ambidextrous handedness refers to the ability of a person to use both the right and left hand with equal skill and ease.
amikacin: Amikacin is an antibiotic medication used for a number of bacterial infections. This includes joint infections, intra-abdominal infections, meningitis, pneumonia, sepsis, and urinary tract infections. It is also used for the treatment of multidrug-resistant tuberculosis. It is used by injection into a vein using an IV or into a muscle.
amino acid: Amino acids are organic compounds that contain both amino and carboxylic acid functional groups. Although over 500 amino acids exist in nature, by far the most important are the 22 α-amino acids incorporated into proteins. Only these 22 appear in the genetic code of life.
ammonia: Ammonia is an inorganic chemical compound of nitrogen and hydrogen with the formula NH3. A stable binary hydride and the simplest pnictogen hydride, ammonia is a colourless gas with a distinctive pungent smell. It is widely used in fertilizers, refrigerants, explosives, cleaning agents, and is a precursor for numerous chemicals. Biologically, it is a common nitrogenous waste, and it contributes significantly to the nutritional needs of terrestrial organisms by serving as a precursor to fertilisers. Around 70% of ammonia produced industrially is used to make fertilisers in various forms and composition, such as urea and diammonium phosphate. Ammonia in pure form is also applied directly into the soil.
amnion: The amnion is a membrane that closely covers human and various other embryos when they first form. It fills with amniotic fluid, which causes the amnion to expand and become the amniotic sac that provides a protective environment for the developing embryo. The amnion, along with the chorion, the yolk sac and the allantois protect the embryo. In birds, reptiles and monotremes, the protective sac is enclosed in a shell. In marsupials and placental mammals, it is enclosed in a uterus.
amniotic fluid: The amniotic fluid is the protective liquid contained by the amniotic sac of a gravid amniote. This fluid serves as a cushion for the growing fetus, but also serves to facilitate the exchange of nutrients, water, and biochemical products between mother and fetus.
amniotic fluid specimen: An amniotic fluid specimen is a sample of the protective liquid surrounding a fetus within the amniotic sac, often collected for prenatal testing to assess fetal health and development.
amphiregulin production: Amphiregulin production refers to the process by which cells synthesize and release amphiregulin, a growth factor involved in cell proliferation, differentiation, and tissue repair.
amplicon sequencing assay: An amplicon sequencing assay is a targeted sequencing technique that involves amplifying specific DNA regions of interest using PCR before sequencing them to analyze genetic variations.
amplification of intermethylated sites a: The amplification of intermethylated sites (AIMS) assay is a molecular biology technique used to detect and analyze DNA methylation patterns by amplifying regions between methylated DNA sites.
amplified DNA: Amplified DNA refers to DNA that has been replicated multiple times through processes such as polymerase chain reaction (PCR) to increase its quantity for analysis or experimentation.
amylase activity: Amylase activity refers to the enzymatic process by which amylase catalyzes the hydrolysis of starch into sugars, such as maltose and glucose, in biological systems.
amylase activity level assay: An amylase activity level assay is a diagnostic test used to measure the activity of the enzyme amylase in a biological sample, typically to assess pancreatic function or diagnose related disorders.
analog-to-digital converter: In electronics, an analog-to-digital converter is a system that converts an analog signal, such as a sound picked up by a microphone or light entering a digital camera, into a digital signal. An ADC may also provide an isolated measurement such as an electronic device that converts an analog input voltage or current to a digital number representing the magnitude of the voltage or current. Typically the digital output is a two's complement binary number that is proportional to the input, but there are other possibilities.
analysis subset ontology module: An "analysis subset ontology module" is a specialized component of an ontology that focuses on a specific subset of data or concepts for targeted analysis within a broader biomedical context.
analyte assay: An analyte assay is a laboratory procedure used to measure the presence, concentration, or activity of a specific substance (analyte) within a sample.
analyte measurement objective: An analyte measurement objective is a specific goal or target that defines the desired accuracy, precision, and reliability of measuring a particular substance or component within a biological sample.
analyte role: An "analyte role" refers to the function or purpose of a substance being measured or analyzed in a biological or chemical assay.
analytical balance: An analytical balance is a class of balance designed to measure small mass in the sub-milligram range. The measuring pan of an analytical balance is inside a transparent enclosure with doors so that dust does not collect and so any air currents in the room do not affect the balance's operation. This enclosure is often called a draft shield. The use of a mechanically vented balance safety enclosure, which has uniquely designed acrylic airfoils, allows a smooth turbulence-free airflow that prevents balance fluctuation and the measure of mass down to 1 μg without fluctuations or loss of product. Also, the sample must be at room temperature to prevent natural convection from forming air currents inside the enclosure from causing an error in reading. Single pan mechanical substitution balance is a method of maintaining consistent response throughout the useful capacity of the balance. This is achieved by maintaining a constant load on the balance beam and thus the fulcrum, by subtracting mass on the same side of the beam as which the sample is added.
analytical chromatography: In chemical analysis, chromatography is a laboratory technique for the separation of a mixture into its components. The mixture is dissolved in a fluid solvent called the mobile phase, which carries it through a system on which a material called the stationary phase is fixed. Because the different constituents of the mixture tend to have different affinities for the stationary phase and are retained for different lengths of time depending on their interactions with its surface sites, the constituents travel at different apparent velocities in the mobile fluid, causing them to separate. The separation is based on the differential partitioning between the mobile and the stationary phases. Subtle differences in a compound's partition coefficient result in differential retention on the stationary phase and thus affect the separation.
analytical chromatography measuring Chik: Analytical chromatography measuring Chikungunya IgM antibody is a laboratory technique used to separate and quantify the presence of IgM antibodies specific to the Chikungunya virus in a sample, aiding in the diagnosis of recent infection.
analytical cytology data file: An analytical cytology data file is a digital record containing quantitative and qualitative data derived from the analysis of cells, often used for diagnostic or research purposes in biomedical studies.
anatomical cluster: An anatomical cluster refers to a group of related anatomical structures or features that are located in close proximity to each other within the body.
anatomical structure quality: Anatomical structure quality refers to the inherent characteristics or attributes that define the physical and functional aspects of a biological structure within an organism.
aneuploid: Aneuploidy is the presence of an abnormal number of chromosomes in a cell, for example a human somatic cell having 45 or 47 chromosomes instead of the usual 46. It does not include a difference of one or more complete sets of chromosomes. A cell with any number of complete chromosome sets is called a euploid cell.
angiograph: The film or image of the blood vessels produced by angiography.
animal cage: A cage is an enclosure often made of mesh, bars, or wires, used to confine, contain or protect something or someone. A cage can serve many purposes, including keeping an animal or person in captivity, capturing an animal or person, and displaying an animal at a zoo.
animal care protocol: An animal care protocol is a detailed plan outlining the procedures and ethical guidelines for the humane treatment and use of animals in research or testing, ensuring compliance with regulatory and institutional standards.
animal euthanization: Animal euthanization is the humane process of intentionally ending an animal's life to alleviate suffering or for other ethical, medical, or welfare reasons.
animal feeding: Animal feeding refers to the practice of providing food and nutrients to animals to support their growth, health, and productivity.
animal-biting arthropod specimen collect: Animal-biting arthropod specimen collection by aspiration is a method of gathering arthropods, such as mosquitoes or ticks, that bite animals, using suction devices to capture them for study or analysis.
animal-biting outdoor arthropod specimen: Animal-biting outdoor arthropod specimen collection by aspiration refers to the process of capturing arthropods, such as mosquitoes or ticks, that feed on animals, using suction devices in outdoor environments for research or monitoring purposes.
anion exchange column: An anion exchange column is a type of chromatography column used to separate and purify negatively charged molecules, such as anions, based on their affinity to a positively charged stationary phase.
anion trap column: An anion trap column is a component used in liquid chromatography systems to selectively capture and remove anionic contaminants from a sample or mobile phase, enhancing the accuracy and sensitivity of the analysis.
ankle joint: The ankle, the talocrural region or the jumping bone (informal) is the area where the foot and the leg meet. The ankle includes three joints: the ankle joint proper or talocrural joint, the subtalar joint, and the inferior tibiofibular joint. The movements produced at this joint are dorsiflexion and plantarflexion of the foot. In common usage, the term ankle refers exclusively to the ankle region. In medical terminology, "ankle" can refer broadly to the region or specifically to the talocrural joint.
ankle joint functionality: Ankle joint functionality refers to the ability of the ankle joint to perform its normal range of motion and support activities such as walking, running, and balancing, by facilitating the movement and stability of the foot relative to the leg.
anterior nasal swab specimen: An anterior nasal swab specimen is a sample collected from the front part of the nasal cavity using a swab, typically for diagnostic testing of respiratory infections.
anterior nasal wall: The anterior nasal wall refers to the front part of the nasal cavity, including the structures that form the entrance of the nose.
anterior to: "Anterior to" refers to a position that is situated in front of or towards the front of another structure or part in the body.
antibacterial: An antibiotic is a type of antimicrobial substance active against bacteria. It is the most important type of antibacterial agent for fighting bacterial infections, and antibiotic medications are widely used in the treatment and prevention of such infections. They may either kill or inhibit the growth of bacteria. A limited number of antibiotics also possess antiprotozoal activity. Antibiotics are not effective against viruses such as the ones which cause the common cold or influenza. Drugs which inhibit growth of viruses are termed antiviral drugs or antivirals. Antibiotics are also not effective against fungi. Drugs which inhibit growth of fungi are called antifungal drugs.
antibiotic administration process: The antibiotic administration process refers to the method and sequence of delivering antibiotics to a patient to treat or prevent bacterial infections.
antibodies from lymphocyte secretions as: The "antibodies from lymphocyte secretions assay" is a laboratory test used to detect and measure the presence and concentration of antibodies produced by lymphocytes in a sample.
antibody binding detection by fluorescen: Antibody binding detection by fluorescence quenching is a technique used to identify the interaction between an antibody and its target antigen by observing a decrease in fluorescence intensity, indicating the quenching effect caused by the binding event.
antibody cross-blocking assay: An antibody cross-blocking assay is a laboratory technique used to determine whether different antibodies can simultaneously bind to the same antigen or if they interfere with each other's binding.
antibody detection by cytometric bead ar: Antibody detection by cytometric bead array assay is a laboratory technique used to identify and quantify specific antibodies in a sample by utilizing fluorescently labeled beads that bind to the target antibodies, allowing for analysis via flow cytometry.
antibody purification of H2-Db protein c: Antibody purification of H2-Db protein complex refers to the process of isolating the H2-Db protein complex from a mixture using specific antibodies that bind to it, facilitating its separation and study.
antibody purification of H2-Dd protein c: Antibody purification of H2-Dd protein complex refers to the process of isolating the H2-Dd protein complex from a mixture using specific antibodies that bind to it, facilitating its separation and study.

Antibody purification of H2-Dd protein complex and/or H2-Kd protein complex refers to the process of isolating these specific major histocompatibility complex (MHC) class I protein complexes from a mixture using antibodies that specifically bind to them.
antibody purification of H2-IA protein c: Antibody purification of H2-IA protein complex refers to the process of isolating the H2-IA protein complex from a mixture using specific antibodies that bind to it, allowing for its separation and study.
antibody purification of H2-IAd protein: Antibody purification of H2-IAd protein complex refers to the process of isolating and purifying the H2-IAd protein complex from a mixture using specific antibodies that bind to this complex, typically for research or therapeutic purposes.
antibody purification of H2-IAg7 protein: Antibody purification of H2-IAg7 protein complex refers to the process of isolating and purifying the specific antibodies that bind to the H2-IAg7 protein complex, which is a major histocompatibility complex class II molecule involved in immune response.
antibody purification of H2-Kb protein c: Antibody purification of H2-Kb, H2-Ks, and H2-Kq protein complexes refers to the process of isolating these specific major histocompatibility complex (MHC) class I protein complexes from a mixture using antibodies that specifically bind to them.
antibody purification of H2-Kd protein c: Antibody purification of H2-Kd protein complex refers to the process of isolating the H2-Kd protein complex from a mixture using specific antibodies that bind to it, allowing for its separation and study.
antibody purification of H2-Ld protein c: Antibody purification of H2-Ld, H2-Db, and/or H2-Dq protein complexes refers to the process of isolating these specific major histocompatibility complex (MHC) class I protein complexes from a mixture using antibodies that specifically bind to them.
antibody purification of HLA protein com: Antibody purification of HLA protein complex with A2 serotype refers to the process of isolating and purifying the human leukocyte antigen (HLA) protein complex, specifically of the A2 serotype, using antibodies that specifically bind to this complex.

Antibody purification of HLA protein complex with A2 serotype and/or HLA protein complex with A28 serotype refers to the process of isolating specific human leukocyte antigen (HLA) protein complexes, which are associated with the A2 and/or A28 serotypes, using antibodies that

Antibody purification of HLA protein complex with A24 serotype refers to the process of isolating and purifying the human leukocyte antigen (HLA) protein complex, specifically of the A24 serotype, using antibodies that specifically bind to this antigen.

Antibody purification of HLA protein complex with A29 serotype refers to the process of isolating and purifying the human leukocyte antigen (HLA) protein complex, specifically the A29 serotype, using antibodies that specifically bind to this antigen.

Antibody purification of HLA protein complex with B27 serotype refers to the process of isolating and purifying the human leukocyte antigen (HLA) protein complex, specifically the B27 serotype, using antibodies that specifically bind to this antigen.

Antibody purification of HLA protein complex with DQ3 serotype refers to the process of isolating and purifying the human leukocyte antigen (HLA) protein complex, specifically the DQ3 serotype, using antibodies that specifically bind to this antigen.
antibody purification of HLA-C protein c: Antibody purification of HLA-C protein complex refers to the process of isolating the HLA-C protein complex from a mixture using specific antibodies that bind to it, allowing for its separation and study.
antibody purification of HLA-DP protein: Antibody purification of HLA-DP protein complex refers to the process of isolating the HLA-DP protein complex from a mixture using specific antibodies that bind to it, facilitating its separation and study.
antibody purification of HLA-DR protein: Antibody purification of HLA-DR protein complex refers to the process of isolating the HLA-DR protein complex from a mixture using specific antibodies that bind to it, allowing for its separation and study.
antibody purification of MHC class I pro: Antibody purification of MHC class I protein complex is a laboratory technique used to isolate and purify major histocompatibility complex (MHC) class I proteins from a mixture using specific antibodies that bind to these proteins.
antibody purification of MHC class II pr: Antibody purification of MHC class II protein complex refers to the process of isolating MHC class II protein complexes from a mixture using specific antibodies that bind to these proteins, allowing for their separation and study.
antibody purification of MHC protein com: Antibody purification of MHC protein complex refers to the process of isolating major histocompatibility complex (MHC) proteins from a mixture using antibodies that specifically bind to these proteins, enabling their study or use in various biomedical applications.
antibody purification of cattle MHC clas: Antibody purification of cattle MHC class I protein complex refers to the process of isolating and purifying the major histocompatibility complex class I proteins from cattle using specific antibodies, to study their structure and function in immune response.

Antibody purification of cattle MHC class II protein complex refers to the process of isolating and purifying the major histocompatibility complex class II proteins from cattle using specific antibodies, which are crucial for the immune response by presenting antigens to T cells.
antibody purification of human MHC class: Antibody purification of human MHC class I protein complex refers to the process of isolating and purifying the major histocompatibility complex class I proteins from human cells using specific antibodies that bind to these proteins.

Antibody purification of human MHC class II protein complex refers to the process of isolating and purifying the major histocompatibility complex (MHC) class II proteins from human cells using specific antibodies that bind to these proteins, facilitating their study and use in research or therapeutic applications.
antibody purification of mouse MHC class: Antibody purification of mouse MHC class I protein complex refers to the process of isolating and purifying the major histocompatibility complex (MHC) class I proteins from mouse cells using specific antibodies that bind to these proteins.

Antibody purification of mouse MHC class I protein complex with H2-b haplotype and/or mouse MHC protein complex with H2-p haplotype refers to the process of isolating and purifying specific major histocompatibility complex (MHC) protein complexes from mice, which are

Antibody purification of mouse MHC class II protein complex refers to the process of isolating and purifying the major histocompatibility complex class II proteins from mouse cells using specific antibodies, typically for research or therapeutic purposes.

Antibody purification of mouse or rat MHC class II protein complex involves isolating these immune system proteins, specifically from mice or rats with the RT1-A haplotype, using antibodies to study their structure and function.
antibody purification of pig MHC class I: Antibody purification of pig MHC class I protein complex refers to the process of isolating and purifying the major histocompatibility complex (MHC) class I proteins from pigs using specific antibodies, to study their structure and function.

Antibody purification of pig, cattle, or human MHC class I protein complex refers to the process of isolating and purifying the major histocompatibility complex (MHC) class I proteins from these species using specific antibodies, to study their structure, function, or interactions.
antibody purification of rat MHC class I: Antibody purification of rat MHC class I protein complex refers to the process of isolating and purifying the major histocompatibility complex class I protein from rat cells using specific antibodies that bind to this protein.
antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity: Antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity (ADCC), also referred to as antibody-dependent cell-mediated cytotoxicity, is a mechanism of cell-mediated immune defense whereby an effector cell of the immune system kills a target cell, whose membrane-surface antigens have been bound by specific antibodies. It is one of the mechanisms through which antibodies, as part of the humoral immune response, can act to limit and contain infection.
anticoagulant tube storage of blood spec: Anticoagulant tube storage of blood specimen refers to the practice of collecting and storing blood samples in tubes containing substances that prevent clotting, thereby preserving the sample for accurate laboratory analysis.
anticoagulant-containing test tube: An anticoagulant-containing test tube is a laboratory tube that has been pre-filled with a substance to prevent blood from clotting, allowing for accurate blood sample analysis.
antigen: In immunology, an antigen (Ag) is a molecule, moiety, foreign particulate matter, or an allergen, such as pollen, that can bind to a specific antibody or T-cell receptor. The presence of antigens in the body may trigger an immune response.
antigen binding: Antigen binding refers to the specific interaction between an antigen and an antibody or a receptor on immune cells, which is crucial for the immune system to recognize and respond to foreign substances.
antigen detection by cytometric bead arr: Antigen detection by cytometric bead array assay is a technique used to identify and quantify specific antigens in a sample by using fluorescently labeled beads that bind to the target antigens, allowing for analysis via flow cytometry.
antigen inhibition assay measuring bindi: An antigen inhibition assay measuring the binding of a B cell epitope:antibody complex is a laboratory technique used to evaluate the interaction between a specific region of an antigen (B cell epitope) and an antibody by assessing the extent to which the binding can be inhibited by competing molecules.
antigen inhibition assay measuring the d: An antigen inhibition assay measuring the dissociation constant [KD] of a B cell epitope:antibody complex approximated by IC50 is a laboratory technique used to estimate the strength of binding between an antibody and its specific antigenic epitope by determining the concentration of antigen required to inhibit
antigen presentation function: Antigen presentation function refers to the process by which immune cells display antigens on their surface, typically via major histocompatibility complex (MHC) molecules, to be recognized by T cells, thereby initiating an immune response.
antigen processing and presentation: Antigen processing and presentation is the biological process by which proteins are broken down into peptides and displayed on the surface of cells by major histocompatibility complex (MHC) molecules for recognition by T cells.
antigen role: The term "antigen role" refers to the function of a substance, typically a protein or polysaccharide, in eliciting an immune response by being recognized as foreign by the immune system, thereby triggering the production of antibodies or the activation of immune cells.
antigen specific antibodies assay: An antigen-specific antibodies assay is a laboratory test designed to detect and measure antibodies in a sample that specifically bind to a particular antigen, indicating an immune response to that antigen.
antigen specific antibodies assay datum: An "antigen specific antibodies assay datum" refers to a single data point or measurement obtained from a test designed to detect and quantify antibodies that specifically bind to a particular antigen.
antigen specific antibodies in blood ass: An "antigen specific antibodies in blood assay" is a laboratory test that detects and measures antibodies in the blood that are specifically targeted against a particular antigen, indicating an immune response to that antigen.

An "antigen specific antibodies in blood assay datum" refers to the data obtained from a laboratory test that measures the presence and concentration of antibodies in the blood that are specifically targeted against a particular antigen.
antigen specific antibodies in milk assa: An "antigen specific antibodies in milk assay" is a laboratory test designed to detect and measure antibodies in milk that are specific to a particular antigen, indicating an immune response to that antigen.

An "antigen specific antibodies in milk assay datum" refers to a data point obtained from an assay that measures the presence and concentration of antibodies in milk that are specific to a particular antigen.
antigen:antibody complex: An antigen:antibody complex is a molecular formation resulting from the binding of an antibody to a specific antigen, often leading to an immune response.
antithrombin-III: Antithrombin-III is a protein in the blood that helps regulate blood clotting by inhibiting thrombin and other enzymes involved in the coagulation process.
antithrombin-III berichrome assay: The antithrombin-III berichrome assay is a laboratory test used to measure the activity or concentration of antithrombin III, a protein that helps regulate blood clotting by inhibiting thrombin and other clotting factors.
aorta: The aorta is the main and largest artery in the human body, originating from the left ventricle of the heart, branching upwards immediately after, and extending down to the abdomen, where it splits at the aortic bifurcation into two smaller arteries. The aorta distributes oxygenated blood to all parts of the body through the systemic circulation.
aorta specimen: An "aorta specimen" refers to a sample of tissue taken from the aorta, the largest artery in the body, typically for the purpose of medical examination or research.
apron: An apron is a garment worn over other clothing to cover the front of the body to protect from liquids. They have several purposes, most commonly as a functional accessory that protects clothes and skin from stains and marks. However, other types of aprons may be worn as a decoration, for hygienic reasons, as part of a uniform, or as protection from certain dangers such as acid, allergens or excessive heat. It can also be used at work stations to hold extra tools and pieces or protect from dust and unwanted materials.
aquatic arthropod specimen collection pr: The aquatic arthropod specimen collection process refers to the systematic method of gathering, preserving, and documenting arthropods, such as insects and crustaceans, from aquatic environments for scientific study and analysis.
arc lamp: An arc lamp or arc light is a lamp that produces light by an electric arc.
areola: The human areola is the pigmented area on the breast around the nipple. More generally, an areola is a small circular area on the body with a different histology from the surrounding tissue, or other small circular areas such as an inflamed region of skin.
areolar swab specimen: An areolar swab specimen is a sample collected from the areola, the pigmented area surrounding the nipple, typically for diagnostic or research purposes.
argon ion laser: An ion laser is a gas laser that uses an ionized gas as its lasing medium. Like other gas lasers, ion lasers feature a sealed cavity containing the laser medium and mirrors forming a Fabry–Pérot resonator. Unlike helium–neon lasers, the energy level transitions that contribute to laser action come from ions. Because of the large amount of energy required to excite the ionic transitions used in ion lasers, the required current is much greater, and as a result almost all except for the smallest ion lasers are water-cooled. A small air-cooled ion laser might produce, for example, 130 milliwatts of output light with a tube current of about 10 amperes and a voltage of 105 volts. Since one ampere times one volt is one watt, this is an electrical power input of about one kilowatt. Subtracting the (desirable) light output of 130 mW from power input, this leaves the large amount of waste heat of nearly one kW. This has to be dissipated by the cooling system. In other words, the power efficiency is very low.
arithmetic mean calculation: Arithmetic mean calculation is the process of determining the average of a set of numerical values by summing them and then dividing by the count of the values.
array based nucleic acid structure mappi: An array-based nucleic acid structure mapping assay is a technique used to analyze the structural features of nucleic acids, such as DNA or RNA, by employing microarray technology to detect interactions or modifications at specific sites.
array image creation: Array image creation refers to the process of generating visual representations of data collected from an array, such as a microarray, to facilitate analysis and interpretation in biomedical research.
array manufacturer role: The term 'array manufacturer role' refers to the function or responsibility of a company or entity in producing and supplying microarrays, which are laboratory tools used for analyzing gene expression or genetic variations.
array platform variation design: Array platform variation design refers to the systematic approach used to assess and compare the performance and variability of different microarray platforms in measuring gene expression or other molecular features.
array scanner: An array scanner is a device used to detect and quantify signals from microarrays, typically by scanning and analyzing fluorescent or luminescent markers on the array surface.
arrayer: A commission of array was a commission given by English sovereigns to officers or gentry in a given territory to muster and array the inhabitants and to see them in a condition for war, or to put soldiers of a country in a condition for military service. The term arrayers is used in some ancient English statutes, for an officer who had a commission of array.
arterial blood: Arterial blood is the oxygenated blood in the circulatory system found in the pulmonary vein, the left chambers of the heart, and in the arteries. It is bright red in color, while venous blood is dark red in color. It is the contralateral term to venous blood.
arterial blood chloride assay: An arterial blood chloride assay is a laboratory test that measures the concentration of chloride ions in arterial blood to assess electrolyte balance and acid-base status in the body.
arterial blood creatinine assay: An arterial blood creatinine assay is a laboratory test that measures the level of creatinine in the arterial blood to assess kidney function and overall metabolic health.
arterial blood glucose assay: An arterial blood glucose assay is a diagnostic test that measures the concentration of glucose in the blood taken from an artery, used to assess and monitor blood sugar levels.
arterial blood hematocrit assay: An arterial blood hematocrit assay is a laboratory test that measures the proportion of red blood cells in a sample of arterial blood, indicating the blood's oxygen-carrying capacity.
arterial blood hemoglobin assay: An arterial blood hemoglobin assay is a laboratory test that measures the concentration of hemoglobin in a sample of arterial blood to assess oxygen-carrying capacity and detect potential blood disorders.
arterial blood lactic acid assay: An arterial blood lactic acid assay is a diagnostic test that measures the concentration of lactic acid in the blood drawn from an artery, often used to assess tissue oxygenation and metabolic function.
arterial blood potassium assay: An arterial blood potassium assay is a diagnostic test that measures the concentration of potassium in the blood obtained from an artery, used to assess electrolyte balance and monitor conditions affecting potassium levels.
arterial blood sodium assay: An arterial blood sodium assay is a diagnostic test that measures the concentration of sodium in the blood obtained from an artery, used to assess electrolyte balance and overall health.
arterial blood specimen: An arterial blood specimen is a sample of blood drawn from an artery, typically used to measure gases and other parameters to assess respiratory and metabolic function.
artery: An artery is a blood vessel in humans and most other animals that takes oxygenated blood away from the heart in the systemic circulation to one or more parts of the body. Exceptions that carry deoxygenated blood are the pulmonary arteries in the pulmonary circulation that carry blood to the lungs for oxygenation, and the umbilical arteries in the fetal circulation that carry deoxygenated blood to the placenta. It consists of a multi-layered artery wall wrapped into a tube-shaped channel.
arthropod attractor role: The term "arthropod attractor role" refers to the function or characteristic of a substance or organism that draws arthropods, such as insects or spiders, towards it.
arthropod collection process with automa: The arthropod collection process with automated identification refers to the systematic gathering of arthropods, such as insects and spiders, using technology that automatically identifies and classifies them based on their physical and genetic characteristics.
arthropod meal of blood specimen: "Arthropod meal of blood specimen" refers to a sample of blood that has been ingested by an arthropod, such as a mosquito or tick, which can be analyzed for various purposes, including the study of vector-borne diseases.
arthropod resting in animal house specim: 'Arthropod resting in animal house specimen collection by aspiration' refers to the process of collecting arthropods, such as insects or arachnids, that are resting in animal housing facilities by using a suction device to aspirate them for study or monitoring purposes.
arthropod resting in human house specime: "Arthropod resting in human house specimen collection by aspiration" refers to the process of collecting arthropods, such as insects or spiders, that are resting inside a human dwelling using a suction device for research or study purposes.
arthropod resting outdoors on artificial: 'Arthropod resting outdoors on artificial support specimen collection by aspiration' refers to the method of collecting arthropods, such as insects, that are resting on man-made structures outside, using a suction device to capture them for study or analysis.
arthropod resting outdoors on natural su: 'Arthropod resting outdoors on natural support specimen collection by aspiration' refers to the method of collecting arthropods, such as insects or spiders, from their natural resting places outdoors using a suction device to capture them for study or analysis.
arthropod resting outdoors specimen coll: 'Arthropod resting outdoors specimen collection by aspiration' refers to the method of collecting arthropods, such as insects or arachnids, from their outdoor resting sites using a suction device to study their behavior, distribution, or disease-carrying potential.
arthropod specimen collection by aspirat: Arthropod specimen collection by aspiration is a method of gathering arthropods, such as insects or arachnids, using a suction device to capture them without causing harm.
arthropod specimen collection process: The arthropod specimen collection process refers to the systematic gathering and preservation of arthropods, such as insects, arachnids, and crustaceans, for scientific study and research.
arthropod trap: An "arthropod trap" is a device or method used to capture arthropods, such as insects, spiders, and other joint-legged invertebrates, for study or pest control purposes.
arthropod trap containing small non-huma: An "arthropod trap containing small non-human animal bait" is a device used to capture arthropods by luring them with bait derived from small non-human animals.
artificial pit shelter: An artificial pit shelter is a man-made excavation or structure designed to provide a controlled environment for the study or protection of organisms, often used in ecological or biological research.
artificially induced DNA repair: Artificially induced DNA repair refers to the deliberate stimulation or enhancement of the natural DNA repair mechanisms in cells through external interventions, such as chemicals or genetic engineering, to correct or mitigate DNA damage.
artificially induced cell membrane lysis: Artificially induced cell membrane lysis refers to the deliberate disruption or breakdown of a cell's membrane using external agents or techniques to release its contents for analysis or other purposes.
artificially induced methylation: Artificially induced methylation refers to the deliberate addition of methyl groups to DNA molecules in a laboratory setting to study or modify gene expression and regulation.
artificially induced nucleic acid hybrid: Artificially induced nucleic acid hybridization is a laboratory technique that involves the deliberate pairing of complementary strands of nucleic acids, such as DNA or RNA, from different sources to form a hybrid molecule.
artificially induced reverse transcripti: Artificially induced reverse transcription is a laboratory process where RNA is converted into complementary DNA (cDNA) using an enzyme called reverse transcriptase, typically for research or diagnostic purposes.
aspartate aminotransferase (human): Aspartate aminotransferase (human) is an enzyme found in the liver and heart that plays a crucial role in amino acid metabolism by catalyzing the transfer of an amino group from aspartate to alpha-ketoglutarate, forming oxaloacetate and glutamate.
aspartate aminotransferase (human) assay: An aspartate aminotransferase (human) assay is a diagnostic test used to measure the level of the enzyme aspartate aminotransferase in human blood, which can help assess liver function and detect liver damage.
aspartate aminotransferase activity leve: An aspartate aminotransferase activity level assay is a laboratory test that measures the activity level of the enzyme aspartate aminotransferase in the blood, which is used to assess liver function and detect liver damage.
asphyxiation: Asphyxia or asphyxiation is a condition of deficient supply of oxygen to the body which arises from abnormal breathing. Asphyxia causes generalized hypoxia, which affects all the tissues and organs, some more rapidly than others. There are many circumstances that can induce asphyxia, all of which are characterized by the inability of a person to acquire sufficient oxygen through breathing for an extended period of time. Asphyxia can cause coma or death. In 2015, about 9.8 million cases of unintentional suffocation occurred which resulted in 35,600 deaths. The word asphyxia is from Ancient Greek α- "without" and σφύξις sphyxis, "squeeze".
aspiration specimen collection: Aspiration specimen collection is a medical procedure that involves using a needle and syringe to withdraw fluid or tissue from the body for diagnostic or therapeutic purposes.
assay: An assay is an investigative (analytic) procedure in laboratory medicine, mining, pharmacology, environmental biology and molecular biology for qualitatively assessing or quantitatively measuring the presence, amount, or functional activity of a target entity. The measured entity is often called the analyte, the measurand, or the target of the assay. The analyte can be a drug, biochemical substance, chemical element or compound, or cell in an organism or organic sample. An assay usually aims to measure an analyte's intensive property and express it in the relevant measurement unit.
assay antigen role: The "assay antigen role" refers to the function of an antigen in a laboratory test or assay, where it is used to detect or quantify the presence of specific antibodies or other substances.
assay array: An assay array is a high-throughput platform used to simultaneously measure multiple biological analytes, such as proteins or nucleic acids, in a sample for research or diagnostic purposes.
assay bead: An assay bead is a small, spherical particle used in biomedical assays to facilitate the detection, quantification, or analysis of biological molecules or reactions.
assay detecting IFN-gamma production: An assay detecting IFN-gamma production is a laboratory test used to measure the production of interferon-gamma, a cytokine involved in immune responses, typically to assess immune function or diagnose infections and immune disorders.
assay detecting a molecular label: An assay detecting a molecular label is a laboratory technique used to identify and measure the presence of a specific molecular marker or tag within a sample.
assay for transposase-accessible chromat: Assay for transposase-accessible chromatin using sequencing (ATAC-seq) is a technique used to assess genome-wide chromatin accessibility by employing a transposase enzyme to insert sequencing adapters into open regions of chromatin, allowing for the identification of active regulatory elements.
assay kit: An assay kit is a pre-packaged set of reagents and materials used to perform a specific laboratory test or experiment to measure the presence, amount, or activity of a target substance.
assay measuring B cell epitope specific: An assay measuring B cell epitope specific in vivo activity is a test that evaluates the immune response of B cells to specific antigenic sites within a living organism.
assay measuring MHC ligand processing an: An assay measuring MHC ligand processing and presentation is a laboratory test used to evaluate the ability of cells to process and present peptide antigens on major histocompatibility complex (MHC) molecules, which is crucial for immune recognition and response.
assay measuring T cell epitope specific: An assay measuring T cell epitope specific in vivo activity is a test that evaluates the immune response of T cells to specific antigenic peptides within a living organism.

An "assay measuring T cell epitope specific suppression in vitro" is a laboratory test designed to evaluate the ability of certain agents or conditions to inhibit the immune response of T cells to specific antigenic epitopes outside of a living organism.
assay measuring a binding constant of a: An assay measuring a binding constant of a B cell epitope:antibody complex is a laboratory test used to quantify the strength and stability of the interaction between a specific region on an antigen (B cell epitope) and an antibody.

An assay measuring a binding constant of a MHC:ligand complex is a laboratory test used to determine the strength and stability of the interaction between a major histocompatibility complex (MHC) molecule and its ligand, typically a peptide or antigen.

An assay measuring a binding constant of a T cell epitope:MHC:TCR complex is a laboratory test used to quantify the strength and stability of the interaction between a T cell receptor (TCR), a major histocompatibility complex (MHC) molecule, and a specific T cell ep
assay measuring binding of a B cell epit: An assay measuring the binding of a B cell epitope:antibody complex is a laboratory test designed to evaluate the interaction and affinity between a specific epitope on an antigen and its corresponding antibody.
assay measuring binding of a MHC:ligand: An assay measuring the binding of a MHC:ligand complex is a laboratory test designed to evaluate the interaction between a major histocompatibility complex (MHC) molecule and its ligand, typically a peptide, to understand immune recognition and response.
assay measuring binding of a T cell epit: An assay measuring the binding of a T cell epitope:MHC:TCR complex is a laboratory test used to evaluate the interaction and affinity between a T cell receptor (TCR), a major histocompatibility complex (MHC) molecule, and a specific T cell epitope, which
assay measuring binding of a cell-bound-: An assay measuring binding of a cell-bound-MHC:ligand complex is a laboratory test designed to evaluate the interaction between a major histocompatibility complex (MHC) molecule on the surface of a cell and a specific ligand, often to assess immune response or compatibility.
assay measuring binding of a cell-lysate: An assay measuring the binding of a cell-lysate-MHC:ligand complex is a laboratory test used to evaluate the interaction between a major histocompatibility complex (MHC) molecule and a ligand within a cell lysate, often to study immune responses or antigen presentation.

assay measuring epitope specific vascula: An "assay measuring epitope specific vascular endothelial growth factor production by T cells" is a laboratory test designed to quantify the production of vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) by T cells in response to specific epitopes, which are the parts of antigens recognized by the immune system.
assay measuring interleukin-9 production: An assay measuring interleukin-9 production by T cells is a laboratory test designed to quantify the amount of interleukin-9 cytokine produced by T cells, which can provide insights into immune response and inflammation.
assay measuring qualitative binding of a: An assay measuring the qualitative binding of a B cell epitope:antibody complex is a test used to evaluate the presence and interaction strength between a specific B cell epitope and an antibody, indicating the antibody's ability to recognize and bind to the epitope.

assay measuring quantitative binding of: An assay measuring quantitative binding of a MHC:ligand complex is a laboratory test used to determine the strength and specificity of the interaction between a major histocompatibility complex (MHC) molecule and its ligand, often a peptide, by quantifying the binding affinity or kinetics.

assay measuring the MHC ligand binding o: An assay measuring the MHC ligand binding on rate [kon] of a MHC:ligand complex quantifies the rate at which a ligand binds to a major histocompatibility complex (MHC) molecule, reflecting the initial kinetics of the interaction.
assay measuring the association constant: An assay measuring the association constant [KA] of a B cell epitope:antibody complex is a laboratory test that quantifies the strength of the binding interaction between a specific region on an antigen (epitope) and an antibody.

An assay measuring the association constant [KA] of a MHC:ligand complex quantifies the strength and stability of the interaction between a major histocompatibility complex (MHC) molecule and its bound ligand, typically a peptide, by determining the rate at which they associate.

assay measuring the dissociation constan: An assay measuring the dissociation constant (KD) of a B cell epitope:antibody complex is a laboratory test used to determine the strength and stability of the binding interaction between a specific region on an antigen (epitope) and an antibody.

assay measuring the half life of a MHC:l: An assay measuring the half-life of an MHC:ligand complex is a laboratory test used to determine the duration for which a major histocompatibility complex (MHC) molecule remains bound to its ligand before dissociating.
assay measuring the half maximal effecti: An assay measuring the half maximal effective concentration (EC50) of a MHC:ligand complex quantifies the concentration of a ligand required to achieve half of the maximum binding or biological response when interacting with a major histocompatibility complex (MHC).
assay measuring the half maximal inhibit: An assay measuring the half maximal inhibitory concentration (IC50) of a MHC:ligand complex quantifies the concentration of a substance required to inhibit 50% of the binding interaction between a major histocompatibility complex (MHC) molecule and its ligand.
assay measuring the off rate [koff] of a: An assay measuring the off rate [koff] of a B cell epitope:antibody complex quantifies the rate at which an antibody dissociates from its specific epitope on a B cell, reflecting the stability and duration of the antibody-antigen interaction.

assay measuring the off rate measurement: An assay measuring the off rate measurement [koff] of a MHC:ligand complex quantifies the rate at which a ligand dissociates from a major histocompatibility complex (MHC) molecule, providing insights into the stability and duration of the interaction.
assay measuring the on rate [kon] of a B: An assay measuring the on rate [kon] of a B cell epitope:antibody complex quantifies the rate at which an antibody binds to a specific epitope on a B cell, reflecting the initial association kinetics of the interaction.
assay measuring the on rate [kon] of a T: An assay measuring the on rate [kon] of a T cell epitope:MHC:TCR complex quantifies the rate at which a T cell receptor (TCR) binds to a major histocompatibility complex (MHC) molecule presenting a specific epitope, reflecting the initial association
assay objective: An "assay objective" refers to the specific goal or purpose of a biological or chemical test, typically aimed at measuring or detecting the presence, quantity, or activity of a target substance or organism.
assay using chromatin immunoprecipitatio: An assay using chromatin immunoprecipitation (ChIP) is a laboratory technique used to investigate the interaction between proteins and DNA in the chromatin of cells, allowing researchers to determine the specific locations on the genome where proteins, such as transcription factors, bind.
assay validation objective: An assay validation objective is the goal of confirming that a particular assay is reliable, accurate, and reproducible for its intended analytical purpose in biomedical research or diagnostics.
assigning a centrally registered identif: Assigning a centrally registered identifier refers to the process of allocating a unique, standardized code or number to a biomedical entity, such as a clinical trial or a biological specimen, to facilitate consistent tracking and referencing across databases and studies.
assigning gene property based on phenoty: Assigning gene property based on phenotypic assessment involves determining the function or characteristics of a gene by analyzing the observable traits or phenotypes it influences.
atomic emission detector: An atomic emission detector is an analytical device used to measure the concentration of elements in a sample by detecting the light emitted from excited atoms as they return to their ground state.
atrial appendage specimen: An atrial appendage specimen refers to a tissue sample taken from the atrial appendage, a small, ear-shaped pouch in the upper chambers of the heart, often for diagnostic or research purposes.
atrium auricular region: The "atrium auricular region" refers to the area of the heart associated with the atria, which are the two upper chambers that receive blood returning to the heart from the body and lungs.
aunt clinical history of cancer: "Aunt clinical history of cancer" refers to the medical record or background information regarding cancer diagnoses and treatments experienced by an individual's aunt, which may be relevant for assessing familial cancer risk.
auto injector: An auto-injector is a medical device designed to deliver a specific dose of medication, typically via a spring-loaded syringe, for self-administration or use by non-medical personnel.
autoclave: An autoclave is a machine used to carry out industrial and scientific processes requiring elevated temperature and pressure in relation to ambient pressure and/or temperature. Autoclaves are used before surgical procedures to perform sterilization and in the chemical industry to cure coatings and vulcanize rubber and for hydrothermal synthesis. Industrial autoclaves are used in industrial applications, especially in the manufacturing of composites.
autofluorescence assay: An autofluorescence assay is a technique used to measure the natural emission of light by biological structures when they absorb light, often used to analyze cellular components or detect changes in tissues without the need for external fluorescent labels.
autofluorescence microscopy assay: An autofluorescence microscopy assay is a technique used to visualize and analyze the natural emission of light by biological structures when they absorb light, without the need for external fluorescent dyes or labels.
autoimmune disease: An autoimmune disease is a condition that results from an anomalous response of the adaptive immune system, wherein it mistakenly targets and attacks healthy, functioning parts of the body as if they were foreign organisms. It is estimated that there are more than 80 recognized autoimmune diseases, with recent scientific evidence suggesting the existence of potentially more than 100 distinct conditions. Nearly any body part can be involved.
automated count venous blood reticulocyt: An automated count venous blood reticulocyte count assay is a laboratory test that uses automated technology to measure the number of reticulocytes, or immature red blood cells, in a venous blood sample to assess bone marrow function and red blood cell production.
automated differential venous blood baso: An automated differential venous blood basophil count assay is a laboratory test that uses automated technology to measure and quantify the number of basophils, a type of white blood cell, in a venous blood sample.
automated differential venous blood eosi: An automated differential venous blood eosinophil count assay is a laboratory test that uses automated equipment to measure and quantify the number of eosinophils, a type of white blood cell, in a venous blood sample to aid in diagnosing and monitoring various medical conditions.
automated differential venous blood lymp: An automated differential venous blood lymphocyte count assay is a laboratory test that uses automated technology to quantify and differentiate lymphocyte subtypes in a blood sample drawn from a vein.
automated differential venous blood mono: An automated differential venous blood monocyte count assay is a laboratory test that uses automated technology to measure and differentiate the number of monocytes in a blood sample drawn from a vein.
automated differential venous blood neut: An automated differential venous blood neutrophil count assay is a laboratory test that uses automated technology to measure and differentiate the number of neutrophils, a type of white blood cell, in a sample of venous blood.
automatic staining machine: An automatic staining machine is a laboratory device designed to apply stains to biological specimens, such as tissue sections or cells, in a consistent and efficient manner without manual intervention.
automatic tissue processor: An automatic tissue processor is a laboratory device used to prepare biological tissue samples by automatically performing a series of dehydration, clearing, and infiltration steps to make them suitable for microscopic examination.
autosampler: An autosampler is commonly a device that is coupled to an analytical instrument providing samples periodically for analysis. An autosampler can also be understood as a device that collects samples periodically from a large sample source, like the atmosphere or a lake, for example.
autotransplantation: The transplantation of tissue from one part of the body to another
avalanche photodiode: An avalanche photodiode (APD) is a highly sensitive type of photodiode, which in general are semiconductor diodes that convert light into electricity via the photovoltaic effect. APDs use materials and a structure optimised for operating with high reverse bias voltage, approaching the reverse breakdown voltage, such that charge carriers generated by the photovoltaic effect are multiplied by an avalanche breakdown; thus they can be used to detect relatively small amounts of light.
average depth of sequence coverage: The average depth of sequence coverage refers to the mean number of times each nucleotide in a DNA sequence is read during sequencing, indicating the reliability and accuracy of the sequencing data.
average linkage hierarchical clustering: Average linkage hierarchical clustering is a method of hierarchical clustering in which the distance between two clusters is defined as the average distance between all pairs of data points, one from each cluster.
average value: In ordinary language, an average is a single number or value that best represents a set of data. The type of average taken as most typically representative of a list of numbers is the arithmetic mean – the sum of the numbers divided by how many numbers are in the list. For example, the mean or average of the numbers 2, 3, 4, 7, and 9 is 5. Depending on the context, the most representative statistic to be taken as the average might be another measure of central tendency, such as the mid-range, median, mode or geometric mean. For example, the average personal income is often given as the median – the number below which are 50% of personal incomes and above which are 50% of personal incomes – because the mean would be higher by including personal incomes from a few billionaires.
averaging data transformation: Averaging data transformation is a statistical method used to reduce variability and enhance signal clarity by calculating the mean of multiple data points or measurements.
averaging objective: In the biomedical context, an "averaging objective" refers to a methodological approach used to aggregate and analyze data by calculating the mean value of a set of observations or measurements to reduce variability and improve the reliability of results.
axillary temperature measurement datum: Axillary temperature measurement datum refers to the recorded data point obtained by measuring body temperature at the armpit (axilla), typically used as an indicator of core body temperature.
b cell epitope prediction: B cell epitope prediction refers to the computational process of identifying specific regions on an antigen that are recognized and bound by B cell receptors or antibodies, aiding in vaccine and therapeutic development.
b transformation: B transformation refers to the process by which B cells, a type of white blood cell, undergo activation and differentiation in response to an antigen, leading to their proliferation and maturation into antibody-producing plasma cells or memory B cells.
background corrected data set: A background corrected data set refers to a collection of data from which background noise or interference has been removed to enhance the accuracy and reliability of the measurements.
background corrected data visualization: Background corrected data visualization refers to the graphical representation of data that has been adjusted to remove background noise or interference, enhancing the clarity and accuracy of the observed results.
