cytometric bead array assay measuring ep: A cytometric bead array assay measuring epitope-specific IP-10 production by T cells is a laboratory technique used to quantify the amount of IP-10 cytokine produced by T cells in response to specific antigenic epitopes, utilizing beads coated with antibodies and flow cytometry for detection.

A cytometric bead array assay measuring epitope-specific RANTES production by T cells is a laboratory technique used to quantify the production of the chemokine RANTES by T cells in response to specific antigenic epitopes, using fluorescently labeled beads for detection.

A cytometric bead array assay measuring epitope-specific chemokine (C-X-C motif) ligand 9 production by T cells is a laboratory technique used to quantify the amount of CXCL9 chemokine produced by T cells in response to specific antigenic stimulation, using beads coated with antibodies

A cytometric bead array assay measuring epitope-specific granulocyte colony-stimulating factor production by T cells is a laboratory technique used to quantify the production of granulocyte colony-stimulating factor by T cells in response to specific epitopes, using beads coated with antibodies and flow cytometry for detection

A cytometric bead array assay measuring epitope-specific granulysin release by T cells is a laboratory technique used to quantify the release of granulysin, a cytotoxic molecule, from T cells in response to specific antigenic epitopes, using bead-based flow cytometry.

A cytometric bead array assay measuring epitope-specific granzyme A release by T cells is a laboratory technique used to quantify the amount of granzyme A, a protein released by T cells in response to specific antigens, using beads tagged with antibodies and flow cytometry.

A cytometric bead array assay measuring epitope-specific granzyme B release by T cells is a laboratory technique used to quantify the amount of granzyme B, a protein involved in inducing cell death, released by T cells in response to specific antigenic epitopes, using bead-based flow cytometry.

A cytometric bead array assay measuring epitope-specific interferon-gamma production by T cells is a laboratory technique used to quantify the amount of interferon-gamma produced by T cells in response to specific antigens, utilizing beads coated with antibodies to capture and detect the cytokine.

A cytometric bead array assay measuring epitope-specific interleukin-10 production by T cells is a laboratory technique used to quantify the amount of interleukin-10, an anti-inflammatory cytokine, produced by T cells in response to specific antigenic epitopes, using beads coated with capture

A cytometric bead array assay measuring epitope-specific interleukin-12 production by T cells is a laboratory technique used to quantify the amount of interleukin-12 produced by T cells in response to specific antigenic epitopes, utilizing beads coated with antibodies to capture and detect the cytokine

A cytometric bead array assay measuring epitope-specific interleukin-27 production by T cells is a laboratory technique used to quantify the amount of interleukin-27 produced by T cells in response to specific antigens, utilizing beads coated with antibodies to capture and detect the cytokine.

A cytometric bead array assay measuring epitope-specific interleukin-3 production by T cells is a laboratory technique used to quantify the amount of interleukin-3 produced by T cells in response to specific antigenic epitopes, utilizing beads coated with antibodies to capture and detect the cytokine

A cytometric bead array assay measuring epitope-specific interleukin-4 production by T cells is a laboratory technique used to quantify the amount of interleukin-4 produced by T cells in response to specific antigens, utilizing beads coated with antibodies to capture and detect the cytokine.

A cytometric bead array assay measuring epitope-specific interleukin-5 production by T cells is a laboratory technique used to quantify the amount of interleukin-5 produced by T cells in response to a specific antigen, using beads coated with antibodies and flow cytometry for detection.

A cytometric bead array assay measuring epitope-specific interleukin-6 production by T cells is a laboratory technique used to quantify the amount of interleukin-6 produced by T cells in response to specific epitopes, utilizing fluorescent beads for detection and analysis.

A cytometric bead array assay measuring epitope-specific interleukin-7 production by T cells is a laboratory technique used to quantify the amount of interleukin-7 produced by T cells in response to specific antigenic epitopes, using bead-based flow cytometry.

A cytometric bead array assay measuring epitope-specific intracellular cytokine staining (ICS) IL-21 production by T cells is a laboratory technique used to quantify the production of the cytokine IL-21 by T cells in response to specific antigens, using beads and flow cytometry for precise measurement

A cytometric bead array assay measuring epitope-specific intracellular cytokine staining (ICS) IL-22 production by T cells is a laboratory technique used to quantify the production of the cytokine IL-22 by T cells in response to specific antigens, using beads and flow cytometry for precise measurement

A cytometric bead array assay measuring epitope-specific intracellular cytokine staining (ICS) IL-23 production by T cells is a laboratory technique used to quantify the production of the cytokine IL-23 by T cells in response to specific epitopes, using bead-based flow cytometry.

A cytometric bead array assay measuring epitope-specific lymphotoxin A production by T cells is a laboratory technique used to quantify the amount of lymphotoxin A produced by T cells in response to a specific antigen, using beads coated with antibodies and flow cytometry for detection.

A cytometric bead array assay measuring epitope-specific macrophage inflammatory protein-1 alpha production by T cells is a laboratory technique used to quantify the production of a specific inflammatory protein by T cells in response to a particular epitope, using beads coated with antibodies and flow cytometry for detection.

A cytometric bead array assay measuring epitope-specific oncostatin M production by T cells is a laboratory technique used to quantify the amount of oncostatin M, a cytokine, produced by T cells in response to specific epitopes, utilizing bead-based flow cytometry for detection.

A cytometric bead array assay measuring epitope-specific perforin release by T cells is a laboratory technique used to quantify the amount of perforin, a protein involved in cell-mediated cytotoxicity, released by T cells in response to specific antigenic epitopes, using fluorescently labeled beads for detection

A cytometric bead array assay measuring epitope-specific transforming growth factor-beta production by T cells is a laboratory technique used to quantify the amount of TGF-beta produced by T cells in response to specific antigens, using beads coated with antibodies that capture and detect the cytokine.

A cytometric bead array assay measuring epitope-specific tumor necrosis factor alpha production by T cells is a laboratory technique used to quantify the amount of TNF-alpha produced by T cells in response to specific antigens, using beads coated with antibodies to capture and detect the cytokine.

A cytometric bead array assay measuring epitope-specific tumor necrosis factor superfamily cytokine production by T cells is a laboratory technique used to quantify specific cytokines produced by T cells in response to particular epitopes, utilizing bead-based flow cytometry for high-throughput analysis.

A cytometric bead array assay measuring epitope-specific vascular endothelial growth factor production by T cells is a laboratory technique used to quantify the amount of VEGF produced by T cells in response to specific epitopes, utilizing beads coated with antibodies to capture and detect the target protein.
cytometric bead array measuring epitope: A cytometric bead array measuring epitope-specific granulocyte macrophage colony-stimulating factor production by T cells is a laboratory technique used to quantify the amount of GM-CSF produced by T cells in response to specific antigens, using beads coated with antibodies to capture and detect the cytokine.
cytometry analysis by automated gating: Cytometry analysis by automated gating is a technique used to analyze cell populations by automatically classifying and quantifying cells based on their characteristics, such as size and fluorescence, using computational algorithms.
cytometry analysis by manual gating: Cytometry analysis by manual gating is a technique used to analyze cell populations in flow cytometry data by manually setting boundaries, or "gates," on scatter plots to identify and quantify specific cell subsets based on their fluorescence and light scattering properties.
cytometry assay: A cytometry assay is a laboratory technique used to measure and analyze the physical and chemical characteristics of cells or particles, often utilizing flow cytometry or image-based cytometry methods.
cytometry time of flight assay: A cytometry time of flight assay is a technique used to analyze the physical and chemical properties of cells or particles by measuring the time it takes for them to pass through a detector, often utilizing mass spectrometry for high-dimensional data analysis.
cytoplasmic RNA extract: Cytoplasmic RNA extract refers to the collection of RNA molecules isolated from the cytoplasm of a cell, excluding nuclear RNA, used for various molecular biology analyses.
cytoplasmic RNA extraction: Cytoplasmic RNA extraction is the process of isolating RNA molecules from the cytoplasm of a cell, separating them from nuclear RNA and other cellular components.
cytosolic creatine kinase complex, MB-ty: The cytosolic creatine kinase complex, MB-type, is an enzyme complex found in the cytosol of cells, particularly in cardiac muscle, that catalyzes the reversible conversion of creatine and ATP to phosphocreatine and ADP, playing a crucial role in energy storage and transfer
The cytosolic creatine kinase complex, MB-type assay is a diagnostic test used to measure the levels of the MB isoenzyme of creatine kinase in the cytosol, often to assess heart muscle damage.
cytotoxic T cell degranulation: Cytotoxic T cell degranulation is the process by which cytotoxic T cells release cytotoxic granules containing perforin and granzymes to destroy target cells, such as virus-infected or cancerous cells.
damage: Damage is any change in a thing, often a physical object, that degrades it away from its initial state. It can broadly be defined as "changes introduced into a system that adversely affect its current or future performance". Damage "does not necessarily imply total loss of system functionality, but rather that the system is no longer operating in its optimal manner". Damage to physical objects is "the progressive physical process by which they break", and includes mechanical stress that weakens a structure, even if this is not visible.
damaged: Damage is any change in a thing, often a physical object, that degrades it away from its initial state. It can broadly be defined as "changes introduced into a system that adversely affect its current or future performance". Damage "does not necessarily imply total loss of system functionality, but rather that the system is no longer operating in its optimal manner". Damage to physical objects is "the progressive physical process by which they break", and includes mechanical stress that weakens a structure, even if this is not visible.
data about an ontology part: "Data about an ontology part" refers to information or metadata concerning a specific component or element within a structured framework that represents knowledge as a set of concepts and the relationships between them in a particular domain.
data combination: In the biomedical context, "data combination" refers to the process of integrating multiple datasets or sources of information to enhance analysis, improve accuracy, and derive more comprehensive insights into biological or medical phenomena.
data encoding: In communications and information processing, code is a system of rules to convert information—such as a letter, word, sound, image, or gesture—into another form, sometimes shortened or secret, for communication through a communication channel or storage in a storage medium. An early example is an invention of language, which enabled a person, through speech, to communicate what they thought, saw, heard, or felt to others. But speech limits the range of communication to the distance a voice can carry and limits the audience to those present when the speech is uttered. The invention of writing, which converted spoken language into visual symbols, extended the range of communication across space and time.
data format specification: A data format specification is a detailed description of the structure, organization, and encoding of data within a particular file format, ensuring consistent interpretation and processing across different systems and applications.
data imputation: Data imputation is the process of replacing missing or incomplete data with substituted values to maintain the integrity and usability of a dataset.
data item: A data item describes an atomic state of a particular object concerning a specific property at a certain time point. A collection of data items for the same object at the same time forms an object instance. Any type of complex information can be broken down to elementary data items. Data items are identified by object (o), property (p) and time (t), while the value (v) is a function of o, p and t: v = F(o,p,t).
data maintenance service: A data maintenance service in the biomedical field refers to the systematic process of managing, updating, and ensuring the accuracy and integrity of biomedical data throughout its lifecycle.
data normalization objective: The "data normalization objective" in biomedical contexts refers to the process of adjusting and scaling data from different sources or experiments to a common standard or scale, ensuring consistency and comparability across datasets.
data partitioning: Data partitioning in the biomedical field refers to the process of dividing a dataset into distinct subsets, such as training, validation, and test sets, to ensure robust model evaluation and development.
data representational model: A data representational model in biomedicine is a structured framework that defines how biomedical data is organized, stored, and interpreted to facilitate analysis and interoperability.
data set: A data set is a collection of data. In the case of tabular data, a data set corresponds to one or more database tables, where every column of a table represents a particular variable, and each row corresponds to a given record of the data set in question. The data set lists values for each of the variables, such as for example height and weight of an object, for each member of the data set. Data sets can also consist of a collection of documents or files.
data set of features: A "data set of features" in a biomedical context refers to a structured collection of data points where each entry is characterized by multiple attributes or variables, often used for analysis, modeling, or machine learning applications.
data set of predicted values according t: A "data set of predicted values according to a fitted curve" refers to a collection of data points that have been estimated based on a mathematical model or curve that best fits a given set of observed data.
data storage service: A data storage service in the biomedical field refers to a digital solution or platform that securely stores, manages, and facilitates access to large volumes of biomedical data, such as patient records, research data, and clinical trial information.
data transformation: In computing, data transformation is the process of converting data from one format or structure into another format or structure. It is a fundamental aspect of most data integration and data management tasks such as data wrangling, data warehousing, data integration and application integration.
data transformation objective: A data transformation objective in biomedicine refers to the specific goal or purpose for altering raw data into a more usable format to facilitate analysis, interpretation, or integration with other datasets.
data vector reduction data transformatio: Data vector reduction data transformation refers to the process of simplifying complex data sets by reducing the number of variables or dimensions, often through techniques like principal component analysis, to facilitate easier analysis and interpretation in biomedical research.
data vector reduction objective: The "data vector reduction objective" in a biomedical context refers to the goal of simplifying complex data sets by reducing the number of variables or dimensions while preserving essential information for analysis.
data visualization: Data and information visualization is the practice of designing and creating graphic or visual representations of quantitative and qualitative data and information with the help of static, dynamic or interactive visual items. These visualizations are intended to help a target audience visually explore and discover, quickly understand, interpret and gain important insights into otherwise difficult-to-identify structures, relationships, correlations, local and global patterns, trends, variations, constancy, clusters, outliers and unusual groupings within data. When intended for the public to convey a concise version of information in an engaging manner, it is typically called infographics.
date process started: "Date process started" refers to the specific calendar date on which a particular biomedical procedure, experiment, or treatment regimen was initiated.
datum label: A "datum label" in the biomedical context refers to a tag or identifier assigned to a specific data point or set of data points to categorize or describe its characteristics or significance within a dataset.
daughter clinical history of cancer: "Daughter clinical history of cancer" refers to the medical history of cancer in a person's daughter, which may be relevant for assessing genetic risk factors and familial cancer patterns.
daytime arthropod specimen collection by: Daytime arthropod specimen collection by aspiration is a method of gathering arthropods, such as insects or spiders, during daylight hours using a suction device to capture them without harm.
dbGaP study identifier: A dbGaP study identifier is a unique alphanumeric code assigned to a specific study within the Database of Genotypes and Phenotypes (dbGaP), which is used to catalog and access genetic and phenotypic data for research purposes.
dead: Death is the end of life; the irreversible cessation of all biological functions that sustain a living organism. Death eventually and inevitably occurs in all organisms. The remains of a former organism normally begin to decompose shortly after death. Some organisms, such as Turritopsis dohrnii, are biologically immortal; however, they can still die from means other than aging. Death is generally applied to whole organisms; the equivalent for individual components of an organism, such as cells or tissues, is necrosis. Something that is not considered an organism, such as a virus, can be physically destroyed but is not said to die, as a virus is not considered alive in the first place.
decapitated organism: A decapitated organism is a living entity that has had its head removed, often used in scientific research to study neural and physiological responses independent of brain activity.
decapitation: Decapitation is the total separation of the head from the body. Such an injury is invariably fatal to humans and all vertebrate animals, since it deprives the brain of oxygenated blood by way of severing through the jugular vein and common carotid artery, while all other organs are deprived of the involuntary functions that are needed for the body to function. The term beheading refers to the act of deliberately decapitating a person, either as a means of murder or as an execution; it may be performed with an axe, sword, or knife, or by mechanical means such as a guillotine. An executioner who carries out executions by beheading is sometimes called a headsman. Accidental decapitation can be the result of an explosion, a car or industrial accident, improperly administered execution by hanging or other violent injury. The national laws of Saudi Arabia and Yemen permit beheading. Under Sharia, which exclusively applies to Muslims, beheading is also a legal punishment in Zamfara State, Nigeria. In practice, Saudi Arabia is the only country that continues to behead its offenders regularly as a punishment for capital crimes. Cases of decapitation by suicidal hanging, suicide by train decapitation and by guillotine are known.
decision analysis study design: A decision analysis study design is a systematic approach used in biomedical research to evaluate and compare the outcomes of different healthcare interventions by modeling their potential impacts, costs, and benefits to inform decision-making.
decision tree building data transformati: Decision tree building data transformation refers to the process of preparing and modifying data to enhance the accuracy and efficiency of decision tree models in biomedical analysis.
decision tree induction objective: Decision tree induction objective refers to the goal of creating a decision tree model that accurately classifies or predicts outcomes by recursively splitting data into subsets based on feature values to maximize information gain or minimize impurity.
decision-theoretic analysis objective: Decision-theoretic analysis objective refers to the goal of applying decision theory principles to evaluate and guide decision-making processes, often under conditions of uncertainty, by quantifying trade-offs between different choices and their potential outcomes.
decoding amplified targeted transcripts: Decoding amplified targeted transcripts with fluorescence in situ hybridization assay is a molecular technique used to visualize and quantify specific RNA molecules within cells by using fluorescent probes that bind to amplified RNA targets.
deep tendon reflex assessment: Deep tendon reflex assessment is a clinical procedure used to evaluate the integrity of the nervous system by eliciting involuntary muscle contractions in response to a sharp tap on a tendon.
deep tendon reflex assessment of the ank: Deep tendon reflex assessment of the ankle joint is a clinical test used to evaluate the integrity of the nervous system by tapping the Achilles tendon to elicit a reflexive contraction of the calf muscles.
deep tendon reflex assessment of the bra: Deep tendon reflex assessment of the brachioradialis is a clinical test used to evaluate the integrity of the C5-C6 nerve roots and the radial nerve by eliciting a reflexive contraction of the brachioradialis muscle in response to a tap on its tendon.
deep tendon reflex assessment of the kne: Deep tendon reflex assessment of the knee joint is a clinical test used to evaluate the integrity of the nervous system by tapping the patellar tendon to elicit an involuntary contraction of the quadriceps muscle, resulting in a knee jerk response.
deep tendon reflex assessment of the ten: Deep tendon reflex assessment of the tendon of biceps brachii is a clinical test used to evaluate the integrity of the C5-C6 spinal segments and the neuromuscular function by eliciting a reflexive contraction of the biceps muscle in response to a tap on its tendon.
defined population inclusion criterion: A "defined population inclusion criterion" refers to specific characteristics or parameters used to determine which individuals are eligible to participate in a biomedical study or clinical trial.
dehydroepiandrosterone: Dehydroepiandrosterone (DHEA), also known as androstenolone, is an endogenous steroid hormone precursor. It is one of the most abundant circulating steroids in humans. DHEA is produced in the adrenal glands, the gonads, and the brain. It functions as a metabolic intermediate in the biosynthesis of the androgen and estrogen sex steroids both in the gonads and in various other tissues. However, DHEA also has a variety of potential biological effects in its own right, binding to an array of nuclear and cell surface receptors, and acting as a neurosteroid and modulator of neurotrophic factor receptors.
delivery form for hormonal replacement t: A delivery form for hormonal replacement therapy refers to the method or medium through which hormones are administered to the body to alleviate symptoms associated with hormonal deficiencies or imbalances, such as pills, patches, gels, or injections.
demultiplexed sequence data: Demultiplexed sequence data refers to genetic sequencing data that has been separated into individual datasets corresponding to their original sources after being initially combined during multiplex sequencing.
denatured polymer: A denatured polymer is a polymer whose native structure has been altered or disrupted, typically through physical or chemical means, resulting in a loss of its original functional properties.
denaturing: Denaturation may refer to:Denaturation (biochemistry), a structural change in macromolecules caused by extreme conditions Denaturation, transforming fissile materials so that they cannot be used in nuclear weapons Denaturation (food), intentional adulteration of food or drink rendering it unfit for consumption while remaining suitable for other uses
denaturing high-performance liquid chrom: A denaturing high-performance liquid chromatography instrument is a laboratory device used to separate, identify, and analyze nucleic acids or proteins based on their differential denaturation properties under high-performance liquid chromatography conditions.
dendritic cell: A dendritic cell (DC) is an antigen-presenting cell of the mammalian immune system. A DC's main function is to process antigen material and present it on the cell surface to the T cells of the immune system. They act as messengers between the innate and adaptive immune systems.
dendrogram: A dendrogram is a diagram representing a tree graph and a similarity metric, based on numerical taxonomy methods. This diagrammatic representation is frequently used in different contexts:in hierarchical clustering, it illustrates the arrangement of the clusters produced by the corresponding analyses. in computational biology, it shows the clustering of genes or samples, sometimes in the margins of heatmaps. in phylogenetics, it displays the evolutionary relationships among various biological taxa. In this case, the dendrogram is also called a phylogenetic tree.
denotator type: In biomedical informatics, a "denotator type" refers to a category or class of entities that a term or symbol represents within a specific ontology or knowledge representation system.
densitometer: A densitometer is a device that measures the degree of darkness of a photographic or semitransparent material or of a reflecting surface. The densitometer is basically a light source aimed at a photoelectric cell. It determines the density of a sample placed between the light source and the photoelectric cell from differences in the readings. Modern densitometers have the same components, but also have electronic integrated circuitry for better reading.
density plot: A density plot is a graphical representation used to estimate the probability distribution of a continuous variable, showing the data's distribution and concentration over a range of values.
deoxyribonuclease-1: Deoxyribonuclease-1 (DNase I) is an enzyme that cleaves DNA molecules by hydrolyzing phosphodiester bonds, playing a crucial role in DNA degradation and cellular processes such as apoptosis.
deoxyribonucleic acid: Deoxyribonucleic acid is a polymer composed of two polynucleotide chains that coil around each other to form a double helix. The polymer carries genetic instructions for the development, functioning, growth and reproduction of all known organisms and many viruses. DNA and ribonucleic acid (RNA) are nucleic acids. Alongside proteins, lipids and complex carbohydrates (polysaccharides), nucleic acids are one of the four major types of macromolecules that are essential for all known forms of life.
deoxyribonucleotide: A deoxyribonucleotide is a nucleotide that contains deoxyribose. They are the monomeric units of the informational biopolymer, deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA). Each deoxyribonucleotide comprises three parts: a deoxyribose sugar (monosaccharide), a nitrogenous base, and one phosphoryl group. The nitrogenous bases are either purines or pyrimidines, heterocycles whose structures support the specific base-pairing interactions that allow nucleic acids to carry information. The base is always bonded to the 1'-carbon of the deoxyribose, an analog of ribose in which the hydroxyl group of the 2'-carbon is replaced with a hydrogen atom. The third component, the phosphoryl group, attaches to the deoxyribose monomer via the hydroxyl group on the 5'-carbon of the sugar.
dermis: The dermis or corium is a layer of skin between the epidermis and subcutaneous tissues, that primarily consists of dense irregular connective tissue and cushions the body from stress and strain. It is divided into two layers, the superficial area adjacent to the epidermis called the papillary region and a deep thicker area known as the reticular dermis. The dermis is tightly connected to the epidermis through a basement membrane. Structural components of the dermis are collagen, elastic fibers, and extrafibrillar matrix. It also contains mechanoreceptors that provide the sense of touch and thermoreceptors that provide the sense of heat. In addition, hair follicles, sweat glands, sebaceous glands, apocrine glands, lymphatic vessels, nerves and blood vessels are present in the dermis. Those blood vessels provide nourishment and waste removal for both dermal and epidermal cells.
descriptive statistical calculation data: Descriptive statistical calculation data transformation refers to the process of applying mathematical operations to raw data in order to summarize, organize, and simplify it for easier interpretation and analysis.
descriptive statistical calculation obje: A "descriptive statistical calculation objective" refers to the goal of summarizing or describing a set of data through statistical measures such as mean, median, mode, and standard deviation to provide insights into its main characteristics.
detection of pathogenic organisms object: The "detection of pathogenic organisms objective" refers to the goal or process of identifying and confirming the presence of harmful microorganisms, such as bacteria, viruses, or fungi, in a given sample or environment.
detection of specific nucleic acid polym: Detection of specific nucleic acid polymers with complementary probes refers to the process of identifying and binding specific sequences of DNA or RNA using complementary strands of nucleic acids, often labeled with a marker, to facilitate their visualization or quantification.
detection of specific nucleic acids with: This assay involves identifying specific nucleic acid sequences using complementary probes to measure the production of the IP-10 protein by T cells in response to a particular epitope.

This term refers to a laboratory technique used to identify and quantify specific nucleic acids by using complementary probes, in order to measure the production of the chemokine RANTES by T cells in response to a specific epitope.

This assay is a laboratory technique used to identify specific nucleic acids using complementary probes, while simultaneously measuring the production of the chemokine CCL1 by T cells in response to a particular epitope.

This assay is a laboratory technique used to identify and quantify the production of the chemokine CCL17 by T cells, using complementary nucleic acid probes to detect specific genetic sequences associated with this process.

This term refers to a laboratory technique used to identify specific nucleic acid sequences using complementary probes, while simultaneously measuring the production of the chemokine CCL19 by T cells in response to a particular epitope.

This assay is a laboratory technique used to identify and measure the production of the chemokine CCL21 by T cells, utilizing complementary probes to detect specific nucleic acids associated with this process.

This assay is a laboratory technique used to identify and quantify the production of the chemokine CCL22 by T cells, using complementary nucleic acid probes to detect specific genetic sequences associated with this process.
This assay detects specific nucleic acids using complementary probes to measure the production of the chemokine CCL4 by T cells in response to specific epitopes.

This term refers to a laboratory technique used to identify and quantify the production of the chemokine ligand 12 by T cells, using probes that bind specifically to complementary nucleic acid sequences associated with this process.

This term refers to a laboratory assay that identifies specific nucleic acids using complementary probes to measure the production of the chemokine CXCL13 by T cells in response to a particular epitope.
This assay detects specific nucleic acids using complementary probes to measure the production of the chemokine ligand CXCL16 by T cells, which is indicative of an immune response.
This assay is a laboratory technique used to identify specific nucleic acids using complementary probes and measures the production of the chemokine ligand 9, which is epitope-specific, by T cells.

This assay is a laboratory technique used to identify specific nucleic acid sequences using complementary probes, while simultaneously measuring the production of granulocyte colony-stimulating factor (G-CSF) by T cells in response to specific epitopes.

This assay is a technique used to identify and measure the production of granulocyte macrophage colony-stimulating factor (GM-CSF) by T cells, using complementary probes to detect specific nucleic acids associated with the epitope of interest.

This assay is a biomedical technique used to identify specific nucleic acids by using complementary probes, while simultaneously measuring the release of granzyme A, an enzyme, from T cells in response to a particular epitope.

This assay is a laboratory technique used to identify specific nucleic acids using complementary probes and measure the release of granzyme B, an enzyme indicative of T cell activation, in response to a specific epitope.
This assay detects specific nucleic acids using complementary probes to measure the production of interferon-beta by T cells in response to a particular epitope.

This assay is a laboratory technique used to identify specific nucleic acids by using complementary probes and to measure the production of interferon-gamma by T cells in response to specific epitopes.

This assay is a laboratory technique used to identify and quantify specific nucleic acids using complementary probes, while simultaneously measuring the production of interleukin-1 alpha by T cells in response to specific epitopes.

This assay is a laboratory technique used to identify and measure the production of interleukin-1 beta by T cells, using complementary nucleic acid probes to detect specific genetic sequences associated with this cytokine's production.
This assay involves identifying specific nucleic acid sequences using complementary probes to measure the production of interleukin-10 by T cells in response to a particular epitope.

This assay is a laboratory technique used to identify specific nucleic acids by using complementary probes, while simultaneously measuring the production of interleukin-12 by T cells in response to a specific epitope.
This assay is a laboratory technique used to identify and quantify the production of interleukin-13 by T cells through the detection of specific nucleic acid sequences using complementary probes.

This assay is a molecular biology technique used to identify and quantify the production of interleukin-16 by T cells, utilizing complementary nucleic acid probes to detect specific genetic sequences associated with the epitope of interest.

This assay is a laboratory technique used to identify specific nucleic acids by using complementary probes, while simultaneously measuring the production of interleukin-17 by T cells in response to specific epitopes.
This assay involves identifying specific nucleic acids using complementary probes to measure the production of interleukin-17A by T cells in response to a particular epitope.

This assay is a laboratory technique used to identify and measure the production of interleukin-17F by T cells, using complementary nucleic acid probes to detect specific genetic sequences associated with this cytokine.
This assay involves identifying specific nucleic acids using complementary probes to measure the production of interleukin-18 by T cells in response to a particular epitope.
This assay detects specific nucleic acids using complementary probes to measure the production of interleukin-2 by T cells in response to a specific epitope.
This assay involves identifying specific nucleic acids using complementary probes to measure the production of interleukin-21 by T cells in response to a particular epitope.

This assay is a laboratory technique used to identify and measure the production of interleukin-22 by T cells, using complementary nucleic acid probes to detect specific genetic sequences associated with the epitope of interest.

This assay is a laboratory technique used to identify specific nucleic acids through complementary probes, while simultaneously measuring the production of interleukin-23 by T cells in response to a particular epitope.

This assay is a laboratory technique used to identify and quantify the production of interleukin-25 by T cells by detecting specific nucleic acids with complementary probes that target the epitope of interest.

This assay is a laboratory technique used to identify and measure the production of interleukin-27 by T cells, utilizing complementary probes to detect specific nucleic acid sequences associated with this cytokine's expression.

This assay is a laboratory technique used to identify and measure the production of interleukin-3 by T cells, utilizing complementary probes to detect specific nucleic acid sequences associated with the epitope of interest.

This assay is a technique used to identify specific nucleic acids using complementary probes, while simultaneously measuring the production of interleukin-4 by T cells in response to specific epitopes.

This assay is a laboratory technique used to identify and quantify the production of interleukin-5 by T cells by detecting specific nucleic acids with complementary probes that bind to the epitope of interest.
This assay is a method used to detect specific nucleic acids using complementary probes, while simultaneously measuring the production of interleukin-6 by T cells in response to specific epitopes.
This assay is a laboratory technique used to identify specific nucleic acids using complementary probes and measure the production of interleukin-7 by T cells in response to a specific epitope.

This assay is a laboratory technique used to identify specific nucleic acids using complementary probes, while simultaneously measuring the production of interleukin-8 by T cells in response to a particular epitope.

This assay is a laboratory technique used to identify and quantify specific nucleic acids by using complementary probes, while simultaneously measuring the production of interleukin-9 by T cells in response to specific epitopes.
This assay is a laboratory technique used to identify specific nucleic acids using complementary probes and measure the production of lymphotoxin A by T cells in response to a specific epitope.
This assay detects specific nucleic acids using complementary probes to measure the production of macrophage inflammatory protein-1 alpha by T cells in response to specific epitopes.

This assay is a laboratory technique used to identify and measure the production of macrophage inflammatory protein-1 gamma by T cells, utilizing complementary probes to detect specific nucleic acid sequences.
This assay involves identifying specific nucleic acids using complementary probes to measure the production of monocyte chemotactic protein-1 (MCP-1) by T cells in response to a particular epitope.

This assay is a laboratory technique used to detect specific nucleic acids by using complementary probes, while simultaneously measuring the release of perforin, a protein involved in immune responses, in an epitope-specific manner.

This assay is a technique used to identify and quantify specific nucleic acids by using complementary probes, focusing on measuring the production of transforming growth factor-beta (TGF-beta) by T cells in response to specific epitopes.
This assay detects specific nucleic acids using complementary probes to measure the production of tumor necrosis factor alpha by T cells in response to a specific epitope.

This assay is a laboratory technique used to identify and quantify specific nucleic acids through complementary probes, while simultaneously measuring the production of tumor necrosis factor superfamily cytokines by T cells, which are specific to certain epitopes.

This assay is a molecular biology technique used to identify and quantify the production of vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) by T cells, using complementary nucleic acid probes to detect specific genetic sequences associated with VEGF production.

This term refers to a method used to identify and quantify specific nucleic acids through complementary probes, which is employed to measure the production of interleukin-15 by T cells in response to specific epitopes.
detection technique: A detection technique in biomedicine refers to a method or process used to identify the presence, quantity, or characteristics of a biological substance or condition.
detector lamp: A detector lamp is a component used in certain types of scientific and medical equipment to detect and measure light or radiation, often as part of an analytical or diagnostic process.
detector reagent role: A "detector reagent role" refers to the function of a substance used in a biomedical context to identify, measure, or quantify the presence of another substance, often through a chemical or biological reaction.
determination if assay will provide reli: "Determination if assay will provide reliable results" refers to the process of evaluating whether a specific assay or test method consistently produces accurate and dependable results under defined conditions.
deterministic brain region atlas image d: A deterministic brain region atlas image data set is a collection of brain images that maps specific anatomical regions with precise boundaries, typically used for research and analysis in neuroscience.
deuterium atom: A deuterium atom is an isotope of hydrogen that contains one proton and one neutron in its nucleus, giving it a greater atomic mass than the more common hydrogen isotope, which has no neutrons.
device creation objective: A "device creation objective" refers to the specific goal or intended purpose that guides the design and development of a biomedical device, ensuring it meets particular medical needs or functions.
device for collection of resting adult a: A "device for collection of resting adult arthropods" is a tool or apparatus designed to capture and gather adult arthropods, such as insects or spiders, while they are in a stationary or non-active state.
device setting: A "device setting" in the biomedical context refers to the specific configuration or parameters adjusted on a medical device to ensure its proper function and suitability for a particular patient or procedure.
diagnosis: Diagnosis is the identification of the nature and cause of a certain phenomenon. Diagnosis is used in a lot of different disciplines, with variations in the use of logic, analytics, and experience, to determine "cause and effect". In systems engineering and computer science, it is typically used to determine the causes of symptoms, mitigations, and solutions.
diagnosis of HIV: HIV tests are used to detect the presence of the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV), the virus that causes HIV/AIDS, in serum, saliva, or urine. Such tests may detect antibodies, antigens, or RNA.
diagnosis of an organism: "Diagnosis of an organism" refers to the process of identifying a disease or condition in a living organism through evaluation of symptoms, medical history, and diagnostic tests.
diagnosis of cancer: Diagnosis of cancer refers to the process of identifying the presence and type of cancer in a patient, typically through medical evaluations such as imaging, laboratory tests, and biopsies.
diagnosis of hepatitis B: Diagnosis of hepatitis B refers to the process of identifying the presence of hepatitis B virus infection in an individual, typically through blood tests that detect viral antigens, antibodies, or DNA.
diagnosis of hepatitis C: Diagnosis of hepatitis C refers to the process of identifying the presence of the hepatitis C virus (HCV) infection in an individual, typically through blood tests that detect HCV antibodies or the virus's genetic material.
diagnosis of infectious disease: Diagnosis of infectious disease refers to the process of identifying the presence and cause of an infection in the body, typically through clinical evaluation, laboratory tests, and imaging studies.
diagnosis textual entity: A "diagnosis textual entity" refers to a specific piece of text within medical documentation that describes or identifies a medical condition or disease based on clinical evaluation and analysis.
dialysis: Dialysis may refer to:Dialysis (chemistry), a process of separating molecules in solution Electrodialysis, used to transport salt ions from one solution to another through an ion-exchange membrane under the influence of an applied electric potential. Kidney dialysis is the process of removing water, solutes and toxins from the blood of individuals with compromised kidney function, primary types of which are: Hemodialysis Peritoneal dialysis Hemofiltration Liver dialysis, a detoxification treatment for liver failure. Dialysis (fly), a genus of insects in the family Xylophagidae
dichroic filter: An interference filter, dichroic filter, or thin-film filter is an optical filter that reflects some wavelengths (colors) of light and transmits others, with almost no absorption for all wavelengths of interest. An interference filter may be high-pass, low-pass, bandpass, or band-rejection. They are used in scientific applications, as well as in architectural and theatrical lighting.
dichroic mirror: An interference filter, dichroic filter, or thin-film filter is an optical filter that reflects some wavelengths (colors) of light and transmits others, with almost no absorption for all wavelengths of interest. An interference filter may be high-pass, low-pass, bandpass, or band-rejection. They are used in scientific applications, as well as in architectural and theatrical lighting.
diethyl pyrocarbonate: Diethyl pyrocarbonate (DEPC), also called diethyl dicarbonate, is used in the laboratory to inactivate RNase enzymes in water and on laboratory utensils. It does so by the covalent modification of histidine, lysine, cysteine, and tyrosine residues.
differential expression analysis data: Differential expression analysis data refers to the quantitative information obtained from comparing gene expression levels between different biological conditions or groups to identify genes that are upregulated or downregulated.
differential expression analysis data tr: Differential expression analysis data transformation refers to the process of applying mathematical or statistical methods to gene expression data to normalize, scale, or adjust the data, enabling accurate comparison of expression levels across different conditions or groups.
differential expression analysis objecti: Differential expression analysis objective refers to the goal of identifying and quantifying differences in gene expression levels between distinct biological conditions or groups, such as healthy versus diseased states, to understand underlying biological processes.
differential medium assay: A differential medium assay is a laboratory technique used to distinguish between different types of microorganisms based on their growth characteristics and biochemical reactions on a specialized culture medium.
differential pressure gauge: A differential pressure gauge is a device used to measure the difference in pressure between two points in a system, often to monitor and control fluid flow or filter performance.
differential screening hybridization: Differential screening hybridization is a molecular biology technique used to identify and isolate specific nucleic acid sequences by comparing hybridization patterns between different samples.
diffractometer: A diffractometer is a measuring instrument for analyzing the structure of a material from the scattering pattern produced when a beam of radiation or particles interacts with it.
diffusion weighted magnetic resonance im: A diffusion weighted magnetic resonance image data set is a collection of MRI images that measure the diffusion of water molecules in tissue, often used to detect abnormalities such as stroke or tumors.
digestive system fluid or secretion spec: A digestive system fluid or secretion specimen is a sample of liquid or semi-liquid material produced by or present in the digestive tract, collected for the purpose of medical analysis or diagnosis.
digestive system secreted substance: A digestive system secreted substance is a biochemical compound produced and released by organs of the digestive system to aid in the breakdown and absorption of nutrients.
digestive tract: The gastrointestinal tract is the tract or passageway of the digestive system that leads from the mouth to the anus. The tract is the largest of the body's systems, after the cardiovascular system. The GI tract contains all the major organs of the digestive system, in humans and other animals, including the esophagus, stomach, and intestines. Food taken in through the mouth is digested to extract nutrients and absorb energy, and the waste expelled at the anus as feces. Gastrointestinal is an adjective meaning of or pertaining to the stomach and intestines.
digestive tract specimen: A digestive tract specimen is a sample of tissue, fluid, or other material collected from the gastrointestinal tract for the purpose of medical examination or diagnosis.
digital acquisition card: A digital acquisition card is a hardware device used to convert analog signals into digital data for processing and analysis in biomedical applications.
digital camera: A digital camera, also called a digicam, is a camera that captures photographs in digital memory. Most cameras produced today are digital, largely replacing those that capture images on photographic film or film stock. Digital cameras are now widely incorporated into mobile devices like smartphones with the same or more capabilities and features of dedicated cameras. High-end, high-definition dedicated cameras are still commonly used by professionals and those who desire to take higher-quality photographs.
digital curation: Digital curation is the selection, preservation, maintenance, collection, and archiving of digital assets. Digital curation establishes, maintains, and adds value to repositories of digital data for present and future use. This is often accomplished by archivists, librarians, scientists, historians, and scholars. Enterprises are starting to use digital curation to improve the quality of information and data within their operational and strategic processes. Successful digital curation will mitigate digital obsolescence, keeping the information accessible to users indefinitely. Digital curation includes digital asset management, data curation, digital preservation, and electronic records management.
digital microscope: A digital microscope is a variation of a traditional optical microscope that uses optics and a digital camera to output an image to a monitor, sometimes by means of software running on a computer. A digital microscope often has its own in-built LED light source, and differs from an optical microscope in that there is no provision to observe the sample directly through an eyepiece. Since the image is focused on the digital circuit, the entire system is designed for the monitor image. The optics for the human eye are omitted.
digital object identifier: A digital object identifier (DOI) is a persistent identifier or handle used to uniquely identify various objects, standardized by the International Organization for Standardization (ISO). DOIs are an implementation of the Handle System; they also fit within the URI system. They are widely used to identify academic, professional, and government information, such as journal articles, research reports, data sets, and official publications.
digital-to-analog converter: In electronics, a digital-to-analog converter is a system that converts a digital signal into an analog signal. An analog-to-digital converter (ADC) performs the reverse function.
digoxigenin: Digoxigenin (DIG) is a steroid found exclusively in the flowers and leaves of the plants Digitalis purpurea, Digitalis orientalis and Digitalis lanata (foxgloves), where it is attached to sugars, to form the glycosides.
digoxin: Digoxin, sold under the brand name Lanoxin among others, is a medication used to treat various heart conditions. Most frequently it is used for atrial fibrillation, atrial flutter, and heart failure. Digoxin is one of the oldest medications used in the field of cardiology. It works by increasing myocardial contractility, increasing stroke volume and blood pressure, reducing heart rate, and somewhat extending the time frame of the contraction. Digoxin is taken by mouth or by injection into a vein. Digoxin has a half life of approximately 36 hours given at average doses in patients with normal renal function. It is excreted mostly unchanged in the urine.
diluted: Dilution may refer to:Reducing the concentration of a chemical Serial dilution, stepwise Homeopathic dilution Dilution (equation), an equation to calculate the rate a gas dilutes Trademark dilution, weakening of a trademark by unauthorised use Stock dilution, issuing of new company shares Dilution gene, lightening animal coat color Dilution ratio Hemodynamics#Hemodilution, of blood Dilution refrigerator, cryogenic device
dimensionality reduction: Dimensionality reduction, or dimension reduction, is the transformation of data from a high-dimensional space into a low-dimensional space so that the low-dimensional representation retains some meaningful properties of the original data, ideally close to its intrinsic dimension. Working in high-dimensional spaces can be undesirable for many reasons; raw data are often sparse as a consequence of the curse of dimensionality, and analyzing the data is usually computationally intractable. Dimensionality reduction is common in fields that deal with large numbers of observations and/or large numbers of variables, such as signal processing, speech recognition, neuroinformatics, and bioinformatics.
dimethyl sulfate: Dimethyl sulfate (DMS) is a chemical compound with formula (CH3O)2SO2. As the diester of methanol and sulfuric acid, its formula is often written as (CH3)2SO4 or Me2SO4, where CH3 or Me is methyl. Me2SO4 is mainly used as a methylating agent in organic synthesis. Me2SO4 is a colourless oily liquid with a slight onion-like odour. Like all strong alkylating agents, Me2SO4 is toxic. Its use as a laboratory reagent has been superseded to some extent by methyl triflate, CF3SO3CH3, the methyl ester of trifluoromethanesulfonic acid.
diode laser: A laser diode is a semiconductor device similar to a light-emitting diode in which a diode pumped directly with electrical current can create lasing conditions at the diode's junction.
diploid: Ploidy is the number of complete sets of chromosomes in a cell, and hence the number of possible alleles for autosomal and pseudoautosomal genes. Here sets of chromosomes refers to the number of maternal and paternal chromosome copies, respectively, in each homologous chromosome pair—the form in which chromosomes naturally exist. Somatic cells, tissues, and individual organisms can be described according to the number of sets of chromosomes present : monoploid, diploid, triploid, tetraploid, pentaploid, hexaploid, heptaploid or septaploid, etc. The generic term polyploid is often used to describe cells with three or more sets of chromosomes.
dipper for arthropod immatures: A "dipper for arthropod immatures" is a tool used to collect immature stages of arthropods, such as larvae or nymphs, from aquatic environments for study or monitoring purposes.
direct RNA sequencing assay: A direct RNA sequencing assay is a technique used to determine the nucleotide sequence of RNA molecules without the need for reverse transcription into DNA, allowing for the analysis of the transcriptome in its native form.
direct bilirubin concentration assay: A direct bilirubin concentration assay is a laboratory test that measures the level of conjugated bilirubin in the blood to assess liver function and diagnose potential liver disorders.
direct binding assay: A direct binding assay is a laboratory technique used to measure the interaction between a ligand and its target molecule, typically by directly detecting the binding event without the need for a secondary reaction or amplification step.
direct insecticide resistance bioassay: A direct insecticide resistance bioassay is a laboratory test used to evaluate the resistance of insects to specific insecticides by directly exposing them to the chemicals and observing their survival or mortality rates.
direct insecticide resistance diagnostic: A direct insecticide resistance diagnostic assay is a laboratory test designed to detect and measure the resistance of insects to specific insecticides, helping to inform pest control strategies.
direct interaction identification design: "Direct interaction identification design" refers to a methodological approach in biomedical research aimed at detecting and characterizing direct physical interactions between biomolecules, such as proteins or nucleic acids, often using techniques like co-immunoprecipitation or yeast two-hybrid screening.
direct submission to IEDB: "Direct submission to IEDB" refers to the process of submitting immunological data, such as information on epitopes, directly to the Immune Epitope Database (IEDB) for inclusion and public access.
direct venous blood bilirubin assay: A direct venous blood bilirubin assay is a laboratory test that measures the levels of bilirubin in the blood, obtained directly from a vein, to assess liver function and diagnose conditions like jaundice.
directed mutagenesis: Adaptive mutation, also called directed mutation or directed mutagenesis is a controversial evolutionary theory. It posits that mutations, or genetic changes, are much less random and more purposeful than traditional evolution, implying that organisms can respond to environmental stresses by directing mutations to certain genes or areas of the genome. There have been a wide variety of experiments trying to support the idea of adaptive mutation, at least in microorganisms.
directed network graph construction: Directed network graph construction refers to the process of creating a graph where nodes represent entities and directed edges indicate relationships or interactions with a specific direction from one node to another, often used to model biological systems or processes.
directive information entity: A "directive information entity" in biomedicine refers to information that provides guidance or instructions for actions or decisions related to healthcare processes or interventions.
discriminant analysis: Linear discriminant analysis (LDA), normal discriminant analysis (NDA), canonical variates analysis (CVA), or discriminant function analysis is a generalization of Fisher's linear discriminant, a method used in statistics and other fields, to find a linear combination of features that characterizes or separates two or more classes of objects or events. The resulting combination may be used as a linear classifier, or, more commonly, for dimensionality reduction before later classification.
discriminant function analysis: Discriminant function analysis is a statistical technique used to classify a set of observations into predefined groups based on predictor variables, by finding a combination of features that best separates the groups.
disease causation objective: The term "disease causation objective" refers to the goal of identifying and understanding the factors and mechanisms that lead to the onset and development of a disease.
disease course: The term "disease course" refers to the progression and sequence of events that occur from the onset of a disease through its development, duration, and resolution or chronicity.
disease exacerbation in vivo interventio: A "disease exacerbation in vivo intervention experiment" is a study conducted on living organisms to assess the effects of a treatment or intervention on the worsening of a disease.
disease prevalence reduction objective: The "disease prevalence reduction objective" refers to a targeted goal within public health initiatives aimed at decreasing the proportion of individuals in a population who are affected by a specific disease over a defined period.
disease prevention objective: A disease prevention objective is a specific, measurable goal aimed at reducing the incidence or impact of diseases through proactive measures such as vaccination, lifestyle changes, or public health interventions.
disease severity reduction objective: The "disease severity reduction objective" refers to a goal in medical treatment or public health strategies aimed at decreasing the intensity or seriousness of a disease's symptoms and complications in affected individuals.
disease specific study design: A disease-specific study design is a research approach tailored to investigate particular characteristics, outcomes, or interventions related to a specific disease or condition.
disease stage: Disease stage refers to the classification of a disease based on its progression and severity at a particular point in time.
disease state design: Disease state design refers to the strategic planning and structuring of clinical studies or experiments to investigate and understand the characteristics, progression, and treatment of a specific disease or medical condition.
display function: In the biomedical context, a "display function" refers to a feature or capability of a medical device or system that visually presents data or information, such as patient vitals or diagnostic results, to healthcare professionals for analysis and decision-making.
disposable footwear cover: A disposable footwear cover is a protective, single-use covering designed to be worn over shoes to maintain hygiene and prevent contamination in sterile or clean environments.
disposable patient gown: A disposable patient gown is a single-use garment made from lightweight, non-woven materials, designed to be worn by patients in medical settings to maintain hygiene and provide modesty during examinations or procedures.
disposition: A disposition is a quality of character, a habit, a preparation, a state of readiness, or a tendency to act in a specified way.
disposition to be a product of antigen p: "Disposition to be a product of antigen processing and presentation" refers to the inherent tendency or potential of a molecule, typically a peptide, to be generated and displayed on the surface of antigen-presenting cells as part of the immune response process.
disposition to be bound by an MHC protei: "Disposition to be bound by an MHC protein complex" refers to the inherent tendency or likelihood of a molecule, typically a peptide or antigen, to interact with and be presented by a Major Histocompatibility Complex (MHC) protein on the surface of cells, facilitating immune recognition.
disposition to be bound by an adaptive i: "Disposition to be bound by an adaptive immune receptor" refers to the inherent tendency or likelihood of a molecule, such as an antigen, to interact with and be recognized by receptors of the adaptive immune system, such as T-cell receptors or antibodies.
disposition to cause an allergic reactio: "Disposition to cause an allergic reaction" refers to the inherent tendency or susceptibility of an individual to develop an allergic response when exposed to certain allergens.
disposition to infect an organism: "Disposition to infect an organism" refers to the inherent or acquired tendency of a pathogen to invade and establish itself within a host organism, potentially leading to infection.
dissection: Dissection is the dismembering of the body of a deceased animal or plant to study its anatomical structure. Autopsy is used in pathology and forensic medicine to determine the cause of death in humans. Less extensive dissection of plants and smaller animals preserved in a formaldehyde solution is typically carried out or demonstrated in biology and natural science classes in middle school and high school, while extensive dissections of cadavers of adults and children, both fresh and preserved are carried out by medical students in medical schools as a part of the teaching in subjects such as anatomy, pathology and forensic medicine. Consequently, dissection is typically conducted in a morgue or in an anatomy lab.
dissolved material entity: A "dissolved material entity" refers to a substance that is uniformly dispersed at the molecular or ionic level within a solvent, forming a solution.
divisive hierarchical clustering: Divisive hierarchical clustering is a method of clustering that involves starting with a single cluster containing all data points and recursively splitting it into smaller clusters until each data point is in its own cluster or a stopping criterion is met.
document: A document is a written, drawn, presented, or memorialized representation of thought, often the manifestation of non-fictional, as well as fictional, content. The word originates from the Latin Documentum, which denotes a "teaching" or "lesson": the verb doceō denotes "to teach". In the past, the word was usually used to denote written proof useful as evidence of a truth or fact. In the Computer Age, "document" usually denotes a primarily textual computer file, including its structure and format, e.g. fonts, colors, and images. Contemporarily, "document" is not defined by its transmission medium, e.g., paper, given the existence of electronic documents. "Documentation" is distinct because it has more denotations than "document". Documents are also distinguished from "realia", which are three-dimensional objects that would otherwise satisfy the definition of "document" because they memorialize or represent thought; documents are considered more as two-dimensional representations. While documents can have large varieties of customization, all documents can be shared freely and have the right to do so, creativity can be represented by documents, also. History, events, examples, opinions, stories etc. all can be expressed in documents.
document editing: Document editing in the biomedical context refers to the process of reviewing and revising scientific or medical documents to ensure accuracy, clarity, and compliance with relevant guidelines and standards.
documenting: A document is a written, drawn, presented, or memorialized representation of thought, often the manifestation of non-fictional, as well as fictional, content. The word originates from the Latin Documentum, which denotes a "teaching" or "lesson": the verb doceō denotes "to teach". In the past, the word was usually used to denote written proof useful as evidence of a truth or fact. In the Computer Age, "document" usually denotes a primarily textual computer file, including its structure and format, e.g. fonts, colors, and images. Contemporarily, "document" is not defined by its transmission medium, e.g., paper, given the existence of electronic documents. "Documentation" is distinct because it has more denotations than "document". Documents are also distinguished from "realia", which are three-dimensional objects that would otherwise satisfy the definition of "document" because they memorialize or represent thought; documents are considered more as two-dimensional representations. While documents can have large varieties of customization, all documents can be shared freely and have the right to do so, creativity can be represented by documents, also. History, events, examples, opinions, stories etc. all can be expressed in documents.
donor role: The "donor role" refers to the function or position of an individual or entity that provides biological material, such as organs, tissues, or blood, for transplantation or research purposes.
dorsal to: "Dorsal to" refers to a position or location that is toward the back or upper side of an organism or anatomical structure.
dose response curve: The dose–response relationship, or exposure–response relationship, describes the magnitude of the response of an organism, as a function of exposure to a stimulus or stressor after a certain exposure time. Dose–response relationships can be described by dose–response curves. This is explained further in the following sections. A stimulus response function or stimulus response curve is defined more broadly as the response from any type of stimulus, not limited to chemicals.
dose response design: A dose response design is a study framework used to assess the relationship between different doses of a drug or treatment and the magnitude of the response or effect it produces in subjects.
dose specification: Dose specification refers to the precise determination and documentation of the amount of a drug or radiation to be administered to a patient to achieve the desired therapeutic effect while minimizing adverse effects.
dot blot assay: A dot blot assay is a molecular biology technique used to detect and quantify specific proteins, DNA, or RNA in a sample by immobilizing them on a membrane and using labeled probes or antibodies for visualization.
dot plot: Dot plot may refer to:Dot plot (bioinformatics), for comparing two sequences Dot plot (statistics), data points on a simple scale Dot plot graphic for Federal Reserve Open Market Committee polling result
double blind study execution: A double-blind study execution is a research method in which neither the participants nor the researchers know who is receiving the treatment or the placebo, to prevent bias in the results.
double-stranded DNA: Deoxyribonucleic acid is a polymer composed of two polynucleotide chains that coil around each other to form a double helix. The polymer carries genetic instructions for the development, functioning, growth and reproduction of all known organisms and many viruses. DNA and ribonucleic acid (RNA) are nucleic acids. Alongside proteins, lipids and complex carbohydrates (polysaccharides), nucleic acids are one of the four major types of macromolecules that are essential for all known forms of life.
double-stranded RNA-specific adenosine d: The double-stranded RNA-specific adenosine deaminase enzyme family are encoded by the ADAR family genes. ADAR stands for adenosine deaminase acting on RNA. This article focuses on the ADAR proteins; This article details the evolutionary history, structure, function, mechanisms and importance of all proteins within this family.
drag swab: A drag swab is a sterile, absorbent material used to collect environmental samples, often from surfaces in animal housing or food production areas, to test for the presence of pathogens.
drawing a conclusion: "Drawing a conclusion" in a biomedical context refers to the process of interpreting data or evidence to arrive at a reasoned judgment or decision regarding a hypothesis or research question.
drawing a conclusion based on data: Drawing a conclusion based on data involves analyzing and interpreting collected information to make informed judgments or decisions.
droplet sorter: A droplet sorter is a device used in flow cytometry to separate and sort individual cells or particles encapsulated in droplets based on specific characteristics, such as size or fluorescence.
drug role: In biomedicine, the term 'drug role' refers to the specific function or effect that a drug is intended to have within a biological system, such as therapeutic, diagnostic, or preventive purposes.
dry ice bath: A dry ice bath is a cooling technique that involves using a mixture of dry ice and a solvent, typically acetone or alcohol, to achieve and maintain low temperatures for laboratory or medical applications.
dual loop autosampler: A dual loop autosampler is a laboratory device used in analytical chemistry to automatically inject samples into an instrument, featuring two separate sample loops to increase throughput and flexibility in sample handling.
dye laser: A dye laser is a laser that uses an organic dye as the lasing medium, usually as a liquid solution. Compared to gases and most solid state lasing media, a dye can usually be used for a much wider range of wavelengths, often spanning 50 to 100 nanometers or more. The wide bandwidth makes them particularly suitable for tunable lasers and pulsed lasers. The dye rhodamine 6G, for example, can be tuned from 635 nm (orangish-red) to 560 nm (greenish-yellow), and produce pulses as short as 16 femtoseconds. Moreover, the dye can be replaced by another type in order to generate an even broader range of wavelengths with the same laser, from the near-infrared to the near-ultraviolet, although this usually requires replacing other optical components in the laser as well, such as dielectric mirrors or pump lasers.
dye role: In the biomedical context, a "dye role" refers to the function of a substance used to impart color to tissues, cells, or materials, often to facilitate visualization under a microscope or in diagnostic procedures.
dye swap design: A dye swap design is an experimental technique used in microarray experiments to control for dye-specific biases by labeling two samples with different fluorescent dyes and then swapping the dyes in a replicate experiment.
dye swap merge: Dye swap merge is a technique used in microarray experiments to reduce dye bias by swapping the fluorescent dyes between two samples and then combining the data to improve accuracy.
dye swap quality control role: The "dye swap quality control role" refers to a method used in microarray experiments to identify and correct for dye-related biases by swapping the fluorescent dyes between samples and comparing the results to ensure data accuracy and reliability.
dysmetria assessment: Dysmetria assessment is a clinical evaluation used to determine the presence and extent of dysmetria, a condition characterized by the inability to control the range of movement in muscular activity, often tested through tasks requiring precise coordination.
eMedical record: An eMedical record, or electronic medical record (EMR), is a digital version of a patient's paper chart, containing their medical history, diagnoses, medications, treatment plans, immunization dates, allergies, radiology images, and laboratory test results, used by healthcare providers for diagnosis and treatment.
eSource document: An eSource document is an electronic record containing source data that is used in clinical research to capture, store, and manage information directly from its original source.
easting coordinate measurement datum: The 'easting coordinate measurement datum' refers to a reference point or baseline used in mapping and geographic information systems to measure the eastward distance of a location from a defined vertical meridian.
edge betweenness calculation: Edge betweenness calculation is a measure in network analysis that quantifies the number of shortest paths passing through a given edge, indicating its importance in the connectivity of the network.
edge quality calculation: Edge quality calculation in biomedicine refers to the assessment of the clarity and precision of the boundaries or edges in medical images, which is crucial for accurate diagnosis and analysis.
edge weighting: Edge weighting in a biomedical context refers to the assignment of numerical values to the edges of a network or graph, representing the strength, significance, or capacity of the relationships between connected nodes, such as genes, proteins, or other biological entities.
edited document: In the biomedical context, an "edited document" refers to a written work that has been reviewed and revised to improve accuracy, clarity, and coherence, often involving updates to reflect new research findings or to correct errors.
editors ontology module: An "editors ontology module" in the biomedical context refers to a specialized component within an ontology that is designed to facilitate the management, modification, and curation of biomedical data and concepts by editors or curators.
effector T cell function: Effector T cell function refers to the activities performed by differentiated T cells, such as cytotoxicity or cytokine production, to directly eliminate infected or cancerous cells and coordinate the immune response.
efficacy of epitope intervention experim: The "efficacy of epitope intervention experiment" refers to the effectiveness of a scientific study designed to assess how well a targeted epitope-based intervention, such as a vaccine or therapeutic, elicits a desired immune response or clinical outcome.
egg specimen collection process: The egg specimen collection process refers to the medical procedure of retrieving eggs from a female's ovaries, typically for purposes such as in vitro fertilization or research.
eh transformation: EH transformation refers to the process by which epithelial cells undergo changes to acquire mesenchymal cell characteristics, often associated with increased migratory and invasive capabilities, and is a key event in cancer progression and metastasis.
electrical conductivity detector: An electrical conductivity detector is a device used to measure the ability of a substance to conduct an electric current, often employed in analytical chemistry to detect and quantify ions in a solution.
electricity supply function: The "electricity supply function" in a biomedical context refers to the role or mechanism by which electrical power is provided and regulated to medical devices or systems to ensure their proper operation and functionality.
electrocution: Electrocution is death or severe injury caused by electric shock from electric current passing through the body. The word is derived from "electro" and "execution", but it is also used for accidental death.
electrode puller: An electrode puller is a device used in biomedical research to fabricate fine-tipped glass micropipettes or electrodes by heating and pulling glass capillaries to a desired shape and size.
