electroencephalography: Electroencephalography (EEG) is a method to record an electrogram of the spontaneous electrical activity of the brain. The bio signals detected by EEG have been shown to represent the postsynaptic potentials of pyramidal neurons in the neocortex and allocortex. It is typically non-invasive, with the EEG electrodes placed along the scalp using the International 10–20 system, or variations of it. Electrocorticography, involving surgical placement of electrodes, is sometimes called "intracranial EEG". Clinical interpretation of EEG recordings is most often performed by visual inspection of the tracing or quantitative EEG analysis.
electrolytes urine potassium assay: An electrolytes urine potassium assay is a laboratory test that measures the concentration of potassium in a urine sample to assess electrolyte balance and kidney function.
electrolytes urine sodium assay: An electrolytes urine sodium assay is a laboratory test that measures the concentration of sodium in a urine sample to assess kidney function and electrolyte balance in the body.
electron capture detector: An electron capture detector (ECD) is a device for detecting atoms and molecules in a gas through the attachment of electrons via electron capture ionization. The device was invented in 1957 by James Lovelock and is used in gas chromatography to detect trace amounts of chemical compounds in a sample.
electron microscope: An electron microscope is a microscope that uses a beam of electrons as a source of illumination. It uses electron optics that are analogous to the glass lenses of an optical light microscope to control the electron beam, for instance focusing it to produce magnified images or electron diffraction patterns. As the wavelength of an electron can be up to 100,000 times smaller than that of visible light, electron microscopes have a much higher resolution of about 0.1 nm, which compares to about 200 nm for light microscopes. Electron microscope may refer to:Transmission electron microscope (TEM) where swift electrons go through a thin sample Scanning transmission electron microscope (STEM) which is similar to TEM with a scanned electron probe Scanning electron microscope (SEM) which is similar to STEM, but with thick samples Electron microprobe similar to a SEM, but more for chemical analysis Low-energy electron microscope (LEEM), used to image surfaces Photoemission electron microscope (PEEM) which is similar to LEEM using electrons emitted from surfaces by photons
electron microscopy assay determining th: An electron microscopy assay determining the 3D structure of a B cell epitope:antibody complex is a technique that uses electron microscopy to visualize and analyze the three-dimensional arrangement of an antibody bound to a specific region (epitope) on a B cell.

An electron microscopy assay determining the 3D structure of a MHC:ligand complex is a technique that uses electron microscopy to visualize and analyze the three-dimensional arrangement of a major histocompatibility complex (MHC) molecule bound to its ligand at high resolution.

An electron microscopy assay determining the 3D structure of a T cell epitope:MHC:TCR complex is a technique used to visualize and analyze the three-dimensional arrangement of a T cell receptor (TCR) bound to a major histocompatibility complex (MHC) presenting a specific ep
electron microscopy assay measuring bind: An electron microscopy assay measuring the binding of a B cell epitope:antibody complex is a technique that uses electron microscopy to visualize and analyze the interaction between a specific region on an antigen (B cell epitope) and its corresponding antibody.
electron microscopy imaging assay: An electron microscopy imaging assay is a technique that uses electron microscopes to visualize and analyze the ultrastructure of biological specimens at a very high resolution.
electron paramagnetic resonance spectrom: An electron paramagnetic resonance spectrometer is an analytical instrument used to detect and characterize chemical species with unpaired electrons by measuring their magnetic interactions in response to an external magnetic field.
electron-microscopy 3D molecular structu: An electron-microscopy 3D molecular structure determination assay is a technique used to visualize and analyze the three-dimensional structures of molecules at high resolution by employing electron microscopy.
electronic case report form: An electronic case report form (eCRF) is a digital version of a paper case report form used to collect and manage clinical trial data electronically.
electronic case report tabulation: An electronic case report tabulation is a digital format for organizing and presenting clinical trial data in a structured manner, typically used for regulatory submissions and analysis.
electronic repeater pipette: An electronic repeater pipette is a laboratory instrument designed to dispense precise and repetitive volumes of liquid, using electronic controls to enhance accuracy and efficiency in liquid handling tasks.
electrophoresis: Electrophoresis is the motion of charged dispersed particles or dissolved charged molecules relative to a fluid under the influence of a spatially uniform electric field. As a rule, these are zwitterions with a positive or negative net charge.
electrophoresis system: An electrophoresis system is a laboratory apparatus used to separate and analyze macromolecules, such as DNA, RNA, or proteins, based on their size and charge by applying an electric field to a gel matrix.
electrophoretic mobility shift assay: An electrophoretic mobility shift assay (EMSA) or mobility shift electrophoresis, also referred as a gel shift assay, gel mobility shift assay, band shift assay, or gel retardation assay, is a common affinity electrophoresis technique used to study protein–DNA or protein–RNA interactions. This procedure can determine if a protein or mixture of proteins is capable of binding to a given DNA or RNA sequence, and can sometimes indicate if more than one protein molecule is involved in the binding complex. Gel shift assays are often performed in vitro concurrently with DNase footprinting, primer extension, and promoter-probe experiments when studying transcription initiation, DNA gang replication, DNA repair or RNA processing and maturation, as well as pre-mRNA splicing. Although precursors can be found in earlier literature, most current assays are based on methods described by Garner and Revzin and Fried and Crothers.
electrophysiology assay: An electrophysiology assay is a laboratory technique used to measure the electrical activity of biological cells or tissues, often to study the function of ion channels and neural circuits.
electroporation: Electroporation, also known as electropermeabilization, is a microbiological and biotechnological technique in which an electric field is applied to cells to briefly increase the permeability of the cell membrane. The application of a high-voltage electric field induces a temporary destabilization of the lipid bilayer, resulting in the formation of nanoscale pores that permit the entry or exit of macromolecules.
elemental oxygen: Elemental oxygen refers to the diatomic molecule O2, which is a colorless, odorless gas essential for respiration in aerobic organisms and is a key component of Earth's atmosphere.
elemental oxygen assay: An elemental oxygen assay is a laboratory technique used to measure the concentration or presence of oxygen in a sample, often for the purpose of assessing its purity or reactivity.
eligibility criterion: An eligibility criterion is a specific condition or requirement that must be met for an individual to participate in a clinical trial or research study.
eluate: In analytical and organic chemistry, elution is the process of extracting one material from another by washing with a solvent: washing of loaded ion-exchange resins to remove captured ions, or eluting proteins or other biopolymers from an electrophoresis or chromatography column.
elution: In analytical and organic chemistry, elution is the process of extracting one material from another by washing with a solvent: washing of loaded ion-exchange resins to remove captured ions, or eluting proteins or other biopolymers from an electrophoresis or chromatography column.
email address: An email address identifies an email box to which messages are delivered. While early messaging systems used a variety of formats for addressing, today, email addresses follow a set of specific rules originally standardized by the Internet Engineering Task Force (IETF) in the 1980s, and updated by RFC 5322 and 6854. The term email address in this article refers to just the addr-spec in Section 3.4 of RFC 5322. The RFC defines address more broadly as either a mailbox or group. A mailbox value can be either a name-addr, which contains a display-name and addr-spec, or the more common addr-spec alone.
email address of Bioinformatics Resource: The "email address of Bioinformatics Resource Center contact person" refers to the electronic mail address used to communicate with the designated individual responsible for handling inquiries and support at a Bioinformatics Resource Center.
email address of sequencing facility con: The "email address of sequencing facility contact person" refers to the electronic mail address used to communicate with the individual responsible for managing inquiries and coordination at a facility that performs genetic sequencing.
email address of specimen collector: The "email address of specimen collector" refers to the electronic mail contact information of the individual responsible for collecting a biological sample for analysis or testing.
email address of specimen provider princ: The "email address of specimen provider principal investigator" refers to the electronic mail contact information of the lead researcher responsible for overseeing the provision of biological specimens for a study or experiment.
encephalitis virus surveillance trap: An "encephalitis virus surveillance trap" is a device used to capture and monitor mosquitoes or other vectors to detect the presence of viruses that cause encephalitis, aiding in public health surveillance and disease prevention efforts.
endonuclease mediated mutagenesis: Endonuclease mediated mutagenesis is a genetic engineering technique that uses endonucleases, enzymes that cut DNA at specific sites, to introduce targeted mutations into an organism's genome.
endotracheal aspirate assay: An endotracheal aspirate assay is a diagnostic test that analyzes the fluid collected from the lower respiratory tract via an endotracheal tube to detect infections or other conditions affecting the lungs.
endotracheal aspirate assay datum: An endotracheal aspirate assay datum refers to a single piece of data obtained from the analysis of a sample collected from the lower respiratory tract via an endotracheal tube, typically used to diagnose infections or other conditions in the lungs.
endotracheal aspirate specimen: An endotracheal aspirate specimen is a sample of secretions collected from the lower respiratory tract via a tube inserted into the trachea, typically used for diagnosing respiratory infections.
endotracheal tube aspirate microbiology: An endotracheal tube aspirate microbiology assay is a diagnostic test that analyzes the microorganisms present in the secretions collected from an endotracheal tube to identify potential respiratory infections.

Endotracheal tube aspirate microbiology datum refers to the microbiological data obtained from analyzing the secretions collected from an endotracheal tube, used to identify and assess the presence of microorganisms in the respiratory tract.
endotracheal tube specimen: An endotracheal tube specimen is a sample of secretions or fluids collected from the lower respiratory tract through an endotracheal tube, typically used for diagnostic testing in patients who are intubated.
energy supply function: The energy supply function in a biomedical context refers to the physiological processes and mechanisms by which energy is produced, stored, and delivered to cells and tissues to support their metabolic activities and maintain homeostasis.
enhanced cross-linking immunoprecipitati: Enhanced cross-linking immunoprecipitation high-throughput sequencing assay (eCLIP-seq) is a technique used to identify and map RNA-protein interactions across the transcriptome by cross-linking proteins to RNA, immunoprecipitating the complexes, and sequencing the associated RNA.
enhancer activity detection by reporter: Enhancer activity detection by reporter gene assay is a technique used to identify and measure the activity of enhancer sequences in DNA by linking them to a reporter gene, whose expression can be easily monitored and quantified.
enhancer-trap mutagenesis: Enhancer-trap mutagenesis is a genetic technique used to identify and study gene regulatory elements by inserting a reporter gene into the genome, which is activated by nearby enhancers, allowing researchers to observe gene expression patterns.
enrichment culture medium: An enrichment culture medium is a nutrient-rich solution designed to selectively promote the growth of specific microorganisms while inhibiting others, thereby facilitating the isolation and study of particular microbial species from a mixed sample.
entity: An entity is something that exists as itself. It does not need to be of material existence. In particular, abstractions and legal fictions are usually regarded as entities. In general, there is also no presumption that an entity is animate, or present. The verb tense of this form is to 'entitize' - meaning to convert into an entity; to perceive as tangible or alive.
entomological data item: An "entomological data item" refers to a specific piece of information or data point related to the study of insects, often used in research or analysis within the field of entomology.
environment control function: The "environment control function" in a biomedical context refers to the regulation and management of environmental factors to maintain optimal conditions for health, safety, and effective operation of biological systems or medical facilities.
environmental control device: An environmental control device is a form of electronic assistive technology which enables people with significant disabilities to independently access equipment in their environment e.g. home or hospital.
environmental exposure to infectious age: Environmental exposure to an infectious agent refers to the contact or interaction with pathogens present in the surrounding environment, which can potentially lead to infection or disease.
environmental history design: Environmental history design refers to the systematic study and documentation of environmental factors and exposures that may influence an individual's health, often used in clinical and research settings to assess potential impacts on disease development and progression.
environmental material: "Environmental material" refers to any substance or component found in the natural or built environment that can interact with living organisms, potentially impacting health and ecosystems.
environmental material collection proces: The "environmental material collection process" refers to the systematic gathering of samples from environmental sources, such as air, water, soil, or biological organisms, for the purpose of analysis, monitoring, or research in biomedical and ecological studies.
environmental proximity to infectious ag: "Environmental proximity to infectious agent" refers to the closeness or nearness of an individual or population to a source or reservoir of an infectious agent, which may increase the risk of exposure and transmission of the disease.
environmental swab specimen: An environmental swab specimen is a sample collected from surfaces or objects in a particular environment to test for the presence of microorganisms, contaminants, or other substances.
enzymatic DNA replication: Enzymatic DNA replication is the biological process by which enzymes synthesize a new strand of DNA using an existing strand as a template, ensuring genetic information is accurately copied and transmitted during cell division.
enzymatic activity level assay: An enzymatic activity level assay is a laboratory test used to measure the rate at which an enzyme catalyzes a specific biochemical reaction, indicating the enzyme's activity level.
enzymatic amplification: Enzymatic amplification is a biochemical process in which an enzyme catalyzes a reaction that produces multiple copies of a product from a single substrate molecule, thereby amplifying the signal or effect.
enzymatic cleavage: Enzymatic cleavage is the process by which enzymes break down complex molecules into simpler ones by severing specific chemical bonds.
enzymatic ligation: In biochemistry, a ligase is an enzyme that can catalyze the joining (ligation) of two molecules by forming a new chemical bond. This is typically via hydrolysis of a small pendant chemical group on one of the molecules, typically resulting in the formation of new C-O, C-S, or C-N bonds. For example, DNA ligase can join two complementary fragments of nucleic acid by forming phosphodiester bonds, and repair single stranded breaks that arise in double stranded DNA during replication.
enzymatic reaction identification design: Enzymatic reaction identification design refers to the process of developing methods or strategies to accurately identify and characterize specific enzymatic reactions within biological systems.
enzyme: An enzyme is a protein that acts as a biological catalyst by accelerating chemical reactions. The molecules upon which enzymes may act are called substrates, and the enzyme converts the substrates into different molecules known as products. Almost all metabolic processes in the cell need enzyme catalysis in order to occur at rates fast enough to sustain life. Metabolic pathways depend upon enzymes to catalyze individual steps. The study of enzymes is called enzymology and the field of pseudoenzyme analysis recognizes that during evolution, some enzymes have lost the ability to carry out biological catalysis, which is often reflected in their amino acid sequences and unusual 'pseudocatalytic' properties.
enzyme-linked antibody: An enzyme-linked antibody is an antibody that is chemically conjugated to an enzyme, used in immunoassays to detect the presence of specific antigens through a colorimetric or luminescent reaction.
enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay: The enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) is a commonly used analytical biochemistry assay, first described by Eva Engvall and Peter Perlmann in 1971. The assay is a solid-phase type of enzyme immunoassay (EIA) to detect the presence of a ligand in a liquid sample using antibodies directed against the ligand to be measured. ELISA has been used as a diagnostic tool in medicine, plant pathology, and biotechnology, as well as a quality control check in various industries.
enzyme-linked immunospot assay: An enzyme-linked immunospot assay (ELISPOT) is a highly sensitive technique used to detect and quantify individual cells secreting specific proteins, such as cytokines or antibodies, by capturing them on a membrane and visualizing them as spots.
eosinophil: Eosinophils, sometimes called eosinophiles or, less commonly, acidophils, are a variety of white blood cells and one of the immune system components responsible for combating multicellular parasites and certain infections in vertebrates. Along with mast cells and basophils, they also control mechanisms associated with allergy and asthma. They are granulocytes that develop during hematopoiesis in the bone marrow before migrating into blood, after which they are terminally differentiated and do not multiply.
eosinophil assay: An eosinophil assay is a laboratory test used to measure the number or activity of eosinophils, a type of white blood cell involved in immune responses and associated with allergic reactions and certain infections.
eosinophil count assay: An eosinophil count assay is a laboratory test that measures the number of eosinophils, a type of white blood cell, in a blood sample to help diagnose and monitor conditions such as allergies, infections, and certain diseases.
eosinophil percentage assay: An eosinophil percentage assay is a laboratory test that measures the proportion of eosinophils, a type of white blood cell, in a blood sample to help diagnose and monitor conditions such as allergies, infections, and certain diseases.
epigenetic modification assay: An epigenetic modification assay is a laboratory technique used to detect and measure changes in gene expression regulation caused by chemical modifications to DNA or histone proteins, without altering the underlying DNA sequence.
epigenetic modification identification o: The "epigenetic modification identification objective" refers to the goal of detecting and characterizing changes in gene expression regulation that do not involve alterations to the underlying DNA sequence, such as DNA methylation or histone modification.
epithelial cell: Epithelium or epithelial tissue is a thin, continuous, protective layer of cells with little extracellular matrix. An example is the epidermis, the outermost layer of the skin. Epithelial (mesothelial) tissues line the outer surfaces of many internal organs, the corresponding inner surfaces of body cavities, and the inner surfaces of blood vessels. Epithelial tissue is one of the four basic types of animal tissue, along with connective tissue, muscle tissue and nervous tissue. These tissues also lack blood or lymph supply. The tissue is supplied by nerves.
epithelium: Epithelium or epithelial tissue is a thin, continuous, protective layer of cells with little extracellular matrix. An example is the epidermis, the outermost layer of the skin. Epithelial (mesothelial) tissues line the outer surfaces of many internal organs, the corresponding inner surfaces of body cavities, and the inner surfaces of blood vessels. Epithelial tissue is one of the four basic types of animal tissue, along with connective tissue, muscle tissue and nervous tissue. These tissues also lack blood or lymph supply. The tissue is supplied by nerves.
epitope: An epitope, also known as antigenic determinant, is the part of an antigen that is recognized by the immune system, specifically by antibodies, B cells, or T cells. The part of an antibody that binds to the epitope is called a paratope. Although epitopes are usually non-self proteins, sequences derived from the host that can be recognized are also epitopes.
epitope binding by adaptive immune recep: Epitope binding by adaptive immune receptor refers to the specific interaction between an epitope, a distinct molecular structure on an antigen, and an adaptive immune receptor, such as an antibody or T-cell receptor, which recognizes and binds to the epitope to initiate an immune response.
epitope disease exacerbation experiment: An "epitope disease exacerbation experiment" refers to a scientific study designed to investigate how specific epitopes, or antigenic determinants, may contribute to the worsening or intensification of a disease.
epitope protection experiment: An epitope protection experiment is a technique used to identify protein-protein interactions by detecting epitopes on a protein that are shielded from antibody binding due to the presence of a binding partner.
epitope protection experiment based on s: An epitope protection experiment based on survival is a technique used to identify and characterize protective epitopes on antigens by assessing the survival of organisms or cells exposed to specific antibodies or immune responses.
epitope protection from infectious chall: An epitope protection from infectious challenge experiment is a study designed to assess whether a specific epitope, when targeted by an immune response, can confer protection against an infectious agent.

An "epitope protection from infectious challenge experiment based on pathogen burden" is a study designed to assess the effectiveness of specific immune responses, targeting particular epitopes, in reducing the load of a pathogen in a host organism following exposure to an infectious agent.

An "epitope protection from infectious challenge experiment based on survival" is a study designed to assess the effectiveness of a specific epitope in eliciting an immune response that enhances survival against a subsequent infectious challenge.
epitope protection from tumor challenge: An "epitope protection from tumor challenge experiment" is a study designed to assess the ability of specific immune responses, typically involving antibodies or T cells targeting particular epitopes, to protect against tumor growth or progression in a model organism.

An "epitope protection from tumor challenge experiment based on burden" is a study designed to assess the efficacy of an immune response, typically involving antibodies or T-cells, in recognizing and protecting against tumor cells by measuring the reduction in tumor burden or size.

An "epitope protection from tumor challenge experiment based on survival" is a study designed to assess the efficacy of specific epitopes in eliciting an immune response that enhances survival rates in subjects challenged with tumor cells.
epitope specific GM-CSF release by T cel: Epitope specific GM-CSF release by T cells refers to the process by which T cells produce and secrete the cytokine granulocyte-macrophage colony-stimulating factor (GM-CSF) in response to recognizing a specific epitope, or antigenic determinant, on a pathogen
epitope specific IFN-g release by T cell: Epitope specific IFN-g release by T cells refers to the process by which T cells produce and release interferon-gamma (IFN-g) in response to recognizing a specific epitope, or antigenic determinant, on a pathogen or infected cell.
epitope specific IL-10 release by T cell: "Epitope specific IL-10 release by T cells" refers to the process by which T cells produce and release the anti-inflammatory cytokine interleukin-10 (IL-10) in response to recognizing a specific epitope, or antigenic determinant, on a pathogen or other foreign
epitope specific IL-12 release by T cell: Epitope specific IL-12 release by T cells refers to the targeted secretion of the cytokine interleukin-12 by T cells in response to a specific antigenic epitope, playing a crucial role in modulating immune responses.
epitope specific IL-13 release by T cell: "Epitope specific IL-13 release by T cells" refers to the process by which T cells produce and release the cytokine IL-13 in response to recognizing a specific epitope, or antigenic determinant, on a pathogen or other foreign substance.
epitope specific IL-17 release by T cell: Epitope specific IL-17 release by T cells refers to the process by which T cells produce and secrete the cytokine IL-17 in response to recognizing a specific epitope, or antigenic determinant, on a pathogen or other target.
epitope specific IL-18 release by T cell: Epitope specific IL-18 release by T cells refers to the process by which T cells secrete the cytokine interleukin-18 in response to recognizing a specific antigenic epitope.
epitope specific IL-1b release by T cell: Epitope specific IL-1β release by T cells refers to the process by which T cells produce and secrete the pro-inflammatory cytokine interleukin-1 beta (IL-1β) in response to recognizing a specific epitope, or antigenic determinant, on a pathogen or
epitope specific IL-2 release by T cells: Epitope specific IL-2 release by T cells refers to the process by which T cells produce and release the cytokine interleukin-2 (IL-2) in response to recognizing a specific epitope, or antigenic determinant, on a pathogen or other target.
epitope specific IL-4 release by T cells: "Epitope specific IL-4 release by T cells" refers to the process by which T cells produce and secrete the cytokine interleukin-4 (IL-4) in response to recognizing a specific epitope, or antigenic determinant, on a pathogen or other foreign substance
epitope specific IL-5 release by T cells: "Epitope specific IL-5 release by T cells" refers to the process by which T cells produce and release the cytokine interleukin-5 (IL-5) in response to recognizing a specific epitope, or antigenic determinant, on a pathogen or other foreign substance.
epitope specific IL-6 release by T cells: "Epitope specific IL-6 release by T cells" refers to the process by which T cells produce and secrete the cytokine interleukin-6 (IL-6) in response to recognizing a specific epitope, or antigenic determinant, on a pathogen or other target.
epitope specific IP-10 production by T c: Epitope specific IP-10 production by T cells refers to the process by which T cells produce the chemokine IP-10 in response to recognizing a specific epitope, or antigenic determinant, on a pathogen or infected cell.
epitope specific RANTES production by T: Epitope specific RANTES production by T cells refers to the process by which T cells produce the chemokine RANTES (Regulated upon Activation, Normal T cell Expressed and Secreted) in response to recognizing a specific epitope, or antigenic determinant, on a pathogen or other
epitope specific T cell activation: Epitope specific T cell activation refers to the process by which T cells are stimulated to respond to a specific antigenic determinant or epitope, leading to an immune response targeted against that particular antigen.
epitope specific T cell enhancement of B: Epitope specific T cell enhancement of B cell mediated immune response refers to the process by which T cells recognize specific epitopes and subsequently aid in the activation and proliferation of B cells, thereby amplifying the antibody-mediated immune response.
epitope specific T cell proliferation: Epitope specific T cell proliferation refers to the process by which T cells multiply in response to recognizing a specific epitope, or antigenic determinant, on a pathogen or other foreign substance.
epitope specific T cell tolerance induct: Epitope specific T cell tolerance induction refers to the process by which the immune system is trained to recognize and ignore specific antigens, preventing an immune response against them, often to avoid autoimmunity or to promote tolerance to transplanted tissues.
epitope specific TNF release by T cells: "Epitope specific TNF release by T cells" refers to the process by which T cells produce and release tumor necrosis factor (TNF) in response to recognizing a specific epitope, or antigenic determinant, on a pathogen or diseased cell.
epitope specific XCL1 release by T cells: Epitope specific XCL1 release by T cells refers to the process by which T cells secrete the chemokine XCL1 in response to recognizing a specific epitope, or antigenic determinant, on a pathogen or infected cell.
epitope specific chemokine (C-C motif) l: Epitope specific chemokine (C-C motif) ligand 1 production by T cells refers to the process by which T cells produce a specific chemokine, CCL1, in response to recognizing a particular epitope, aiding in immune response regulation and cell signaling.

Epitope specific chemokine (C-C motif) ligand 19 production by T cells refers to the process by which T cells generate and release the chemokine CCL19 in response to recognizing a specific epitope, aiding in immune cell trafficking and immune response coordination.

Epitope specific chemokine (C-C motif) ligand 21 production by T cells refers to the process by which T cells generate and release the chemokine CCL21 in response to a specific antigenic epitope, playing a role in immune cell trafficking and lymphoid tissue organization

Epitope specific chemokine (C-C motif) ligand 22 production by T cells refers to the process by which T cells produce the chemokine CCL22 in response to recognizing a specific epitope, facilitating immune cell recruitment and communication.

Epitope specific chemokine (C-C motif) ligand 4 production by T cells refers to the process by which T cells produce the chemokine CCL4 in response to recognizing a specific epitope, aiding in the recruitment of other immune cells to the site of an immune response
epitope specific chemokine (C-X-C motif): Epitope specific chemokine (C-X-C motif) ligand 12 production by T cells refers to the process by which T cells produce the chemokine CXCL12 in response to a specific epitope, playing a role in immune cell signaling and trafficking.

Epitope specific chemokine (C-X-C motif) ligand 13 production by T cells refers to the process by which T cells produce the chemokine CXCL13 in response to recognizing a specific antigenic epitope, playing a role in immune cell recruitment and organization within lymphoid

Epitope specific chemokine (C-X-C motif) ligand 16 production by T cells refers to the process by which T cells generate and release the chemokine CXCL16 in response to recognizing a specific epitope, which is a part of an antigen that the immune system identifies

Epitope specific chemokine (C-X-C motif) ligand 9 production by T cells refers to the process by which T cells produce a specific chemokine, CXCL9, in response to recognizing a particular epitope, aiding in the recruitment of immune cells to sites of inflammation
epitope specific cytokine production by: Epitope specific cytokine production by T cells refers to the process by which T cells produce cytokines in response to recognizing a specific epitope, or antigenic determinant, on a pathogen or infected cell.
epitope specific cytotoxic T cell degran: Epitope specific cytotoxic T cell degranulation refers to the process by which cytotoxic T cells release cytotoxic granules in response to recognizing a specific epitope on a target cell, leading to the destruction of the target cell.
epitope specific granulocyte colony stim: Epitope specific granulocyte colony stimulating factor production by T cells refers to the process by which T cells produce granulocyte colony-stimulating factor (G-CSF) in response to a specific epitope, aiding in the regulation and stimulation of granulocyte production in the immune response.
epitope specific granulysin production b: Epitope specific granulysin production by T cells refers to the process by which T cells produce granulysin, a cytolytic protein, in response to recognizing a specific epitope on an antigen.
epitope specific granzyme A production b: Epitope specific granzyme A production by T cells refers to the process by which T cells produce granzyme A, a serine protease, in response to recognizing a specific epitope on a target cell, contributing to the targeted cell's destruction.
epitope specific granzyme B production b: Epitope specific granzyme B production by T cells refers to the process by which T cells produce granzyme B, a serine protease, in response to recognizing a specific epitope on a target cell, facilitating targeted cell death.
epitope specific helper T cell enhanceme: Epitope specific helper T cell enhancement of T cell mediated immune response refers to the process by which helper T cells recognize specific epitopes on antigens and subsequently enhance the activation and proliferation of other T cells, thereby strengthening the immune response against the antigen.
epitope specific immune intervention: Epitope specific immune intervention refers to a therapeutic approach that targets specific epitopes, or distinct parts of an antigen, to modulate the immune response for treating diseases.
epitope specific interferon-beta product: Epitope specific interferon-beta production by T cells refers to the process by which T cells produce the cytokine interferon-beta in response to recognizing a specific epitope, or antigenic determinant, on a pathogen or diseased cell.
epitope specific interleukin-1 alpha pro: Epitope specific interleukin-1 alpha production by T cells refers to the process by which T cells produce the cytokine interleukin-1 alpha in response to recognizing a specific epitope, or antigenic determinant, on a pathogen or other foreign substance.
epitope specific interleukin-15 producti: Epitope specific interleukin-15 production by T cells refers to the process by which T cells produce the cytokine interleukin-15 in response to recognizing a specific epitope, or antigenic determinant, on a pathogen or other foreign substance.
epitope specific interleukin-16 producti: Epitope specific interleukin-16 production by T cells refers to the process by which T cells produce the cytokine interleukin-16 in response to a specific antigenic epitope, playing a role in immune signaling and regulation.
epitope specific interleukin-17A product: Epitope specific interleukin-17A production by T cells refers to the process by which T cells produce the cytokine interleukin-17A in response to recognizing a specific epitope, or antigenic determinant, on a pathogen or other target.
epitope specific interleukin-17F product: Epitope specific interleukin-17F production by T cells refers to the process by which T cells produce the cytokine interleukin-17F in response to recognizing a specific epitope, or antigenic determinant, on a pathogen or other foreign substance.
epitope specific interleukin-21 producti: Epitope specific interleukin-21 production by T cells refers to the process by which T cells produce the cytokine interleukin-21 in response to recognizing a specific epitope, or antigenic determinant, on a pathogen or other target.
epitope specific interleukin-22 producti: Epitope specific interleukin-22 production by T cells refers to the process by which T cells produce the cytokine interleukin-22 in response to recognizing a specific epitope, or antigenic determinant, on a pathogen or other foreign substance.
epitope specific interleukin-23 producti: Epitope specific interleukin-23 production by T cells refers to the process by which T cells produce the cytokine interleukin-23 in response to recognizing a specific epitope, or antigenic determinant, on a pathogen or other foreign substance.
epitope specific interleukin-27 producti: Epitope specific interleukin-27 production by T cells refers to the process by which T cells produce the cytokine interleukin-27 in response to a specific antigenic epitope, playing a role in modulating immune responses.
epitope specific interleukin-3 productio: Epitope specific interleukin-3 production by T cells refers to the process by which T cells produce the cytokine interleukin-3 in response to recognizing a specific epitope, or antigenic determinant, on a pathogen or other foreign substance.
epitope specific interleukin-7 productio: Epitope specific interleukin-7 production by T cells refers to the process by which T cells produce the cytokine interleukin-7 in response to recognizing a specific epitope, or antigenic determinant, on a pathogen or other foreign substance.
epitope specific interleukin-8 productio: Epitope specific interleukin-8 production by T cells refers to the process by which T cells produce the cytokine interleukin-8 in response to a specific epitope, which is a distinct part of an antigen that is recognized by the immune system.
epitope specific interleukin-9 productio: Epitope specific interleukin-9 production by T cells refers to the process by which T cells produce the cytokine interleukin-9 in response to recognizing a specific epitope, or antigenic determinant, on a pathogen or other foreign substance.
epitope specific killing by T cells: Epitope specific killing by T cells refers to the targeted destruction of infected or cancerous cells by T cells that recognize and bind to specific antigenic peptides, or epitopes, presented on the surface of these cells.
epitope specific lymphotoxin A productio: 'Epitope specific lymphotoxin A production by T cells' refers to the process by which T cells produce lymphotoxin A in response to recognizing a specific epitope, or antigenic determinant, on a pathogen or infected cell.
epitope specific macrophage inflammatory: Epitope specific macrophage inflammatory protein-1 alpha production by T cells refers to the process by which T cells produce a specific chemokine, MIP-1α, in response to recognizing a particular epitope, playing a role in immune response and inflammation.

Epitope specific macrophage inflammatory protein-1 gamma production by T cells refers to the process by which T cells produce a specific chemokine, macrophage inflammatory protein-1 gamma, in response to recognizing a particular epitope, or antigenic determinant, on a pathogen or infected cell.
epitope specific monocyte chemotactic pr: Epitope specific monocyte chemotactic protein-1 production by T cells refers to the process by which T cells produce a signaling molecule, monocyte chemotactic protein-1 (MCP-1), in response to recognizing a specific epitope, thereby attracting monocytes to the site
epitope specific perforin production by: Epitope specific perforin production by T cells refers to the process by which T cells produce perforin, a protein that helps destroy target cells, in response to recognizing a specific epitope, or antigenic determinant, on a pathogen or infected cell.
epitope specific tolerance induction by: Epitope specific tolerance induction by T cells refers to the process by which T cells are trained to recognize and tolerate specific antigenic epitopes, preventing an immune response against them and thereby maintaining immune homeostasis.
epitope specific transforming growth fac: Epitope specific transforming growth factor-beta production by T cells refers to the process by which T cells produce the cytokine transforming growth factor-beta (TGF-β) in response to recognizing a specific epitope, which is a distinct part of an antigen.
epitope specific tumor necrosis factor (: Epitope specific tumor necrosis factor (ligand) superfamily member 11 production by T cells refers to the process by which T cells generate a specific ligand, known as member 11 of the tumor necrosis factor superfamily, in response to a particular epitope, playing a role
epitope specific tumor necrosis factor s: 'Epitope specific tumor necrosis factor superfamily cytokine production by T cells' refers to the process by which T cells produce cytokines from the tumor necrosis factor superfamily in response to a specific antigenic epitope.
epitope specific type IV hypersensitivit: Epitope specific type IV hypersensitivity by T cells is an immune response where T cells recognize and react to specific epitopes on antigens, leading to delayed-type hypersensitivity characterized by inflammation and tissue damage.
epitope specific vascular endothelial gr: Epitope specific vascular endothelial growth factor production by T cells refers to the process by which T cells produce vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) in response to recognizing a specific epitope, or antigenic determinant, which can influence angiogenesis and immune responses.
epitope tolerance induction experiment: An epitope tolerance induction experiment is a study designed to investigate methods of training the immune system to recognize and tolerate specific epitopes, thereby preventing an immune response against them.
epitope treatment experiment: An epitope treatment experiment is a research procedure designed to study the effects of targeting specific epitopes, which are distinct molecular sites on antigens, with therapeutic agents to understand immune responses or develop treatments.
epitope:MHC:TCR complex: The epitope:MHC:TCR complex is a molecular assembly where an epitope (a specific part of an antigen) is presented by a Major Histocompatibility Complex (MHC) molecule and recognized by a T-cell receptor (TCR), facilitating immune response activation.
equilibrium association constant (KA): The equilibrium association constant (KA) is a measure of the affinity between two molecules, indicating the strength of their binding interaction at equilibrium.
equilibrium dissociation constant (KD): The equilibrium dissociation constant (KD) is a measure of the affinity between a ligand and a protein, representing the concentration at which half of the binding sites are occupied.
equilibrium dissociation constant (KD) a: The equilibrium dissociation constant (KD) approximated by EC50 refers to the concentration of a ligand at which half-maximal binding or effect is observed, often used as an estimate of the ligand's affinity for its target in pharmacology.

The equilibrium dissociation constant (KD) approximated by IC50 is a measure of the potency of a ligand or inhibitor, representing the concentration at which half-maximal inhibition of a target is observed, often used when the binding and functional assays are closely related.
error corrected data set: An "error corrected data set" in biomedical research refers to a collection of data that has been processed to identify and correct errors or inaccuracies, thereby improving its reliability and accuracy for analysis.
error correction data transformation: Error correction data transformation in biomedicine refers to the process of identifying and rectifying errors in biological data to ensure accuracy and reliability in subsequent analyses and interpretations.
error correction objective: The "error correction objective" in a biomedical context refers to a goal or process aimed at identifying and rectifying errors in biological data or systems to improve accuracy and reliability.
erythrocyte: Red blood cells (RBCs), referred to as erythrocytes in academia and medical publishing, also known as red cells, erythroid cells, and rarely haematids, are the most common type of blood cell and the vertebrate's principal means of delivering oxygen to the body tissues—via blood flow through the circulatory system. Erythrocytes take up oxygen in the lungs, or in fish the gills, and release it into tissues while squeezing through the body's capillaries.
erythrocyte assay: An erythrocyte assay is a laboratory test used to evaluate the properties, functions, or characteristics of red blood cells.
erythrocyte count assay: An erythrocyte count assay is a laboratory test that measures the number of red blood cells (erythrocytes) in a given volume of blood to assess overall health and detect conditions such as anemia.
erythrocyte specimen: An erythrocyte specimen is a sample of red blood cells collected for laboratory analysis or diagnostic purposes.
erythropoietin: Erythropoietin, also known as erythropoetin, haematopoietin, or haemopoietin, is a glycoprotein cytokine secreted mainly by the kidneys in response to cellular hypoxia; it stimulates red blood cell production (erythropoiesis) in the bone marrow. Low levels of EPO are constantly secreted in sufficient quantities to compensate for normal red blood cell turnover. Common causes of cellular hypoxia resulting in elevated levels of EPO include any anemia, and hypoxemia due to chronic lung disease.
esophagogastric junction: The stomach is a muscular, hollow organ in the upper gastrointestinal tract of humans and many other animals, including several invertebrates. The Ancient Greek name for the stomach is gaster which is used as gastric in medical terms related to the stomach. The stomach has a dilated structure and functions as a vital organ in the digestive system. The stomach is involved in the gastric phase of digestion, following the cephalic phase in which the sight and smell of food and the act of chewing are stimuli. In the stomach a chemical breakdown of food takes place by means of secreted digestive enzymes and gastric acid. It also plays a role in regulating gut microbiota, influencing digestion and overall health.
esophagogastric junction specimen: An esophagogastric junction specimen refers to a tissue sample taken from the area where the esophagus meets the stomach, often for diagnostic examination.
esophagus mucosa: The esophagus mucosa is the innermost layer of the esophagus, consisting of epithelial cells, connective tissue, and a thin layer of muscle, which serves as a protective barrier and facilitates the passage of food to the stomach.
esophagus mucosa specimen: An "esophagus mucosa specimen" is a sample of the innermost lining tissue of the esophagus, typically collected for diagnostic examination or research purposes.
esophagus muscularis mucosa: The esophagus muscularis mucosa is a thin layer of smooth muscle fibers located in the mucosal layer of the esophagus, responsible for aiding in the movement of the mucosa and facilitating the passage of food.
esophagus muscularis mucosa specimen: An "esophagus muscularis mucosa specimen" refers to a tissue sample taken from the thin layer of smooth muscle located beneath the mucosal layer of the esophagus, often used for diagnostic examination.
establishing cancer cell line: "Establishing a cancer cell line" refers to the process of isolating and cultivating cancer cells from a tumor in a laboratory setting to create a stable, reproducible population of cells that can be used for research and experimentation.
establishing cell culture: Establishing cell culture refers to the process of growing cells under controlled conditions, typically outside of their natural environment, to study their behavior, physiology, and biochemistry in a laboratory setting.
establishing cell line: "Establishing a cell line" refers to the process of developing a population of cells from a primary culture that can proliferate indefinitely under specific conditions for use in research or therapeutic applications.
establishing primary cell culture: Establishing primary cell culture involves isolating cells directly from living tissues and maintaining them in a controlled artificial environment to study their behavior and characteristics.
estimated venous blood glomerular filtra: The "estimated venous blood glomerular filtration assay" is a diagnostic test used to approximate the glomerular filtration rate (GFR) by analyzing venous blood samples, which helps assess kidney function.
estradiol: Estradiol (E2), also called oestrogen, oestradiol, is an estrogen steroid hormone and the major female sex hormone. It is involved in the regulation of female reproductive cycles such as estrous and menstrual cycles. Estradiol is responsible for the development of female secondary sexual characteristics such as the breasts, widening of the hips and a female pattern of fat distribution. It is also important in the development and maintenance of female reproductive tissues such as the mammary glands, uterus and vagina during puberty, adulthood and pregnancy. It also has important effects in many other tissues including bone, fat, skin, liver, and the brain.
estradiol assay: An estradiol assay is a laboratory test used to measure the levels of estradiol, a form of estrogen hormone, in a biological sample such as blood or urine.
estradiol concentration assay: An estradiol concentration assay is a laboratory test used to measure the levels of estradiol, a form of estrogen hormone, in a biological sample such as blood or urine.
ethical standard compliance rule: An "ethical standard compliance rule" refers to a guideline or regulation designed to ensure that actions and decisions within the biomedical field adhere to established ethical principles and standards.
ethnicity inclusion criterion: An "ethnicity inclusion criterion" refers to a specific requirement in a biomedical study or clinical trial that ensures the participation of individuals from diverse ethnic backgrounds to enhance the generalizability and applicability of the research findings.
euclidean distance calculation: Euclidean distance calculation is a mathematical method used to determine the straight-line distance between two points in Euclidean space.
eukaryota in blood datum: "Eukaryota in blood datum" refers to the presence and analysis of eukaryotic cells or organisms, such as fungi or parasites, within a blood sample.
eukaryota in feces datum: "Eukaryota in feces datum" refers to data or information regarding the presence and characteristics of eukaryotic organisms, such as animals, plants, fungi, or protists, found in fecal samples.
eukaryota in induced sputum datum: "Eukaryota in induced sputum datum" refers to the data or information obtained from the presence and analysis of eukaryotic cells in sputum samples that have been collected through induction, typically for diagnostic or research purposes in a biomedical context.
eukaryota in lung datum: "Eukaryota in lung datum" refers to data or information related to the presence, characteristics, or study of eukaryotic organisms, such as fungi or protists, within lung tissue or samples.
eukaryota in nasopharyngeal or oropharyn: "Eukaryota in nasopharyngeal or oropharyngeal swab datum" refers to the presence and identification of eukaryotic cells or organisms, such as fungi or protozoa, in samples collected from the nasopharynx or oropharynx for diagnostic or
eukaryota in placental blood datum: "Eukaryota in placental blood datum" refers to the presence and analysis of eukaryotic cells, which have a nucleus and organelles, in the blood obtained from the placenta, often used for research or diagnostic purposes.
eukaryota in pleural fluid datum: "Eukaryota in pleural fluid datum" refers to the presence and measurement of eukaryotic cells, such as fungi or protozoa, in the pleural fluid, which is the liquid found in the pleural cavity surrounding the lungs.
eukaryota in umbilical cord blood datum: "Eukaryota in umbilical cord blood datum" refers to data or information concerning the presence and characteristics of eukaryotic cells, which have a defined nucleus, found within the blood of the umbilical cord.
eukaryota in urine datum: "Eukaryota in urine datum" refers to the presence and recorded data of eukaryotic cells, such as fungi or parasites, in a urine sample, which may indicate an infection or contamination.
euploid: Ploidy is the number of complete sets of chromosomes in a cell, and hence the number of possible alleles for autosomal and pseudoautosomal genes. Here sets of chromosomes refers to the number of maternal and paternal chromosome copies, respectively, in each homologous chromosome pair—the form in which chromosomes naturally exist. Somatic cells, tissues, and individual organisms can be described according to the number of sets of chromosomes present : monoploid, diploid, triploid, tetraploid, pentaploid, hexaploid, heptaploid or septaploid, etc. The generic term polyploid is often used to describe cells with three or more sets of chromosomes.
evaluant role: In biomedical ontology, an "evaluant role" refers to the function or capacity of an entity to serve as a standard or criterion for assessment or evaluation in a given context.
evaporative light scattering detector: An evaporative light scattering detector (ELSD) is a destructive chromatography detector, used in conjunction with high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC), ultra high-performance liquid chromatography (UHPLC), purification liquid chromatography such as flash or preparative chromatography, countercurrent or centrifugal partition chromatography and supercritical fluid chromatography (SFC). It is commonly used for analysis of compounds that do not absorb UV-VIS radiation significantly, such as sugars, antiviral drugs, antibiotics, fatty acids, lipids, oils, phospholipids, polymers, surfactants, terpenoids and triglycerides.
ex vivo design: Ex vivo design refers to experimental procedures or studies conducted on biological tissues or cells outside their natural living organism, often in a controlled laboratory environment, to investigate biological processes or test medical treatments.
excision: Excision may refer to:In surgery, the partial removal of an organ, tissue, bone or tumor from a body Type II female genital mutilation A term used by the Australian government as part of its definition of the Australian migration zone Excision theorem in algebraic topology, a branch of mathematics Excise, taxes charged on the purchase of goods or services Excision (musician), a Canadian dubstep producer from British Columbia. Excision (film), a 2012 American horror film
excitation function: Excitation function is a term used in nuclear physics to describe a graphical plot of the yield of a radionuclide or reaction channel as a function of the bombarding projectile energy or the calculated excitation energy of the compound nucleus. The yield is the measured intensity of a particular transition.
exclusion criterion: An exclusion criterion is a specific condition or factor that disqualifies a potential participant from being included in a clinical study or trial.
exclusion subset ontology module: An exclusion subset ontology module is a component of an ontology that defines a specific subset of terms or concepts by excluding certain elements, often to tailor the ontology for a particular application or context.
exome sequencing assay: An exome sequencing assay is a genomic technique used to sequence all the protein-coding regions, known as exons, of an organism's genome to identify genetic variations associated with diseases.
expectation maximization: In statistics, an expectation–maximization (EM) algorithm is an iterative method to find (local) maximum likelihood or maximum a posteriori (MAP) estimates of parameters in statistical models, where the model depends on unobserved latent variables. The EM iteration alternates between performing an expectation (E) step, which creates a function for the expectation of the log-likelihood evaluated using the current estimate for the parameters, and a maximization (M) step, which computes parameters maximizing the expected log-likelihood found on the E step. These parameter-estimates are then used to determine the distribution of the latent variables in the next E step. It can be used, for example, to estimate a mixture of gaussians, or to solve the multiple linear regression problem.
experimental disease induction: Experimental disease induction refers to the deliberate initiation or simulation of a disease in a controlled laboratory setting, typically in animal models, to study its mechanisms, progression, and potential treatments.
experimental infection of cell culture: Experimental infection of cell culture refers to the deliberate introduction of a pathogen into cultured cells in a controlled laboratory setting to study the infection process, host-pathogen interactions, and potential treatments.
experimental_feature: In the biomedical context, an "experimental feature" refers to a characteristic or variable that is being investigated or manipulated in a scientific study to observe its effects or outcomes.
experimentally modified cell in vitro: An "experimentally modified cell in vitro" refers to a cell that has been altered or manipulated in a controlled laboratory environment outside of a living organism for research purposes.
exponential base: In mathematics, the exponential function is the unique real function which maps zero to one and has a derivative everywhere equal to its value. The exponential of a variable ⁠⁠ is denoted ⁠⁠ or ⁠⁠, with the two notations used interchangeably. It is called exponential because its argument can be seen as an exponent to which a constant number e ≈ 2.718, the base, is raised. There are several other definitions of the exponential function, which are all equivalent although being of very different nature.
exponential transformation: Exponential transformation in a biomedical context refers to the mathematical process of applying an exponential function to data, often used to linearize relationships or stabilize variance in statistical analyses.
exposure of material to environment: "Exposure of material to environment" refers to the condition or process in which a material comes into contact with external environmental factors, such as air, moisture, temperature, or biological agents, potentially affecting its properties or behavior.
exposure resulting in immune reactivity: "Exposure resulting in immune reactivity" refers to the process by which the immune system is activated or sensitized in response to contact with a foreign substance or antigen.
exposure to arsenic history: "Exposure to arsenic history" refers to the record or documentation of an individual's or population's past contact with arsenic, a toxic element, which may have occurred through various sources such as contaminated water, food, or air, and is relevant for assessing potential health risks.
exposure to asbestos history: "Exposure to asbestos history" refers to a record or account of an individual's past contact with asbestos, a naturally occurring fibrous mineral known to pose health risks such as respiratory diseases and cancer when inhaled.
exposure to blood borne infectious disea: The "exposure to blood borne infectious disease exclusion criterion" refers to a rule or standard used in clinical research or medical settings to exclude individuals from participation if they have been exposed to infectious diseases transmitted through blood, to ensure safety and integrity of the study or treatment.
exposure to chromium history: "Exposure to chromium history" refers to the record or documentation of an individual's or population's past contact with chromium, a chemical element that can have various health implications depending on its form and level of exposure.
exposure to diesel exhaust history: "Exposure to diesel exhaust history" refers to the record or account of an individual's past contact or interaction with diesel engine emissions, which may have implications for their health.
exposure to environmental and workplace: "Exposure to environmental and workplace carcinogens history" refers to a record or account of an individual's past contact with substances in their environment or workplace that are known to potentially cause cancer.
exposure to second hand smoke: Exposure to secondhand smoke refers to the involuntary inhalation of smoke from tobacco products, such as cigarettes, cigars, or pipes, by individuals who are in close proximity to smokers.
exposure to second hand smoke in current: "Exposure to secondhand smoke in the current household" refers to the involuntary inhalation of tobacco smoke by individuals who live in a home where others are actively smoking.
exposure to second hand smoke in househo: "Exposure to secondhand smoke in household during childhood" refers to the inhalation of tobacco smoke by children who live in a home where others smoke, leading to potential health risks despite the children not actively smoking themselves.
exposure to silica history: "Exposure to silica history" refers to the record or documentation of an individual's past contact with silica particles, typically in occupational or environmental settings, which may have implications for health risks such as respiratory diseases.
external import ontology module: An external import ontology module is a component of an ontology that incorporates and integrates terms and relationships from an external ontology to enhance interoperability and data sharing.
extracellular electrophysiology recordin: An extracellular electrophysiology recording assay is a technique used to measure the electrical activity of neurons or other excitable cells from outside the cell membrane, typically using electrodes placed in the extracellular space.
extrachromosomal circular DNA sequencing: An extrachromosomal circular DNA sequencing assay is a laboratory technique used to identify and analyze circular DNA molecules that exist outside of chromosomes in a cell.
extract: An extract (essence) is a substance made by extracting a part of a raw material, often by using a solvent such as ethanol, oil or water. Extracts may be sold as tinctures or absolutes or dried and powdered.
extraction date: The extraction date refers to the specific date on which data or samples are collected or retrieved from a source for analysis or processing in a biomedical context.
extraction duration time: Extraction duration time refers to the period required to remove a substance or component from a biological system or sample during a biomedical procedure.
eye specimen: An eye specimen refers to a sample of tissue, fluid, or cells taken from the eye for the purpose of diagnostic examination or research.
face mask: Face mask may refer to:an item of protective equipment that primarily guards the airways: Respirator, including the N95 and FFP2, which are designed for the prevention of airborne viruses like COVID-19, tuberculosis and flu Surgical mask Cloth face mask Dust mask Diving mask, for use underwater Facemask (orthodontics), used for correcting teeth misalignments Facial mask, used for cosmetic skin treatment Face mask, in sports A mask for the face, typically used in rituals, performance art and as a disguise mostly during the Halloween holiday. Face mask, a West African wooden mask at the Indianapolis Museum of Art, Indiana, US
face shield: A face shield, an item of personal protective equipment, aims to protect the wearer's entire face from hazards such as flying objects and road debris, chemical splashes, or potentially infectious materials.
facial atrophy assessment: Facial atrophy assessment is the evaluation of the loss of volume or tissue in the face, often used to diagnose or monitor conditions that cause facial wasting or degeneration.
facial muscle: The facial muscles are a group of striated skeletal muscles supplied by the facial nerve that, among other things, control facial expression. These muscles are also called mimetic muscles. They are only found in mammals, although they derive from neural crest cells found in all vertebrates. They are the only muscles that attach to the dermis.
facial muscle performance: Facial muscle performance refers to the ability and efficiency of the muscles in the face to execute movements and expressions, often assessed in terms of strength, coordination, and endurance.
factorial design: In statistics, a factorial experiment investigates how multiple factors influence a specific outcome, called the response variable. Each factor is tested at distinct values, or levels, and the experiment includes every possible combination of these levels across all factors. This comprehensive approach lets researchers see not only how each factor individually affects the response, but also how the factors interact and influence each other.
falcivax rapid diagnostic test: The Falcivax rapid diagnostic test is a medical tool used for the quick detection of Plasmodium falciparum, the parasite responsible for the most severe form of malaria, in human blood samples.
false discovery rate correction method: A false discovery rate correction method is a statistical approach used to control the expected proportion of incorrect rejections (false positives) among all significant findings in multiple hypothesis testing.
family clinical history of cancer: Family clinical history of cancer refers to the record of cancer diagnoses and related health conditions among immediate and extended family members, which can help assess an individual's genetic risk for developing cancer.
family history design: Family history design is a research approach used to assess the genetic and environmental contributions to a trait or disorder by examining its prevalence and patterns within families.
family status inclusion criterion: The "family status inclusion criterion" refers to a specific requirement in a biomedical study or clinical trial that determines eligibility based on an individual's family-related characteristics, such as marital status, number of dependents, or caregiving responsibilities.
family wise error rate correction method: A family-wise error rate correction method is a statistical approach used to adjust the significance levels of multiple hypothesis tests to control the probability of making one or more type I errors across all tests.
far-western blot assay: A far-western blot assay is a laboratory technique used to detect protein-protein interactions by probing a protein sample immobilized on a membrane with a labeled protein rather than an antibody.
fasted: simple past and past participle of fast
fasting: Fasting is the act of refraining from eating, and sometimes drinking. However, from a purely physiological context, "fasting" may refer to the metabolic status of a person who has not eaten overnight, or to the metabolic state achieved after complete digestion and absorption of a meal. Metabolic changes in the fasting state begin after absorption of a meal.
fasting venous blood glucose assay: A fasting venous blood glucose assay is a laboratory test that measures the concentration of glucose in the blood after an individual has abstained from eating or drinking (except water) for a specified period, typically 8-12 hours, to assess glucose metabolism and diagnose conditions like diabetes.
father clinical history of cancer: "Father clinical history of cancer" refers to the documented medical history indicating that an individual's father has been diagnosed with or treated for cancer.
fatty acid: In chemistry, in particular in biochemistry, a fatty acid is a carboxylic acid with an aliphatic chain, which is either saturated or unsaturated. Most naturally occurring fatty acids have an unbranched chain of an even number of carbon atoms, from 4 to 28. Fatty acids are a major component of the lipids in some species such as microalgae but in some other organisms are not found in their standalone form, but instead exist as three main classes of esters: triglycerides, phospholipids, and cholesteryl esters. In any of these forms, fatty acids are both important dietary sources of fuel for animals and important structural components for cells.
fatty acid assay: A fatty acid assay is a laboratory technique used to measure the concentration or composition of fatty acids in a biological sample.
feature extraction: Feature engineering is a preprocessing step in supervised machine learning and statistical modeling which transforms raw data into a more effective set of inputs. Each input comprises several attributes, known as features. By providing models with relevant information, feature engineering significantly enhances their predictive accuracy and decision-making capability.
feature extraction objective: Feature extraction objective refers to the goal of identifying and selecting relevant characteristics or attributes from raw biomedical data to facilitate analysis, interpretation, or further processing.
fecal swab specimen: A fecal swab specimen is a sample collected using a swab to obtain a small amount of fecal matter for diagnostic testing or analysis.
feces: Feces are the solid or semi-solid remains of food that was not digested in the small intestine, and has been broken down by bacteria in the large intestine. Feces contain a relatively small amount of metabolic waste products such as bacterially-altered bilirubin and dead epithelial cells from the lining of the gut.
feces assay: A feces assay is a laboratory test that analyzes stool samples to detect and measure the presence of specific substances, microorganisms, or biomarkers for diagnostic or research purposes.
feces assay datum: A feces assay datum is a single data point or measurement obtained from analyzing a fecal sample to assess various biological or chemical parameters.
feces microbiology assay: A feces microbiology assay is a laboratory test that analyzes the microbial composition and activity in a stool sample to assess gut health or diagnose infections.
feces microbiology datum: Feces microbiology datum refers to the data or information obtained from the analysis of microbial content and composition in a fecal sample.
feces specimen: A feces specimen is a sample of human or animal excrement collected for the purpose of medical testing or analysis.
feed role: In the biomedical context, "feed role" typically refers to the function or purpose of a substance or component in providing nutritional support or contributing to the growth and maintenance of an organism.
female: An organism's sex is female if it produces the ovum, the type of gamete that fuses with the male gamete during sexual reproduction.
ferritin assay: A ferritin assay is a laboratory test that measures the concentration of ferritin, a protein that stores iron, in the blood to assess a person's iron status and help diagnose conditions related to iron deficiency or overload.
ferritin complex: The ferritin complex is a protein complex that stores and releases iron in a controlled manner within cells, helping to maintain iron homeostasis in the body.
fiat object: A "fiat object" in biomedical contexts refers to an entity whose boundaries or existence are defined by human decision or convention rather than by inherent physical discontinuities.
fibrinogen assay: A fibrinogen assay is a laboratory test that measures the level of fibrinogen, a blood plasma protein essential for clot formation, to assess bleeding disorders or monitor coagulation status.
fibrinogen complex: The fibrinogen complex is a soluble plasma glycoprotein, produced by the liver, that is converted by thrombin into fibrin during blood clot formation.
fibrinogen concentration assay: A fibrinogen concentration assay is a laboratory test used to measure the level of fibrinogen, a blood plasma protein essential for clot formation, in a patient's blood.
fibroblast: A fibroblast is a type of biological cell typically with a spindle shape that synthesizes the extracellular matrix and collagen, produces the structural framework (stroma) for animal tissues, and plays a critical role in wound healing. Fibroblasts are the most common cells of connective tissue in animals.
file merge: In a biomedical context, "file merge" refers to the process of combining multiple data files or datasets into a single, cohesive file, often to facilitate comprehensive analysis or integration of research data.
filled capsule: A filled capsule is a dosage form in which a solid, liquid, or semi-solid substance is enclosed within a soluble container or shell, typically made of gelatin, for oral administration.
filter function: In biomedical contexts, a "filter function" typically refers to a mathematical or computational process used to selectively remove or reduce certain frequencies or components from a signal or dataset, enhancing the desired information while minimizing noise or irrelevant data.
filter paper: Filter paper is a semi-permeable paper barrier placed perpendicular to a liquid or air flow. It is used to separate fine solid particles from liquids or gases.
filtration: Filtration is a physical separation process that separates solid matter and fluid from a mixture using a filter medium that has a complex structure through which only the fluid can pass. Solid particles that cannot pass through the filter medium are described as oversize and the fluid that passes through is called the filtrate. Oversize particles may form a filter cake on top of the filter and may also block the filter lattice, preventing the fluid phase from crossing the filter, known as blinding. The size of the largest particles that can successfully pass through a filter is called the effective pore size of that filter. The separation of solid and fluid is imperfect; solids will be contaminated with some fluid and filtrate will contain fine particles. Filtration occurs both in nature and in engineered systems; there are biological, geological, and industrial forms. In everyday usage the verb "strain" is more often used; for example, using a colander to drain cooking water from cooked pasta.
fine needle aspiration biopsy: Fine-needle aspiration (FNA) is a diagnostic procedure used to investigate lumps or masses. In this technique, a thin, hollow needle is inserted into the mass for sampling of cells that, after being stained, are examined under a microscope (biopsy). The sampling and biopsy considered together are called fine-needle aspiration biopsy (FNAB) or fine-needle aspiration cytology (FNAC). Fine-needle aspiration biopsies are very safe for minor surgical procedures. Often, a major surgical biopsy can be avoided by performing a needle aspiration biopsy instead, eliminating the need for hospitalization. In 1981, the first fine-needle aspiration biopsy in the United States was done at Maimonides Medical Center. The modern procedure is widely used to diagnose cancer and inflammatory conditions. Fine needle aspiration is generally considered a safe procedure. Complications are infrequent.
finger taps assessment: The finger taps assessment is a neurological test used to evaluate motor function and coordination by measuring the speed and rhythm of finger tapping movements.
finger to finger assessment: The "finger to finger assessment" is a neurological test used to evaluate coordination and proprioception by having a patient alternately touch their nose and the examiner's finger.
fixed tissue slide specimen: A fixed tissue slide specimen is a sample of biological tissue that has been preserved and mounted on a glass slide for microscopic examination.
fixed tissue specimen: A fixed tissue specimen is a biological sample that has been preserved using chemical fixatives to maintain its structure and prevent degradation for microscopic examination or analysis.
flame ionization detector: A flame ionization detector (FID) is an analytical device used in gas chromatography to detect and measure organic compounds by ionizing them in a hydrogen flame and measuring the resulting ions' electrical conductivity.
flame photometric detector: Gas chromatography (GC) is a common type of chromatography used in analytical chemistry for separating and analyzing compounds that can be vaporized without decomposition. Typical uses of GC include testing the purity of a particular substance or separating the different components of a mixture. In preparative chromatography, GC can be used to prepare pure compounds from a mixture.
flash freezing: In physics and chemistry, flash freezing is a process by which an object is rapidly frozen by subjecting an object to cryogenic temperatures, or through direct contact with liquid nitrogen at −196 °C (−320.8 °F).
flash pump system: The term "flash pump system" does not appear to be a recognized or standard term in biomedical literature or practice; it may refer to a specific proprietary technology or concept not widely documented.
flow cell: A part of a flow cytometer in which a stream of cells is aligned to pass one at a time through a light beam
flow cytometer: Flow cytometry (FC) is a technique used to detect and measure the physical and chemical characteristics of a population of cells or particles.
flow cytometer analyzer: A flow cytometer analyzer is a laboratory instrument used to measure and analyze the physical and chemical characteristics of cells or particles as they flow in a fluid stream through a laser beam.
flow cytometer sorter: A flow cytometer sorter is a specialized instrument used to analyze and separate cells or particles in a fluid suspension based on their optical and fluorescent characteristics.
flow cytometry assay: A flow cytometry assay is a laboratory technique used to analyze the physical and chemical characteristics of cells or particles as they flow in a fluid stream through a beam of light, typically using fluorescent markers.
flow cytometry assay measuring binding o: A flow cytometry assay measuring the binding of a B cell epitope:antibody complex is a laboratory technique used to analyze and quantify the interaction between specific antibodies and their corresponding B cell epitopes on the surface of cells, by detecting fluorescence-labeled antibodies bound to these epitopes.
