population quality: Population quality refers to the overall health, genetic diversity, and well-being of a specific group of organisms, often assessed to understand their potential for survival, reproduction, and adaptation in a given environment.
portable fluorometer: A portable fluorometer is a compact, handheld device used to measure the intensity of fluorescent light emitted by a sample, often for the purpose of detecting and quantifying specific biomolecules or compounds in various research and clinical settings.
portioning objective: In biomedical contexts, a "portioning objective" refers to a specific goal or criterion used to determine the appropriate division or allocation of a substance, treatment, or resource to achieve desired outcomes in research or clinical practice.
position sense assessment: Position sense assessment is a clinical evaluation of an individual's ability to perceive the position of their body parts in space, often used to assess proprioceptive function.
positive binding datum: A "positive binding datum" refers to experimental data indicating a successful interaction or binding event between two or more biological molecules, such as a ligand and its receptor.
positive reference substance role: A "positive reference substance role" refers to the function of a substance used as a standard or control in experiments to validate the effectiveness or accuracy of a test or measurement, typically by producing a known positive result.
positive/negative ion switching metaboli: A positive/negative ion switching metabolite profiling assay is a mass spectrometry technique used to analyze and identify metabolites by alternating between positive and negative ion modes to capture a comprehensive profile of the sample's chemical composition.
positron emission tomography imaging ass: A positron emission tomography (PET) imaging assay is a diagnostic technique that uses radioactive tracers to visualize and measure changes in metabolic processes, and other physiological activities within the body.
positron emission tomography scanner: Positron emission tomography (PET) is a functional imaging technique that uses radioactive substances known as radiotracers to visualize and measure changes in metabolic processes, and in other physiological activities including blood flow, regional chemical composition, and absorption.
post mortem specimen: A post mortem specimen is a biological sample collected from a body after death for the purpose of examination or analysis.
post-Gd T1 weighted magnetic resonance i: A post-Gd T1 weighted magnetic resonance image data set refers to a collection of MRI images taken after the administration of a gadolinium-based contrast agent, which enhances the visibility of certain tissues and structures in T1-weighted scans.
post-transcriptional modification design: Post-transcriptional modification design refers to the deliberate alteration and regulation of RNA molecules after transcription, to influence gene expression and protein synthesis.
postal address: An address is a collection of information, presented in a mostly fixed format, used to give the location of a building, apartment, or other structure or a plot of land, generally using political boundaries and street names as references, along with other identifiers such as house or apartment numbers and organization name. Some addresses also contain special codes, such as a postal code, to make identification easier and aid in the routing of mail.
postmenopausal status: Postmenopausal status refers to the phase in a woman's life that occurs after she has experienced 12 consecutive months without a menstrual period, marking the end of her reproductive years.
potassium(1+): Potassium(1+) is the monovalent cation form of potassium, represented as K⁺, which plays a crucial role in various physiological processes, including nerve impulse transmission and muscle contraction.
potassium(1+) assay: A potassium(1+) assay is a laboratory test used to measure the concentration of potassium ions (K⁺) in a biological sample, such as blood or urine, to assess electrolyte balance and overall health.
potassium(1+) concentration assay: A potassium(1+) concentration assay is a laboratory test used to measure the amount of potassium ions (K⁺) present in a biological sample.
power supply: A power supply is an electrical device that supplies electric power to an electrical load. The main purpose of a power supply is to convert electric current from a source to the correct voltage, current, and frequency to power the load. As a result, power supplies are sometimes referred to as electric power converters. Some power supplies are separate standalone pieces of equipment, while others are built into the load appliances that they power. Examples of the latter include power supplies found in desktop computers and consumer electronics devices. Other functions that power supplies may perform include limiting the current drawn by the load to safe levels, shutting off the current in the event of an electrical fault, power conditioning to prevent electronic noise or voltage surges on the input from reaching the load, power-factor correction, and storing energy so it can continue to power the load in the event of a temporary interruption in the source power.
pre-moistened swab stick: A pre-moistened swab stick is a medical tool consisting of a small stick with an absorbent tip that has been pre-saturated with a specific solution, used for collecting samples or cleaning surfaces in a sterile manner.
pre-mortem specimen: A pre-mortem specimen is a biological sample collected from a living organism before death for the purpose of medical analysis or research.
preamplifier: A preamplifier, also known as a preamp, is an electronic amplifier that converts a weak electrical signal into an output signal strong enough to be noise-tolerant and strong enough for further processing, or for sending to a power amplifier and a loudspeaker. Without this, the final signal would be noisy or distorted. They are typically used to amplify signals from analog sensors such as microphones and pickups. Because of this, the preamplifier is often placed close to the sensor to reduce the effects of noise and interference.
precipitate: In an aqueous solution, precipitation is the "sedimentation of a solid material from a liquid solution". The solid formed is called the precipitate. In case of an inorganic chemical reaction leading to precipitation, the chemical reagent causing the solid to form is called the precipitant.
precision nuclear run-on sequencing assa: Precision nuclear run-on sequencing assay is a technique used to measure nascent RNA transcription at a genome-wide scale, providing insights into gene expression regulation by capturing and sequencing newly synthesized RNA.
precursor role: In biomedicine, a "precursor role" refers to the function of a substance or cell that serves as a forerunner or initial stage in the development or synthesis of another, more complex substance or cell.
predicted data item: A "predicted data item" in biomedicine refers to a data point or value that is estimated or forecasted based on a model or algorithm, often using existing data to anticipate future outcomes or trends.
predicted mass value: The "predicted mass value" refers to the calculated mass of a molecule or compound based on its chemical formula and isotopic composition, often used in mass spectrometry to identify or confirm the presence of specific substances.
predicted value: In statistics, simple linear regression (SLR) is a linear regression model with a single explanatory variable. That is, it concerns two-dimensional sample points with one independent variable and one dependent variable and finds a linear function that, as accurately as possible, predicts the dependent variable values as a function of the independent variable. The adjective simple refers to the fact that the outcome variable is related to a single predictor.
pregnancy history: Pregnancy history refers to a detailed record of a woman's previous pregnancies, including outcomes, complications, and any relevant medical information.
premenopausal status: Premenopausal status refers to the phase in a woman's life before the cessation of menstrual periods, during which she experiences regular menstrual cycles.
preparative autosampler: A preparative autosampler is a laboratory device used to automatically load and inject samples into a preparative chromatography system for analysis or purification.
preparative chromatography: In chemical analysis, chromatography is a laboratory technique for the separation of a mixture into its components. The mixture is dissolved in a fluid solvent called the mobile phase, which carries it through a system on which a material called the stationary phase is fixed. Because the different constituents of the mixture tend to have different affinities for the stationary phase and are retained for different lengths of time depending on their interactions with its surface sites, the constituents travel at different apparent velocities in the mobile fluid, causing them to separate. The separation is based on the differential partitioning between the mobile and the stationary phases. Subtle differences in a compound's partition coefficient result in differential retention on the stationary phase and thus affect the separation.
presence of blood from host organism in: The term "presence of blood from host organism in blood meal specimen" refers to the detection of blood originating from a host organism within a sample of a blood meal, typically consumed by a hematophagous organism such as a mosquito or tick.
presence or over-threshold value specifi: "Presence or over-threshold value specification" refers to the identification or quantification of a biological marker or substance that is either detectable or exceeds a predefined threshold level, indicating a significant physiological or pathological condition.
presentation of stimulus: "Presentation of stimulus" refers to the process of delivering or exposing a subject to a specific sensory input or environmental cue for the purpose of eliciting a response or measuring its effects.
pressure unit: A pressure unit is a measurement used to quantify the force exerted per unit area, commonly used in biomedical contexts to describe blood pressure or other physiological pressures.
prevalence of blood meal specimens from: The "prevalence of blood meal specimens from a host organism" refers to the proportion or percentage of blood samples taken from a host organism that contain evidence of feeding by a particular parasite or vector, such as a mosquito or tick.
prevalence of pathogen in specimens: The "prevalence of pathogen in specimens" refers to the proportion or percentage of samples or specimens that test positive for a specific pathogen within a given population or study group at a particular time.
primary cell culture: Primary cell culture is the ex vivo culture of cells freshly obtained from a multicellular organism, as opposed to the culture of immortalized cell lines. In general, primary cell cultures are considered more representative of in vivo tissues than cell lines, and this is recognized legally in some countries such as the UK. However, primary cells require adequate substrate and nutrient conditions to thrive and after a certain number of divisions they acquire a senescent phenotype, leading to irreversible cell cycle arrest. The generation of cell lines stems from these two reasons. Primary cells can become immortalized either spontaneously or by genetic modification, at which point they become cell lines which can be subcultured indefinitely.
primary cultured cell: A primary cultured cell is a cell that is directly isolated from living tissue and grown in vitro for the first time, maintaining many of the physiological properties of its tissue of origin.
primary cultured cell population: A primary cultured cell population refers to a group of cells that are directly isolated from living tissue and grown under controlled conditions in a laboratory for the first time, retaining many of the physiological characteristics of their tissue of origin.
primary structure of DNA macromolecule: The primary structure of a DNA macromolecule refers to the specific linear sequence of nucleotide bases (adenine, thymine, cytosine, and guanine) along a DNA strand.
primary structure of RNA molecule: The primary structure of an RNA molecule refers to its linear sequence of nucleotides, specifically the order of the four bases: adenine (A), cytosine (C), guanine (G), and uracil (U).
primer role: In the context of molecular biology, a "primer role" refers to the function of a short strand of nucleic acid that serves as a starting point for DNA synthesis during replication or PCR amplification.
principal component regression: In statistics, principal component regression (PCR) is a regression analysis technique that is based on principal component analysis (PCA). PCR is a form of reduced rank regression. More specifically, PCR is used for estimating the unknown regression coefficients in a standard linear regression model.
principal components analysis dimensiona: Principal components analysis (PCA) dimensionality reduction is a statistical technique used to reduce the number of variables in a dataset while preserving as much variance as possible by transforming the original variables into a new set of uncorrelated variables called principal components.
principal investigator role: The principal investigator role refers to the lead researcher responsible for the design, conduct, and management of a research project or clinical study, ensuring compliance with regulatory requirements and ethical standards.
probabilistic algorithm: A probabilistic algorithm is a computational method that uses randomization to make decisions or solve problems, often providing solutions that are correct with a certain probability.
probabilistic brain region atlas image d: A probabilistic brain region atlas image dataset is a collection of brain images that maps the likelihood of specific brain regions across a population, aiding in the study of anatomical variability and functional localization.
process boundary: In biomedical contexts, a "process boundary" refers to the demarcation or limit that defines the extent or scope of a biological or physiological process, distinguishing it from other processes or systems.
process profile: A "process profile" in a biomedical context typically refers to a detailed characterization or analysis of the sequence, conditions, and parameters involved in a biological or biochemical process, often used to optimize or understand the process's efficiency and outcomes.
processed material: In the biomedical context, "processed material" refers to any biological or synthetic substance that has been altered or treated through various methods to achieve a specific form or function for research, diagnostic, or therapeutic purposes.
processed specimen: A processed specimen is a biological sample that has undergone specific preparation or treatment steps to make it suitable for analysis or testing in a laboratory setting.
progesterone: Progesterone is an endogenous steroid and progestogen sex hormone involved in the menstrual cycle, pregnancy, and embryogenesis of humans and other species. It belongs to a group of steroid hormones called the progestogens and is the major progestogen in the body. Progesterone has a variety of important functions in the body. It is also a crucial metabolic intermediate in the production of other endogenous steroids, including the sex hormones and the corticosteroids, and plays an important role in brain function as a neurosteroid.
progesterone assay: A progesterone assay is a laboratory test that measures the level of progesterone, a hormone, in a biological sample to assess reproductive health or diagnose hormonal disorders.
progesterone concentration assay: A progesterone concentration assay is a laboratory test used to measure the levels of progesterone hormone in a biological sample, typically blood or serum, to assess reproductive health or diagnose hormonal imbalances.
programmable array microscope: A programmable array microscope is an advanced optical imaging system that uses a spatial light modulator to dynamically control the illumination pattern, enabling high-resolution and high-contrast imaging of biological specimens.
promoter activity detection by reporter: Promoter activity detection by reporter gene assay is a technique used to measure the activity of a specific promoter by linking it to a reporter gene, whose expression can be easily quantified.

Promoter activity detection by reporter gene assay measuring epitope specific interleukin-2 production by T cells refers to a laboratory technique used to assess the activity of a specific DNA promoter by quantifying the production of interleukin-2 by T cells in response to a specific epitope,
promyelocyte: A promyelocyte is a granulocyte precursor, developing from the myeloblast and developing into the myelocyte. Promyelocytes measure 12–20 microns in diameter. The nucleus of a promyelocyte is approximately the same size as a myeloblast but their cytoplasm is much more abundant. They also have less prominent nucleoli than myeloblasts and their chromatin is more coarse and clumped. The cytoplasm is basophilic and contains primary red/purple granules.
promyelocyte assay: A promyelocyte assay is a laboratory test used to evaluate the differentiation and maturation of promyelocytes, which are precursor cells in the granulocytic series of white blood cells, often for research or diagnostic purposes in hematology.
proportion mapped reads: "Proportion mapped reads" refers to the fraction of sequencing reads from a genomic experiment that successfully align to a reference genome or transcriptome.
proportion of expected false positives c: The "proportion of expected false positives correction method" is a statistical technique used to adjust for the anticipated rate of false positive results in multiple hypothesis testing to control the overall error rate.
proportional hazards model estimation: Proportional hazards model estimation is a statistical technique used to assess the effect of variables on the time until an event occurs, assuming that the hazard ratios are constant over time.
prostate gland: The prostate is an accessory gland of the male reproductive system and a muscle-driven mechanical switch between urination and ejaculation. It is found in all male mammals. It differs between species anatomically, chemically, and physiologically. Anatomically, the prostate is found below the bladder, with the urethra passing through it. It is described in gross anatomy as consisting of lobes and in microanatomy by zone. It is surrounded by an elastic, fibromuscular capsule and contains glandular tissue, as well as connective tissue.
prostate gland specimen: A prostate gland specimen is a sample of tissue taken from the prostate gland, typically for the purpose of medical examination or diagnosis.
prostate-specific antigen: Prostate-specific antigen (PSA), also known as gamma-seminoprotein or kallikrein-3 (KLK3), P-30 antigen, is a glycoprotein enzyme encoded in humans by the KLK3 gene. PSA is a member of the kallikrein-related peptidase family and is secreted by the epithelial cells of the prostate gland in men and the paraurethral glands in women.
prostate-specific antigen assay: A prostate-specific antigen assay is a blood test used to measure the level of prostate-specific antigen (PSA) in the blood, which can help in the screening and monitoring of prostate health, including the detection of prostate cancer.
protease cleavage: Protease cleavage is the enzymatic process by which a protease cuts peptide bonds within a protein, leading to the breakdown or activation of the protein.
protection from challenge in vivo interv: "Protection from challenge in vivo intervention experiment" refers to a study conducted on living organisms to assess the effectiveness of a treatment or intervention in preventing or mitigating the effects of a specific challenge, such as a pathogen or disease.
protective apron: A protective apron is a garment made of lead or other radiation-attenuating materials worn by healthcare professionals to shield the body from exposure to harmful radiation during medical procedures.
protective coverall: A protective coverall is a one-piece garment designed to shield the wearer from hazardous substances or environments, often used in medical, laboratory, or industrial settings to ensure safety and hygiene.
protective sleeve: A protective sleeve in a biomedical context is a covering designed to shield medical devices, instruments, or body parts from contamination, damage, or environmental exposure.
protein: Proteins are large biomolecules and macromolecules that comprise one or more long chains of amino acid residues. Proteins perform a vast array of functions within organisms, including catalysing metabolic reactions, DNA replication, responding to stimuli, providing structure to cells and organisms, and transporting molecules from one location to another. Proteins differ from one another primarily in their sequence of amino acids, which is dictated by the nucleotide sequence of their genes, and which usually results in protein folding into a specific 3D structure that determines its activity.
protein and DNA interaction identificati: The "protein and DNA interaction identification objective" refers to the goal of identifying and characterizing the specific interactions between proteins and DNA molecules, which are crucial for understanding biological processes such as gene regulation and expression.
protein and RNA interaction identificati: The "protein and RNA interaction identification objective" refers to the goal of detecting and characterizing the interactions between proteins and RNA molecules, which are crucial for understanding cellular processes and regulatory mechanisms.
protein assay: A protein assay is a laboratory technique used to measure the concentration or amount of protein in a sample.
protein binding site identification desi: Protein binding site identification design refers to the process of determining and designing the specific regions on a protein where ligands, such as drugs or other molecules, can bind, often using computational and experimental methods.
protein column: A protein column is a type of chromatography column used in laboratories to separate and purify proteins from a mixture based on their specific properties such as size, charge, or affinity.
protein domain specific binding: Protein domain specific binding refers to the selective and non-covalent interaction between a protein domain and a specific ligand or molecular structure.
protein expression profiling assay: A protein expression profiling assay is a laboratory technique used to measure and analyze the levels and patterns of proteins expressed in a cell, tissue, or organism under specific conditions.
protein extract: A protein extract is a solution containing proteins that have been isolated and purified from biological tissues or cells for research or industrial purposes.
protein localization assay: A protein localization assay is a laboratory technique used to determine the specific location or distribution of a protein within a cell or tissue.
protein microarray: A protein microarray is a high-throughput method used to track the interactions and activities of proteins, and to determine their function, and determining function on a large scale. Its main advantage lies in the fact that large numbers of proteins can be tracked in parallel. The chip consists of a support surface such as a glass slide, nitrocellulose membrane, bead, or microtitre plate, to which an array of capture proteins is bound. Probe molecules, typically labeled with a fluorescent dye, are added to the array. Any reaction between the probe and the immobilised protein emits a fluorescent signal that is read by a laser scanner. Protein microarrays are rapid, automated, economical, and highly sensitive, consuming small quantities of samples and reagents. The concept and methodology of protein microarrays was first introduced and illustrated in antibody microarrays in 1983 in a scientific publication and a series of patents. The high-throughput technology behind the protein microarray was relatively easy to develop since it is based on the technology developed for DNA microarrays, which have become the most widely used microarrays.
protein separation apparatus: A protein separation apparatus is a device or system used to isolate and purify proteins from a mixture based on their physical or chemical properties, such as size, charge, or affinity.
protein sequencer: A protein sequencer is a laboratory instrument used to determine the amino acid sequence of a protein or peptide.
protein sequencing by tandem mass spectr: Protein sequencing by tandem mass spectrometry assay is a technique used to determine the amino acid sequence of a protein by fragmenting the protein into peptides and analyzing the mass-to-charge ratios of these fragments using two stages of mass spectrometry.
protein state assay: A protein state assay is a laboratory technique used to determine the conformational state, activity, or modifications of a protein under specific conditions.
protein-containing complex: A protein-containing complex is a stable assembly of multiple proteins, often along with other molecules, that interact to perform a specific biological function within a cell.
protein-glutamine gamma-glutamyltransfer: Transglutaminases are enzymes that in nature primarily catalyze the formation of an isopeptide bond between γ-carboxamide groups ( -(C=O)NH2 ) of glutamine residue side chains and the ε-amino groups ( -NH2 ) of lysine residue side chains with subsequent release of ammonia ( NH3 ). Lysine and glutamine residues must be bound to a peptide or a protein so that this cross-linking (between separate molecules) or intramolecular (within the same molecule) reaction can happen. Bonds formed by transglutaminase exhibit high resistance to proteolytic degradation (proteolysis). The reaction isGln-(C=O)NH2 + NH2-Lys → Gln-(C=O)NH-Lys + NH3
protein-protein interaction detection as: A protein-protein interaction detection assay is a laboratory technique used to identify and characterize the physical interactions between two or more proteins.
proteomic profiling by array assay: Proteomic profiling by array assay is a technique used to analyze the expression levels of multiple proteins simultaneously in a biological sample, utilizing an array-based platform to identify and quantify proteins for research or diagnostic purposes.
proteomic profiling by array design: Proteomic profiling by array design is a technique used to analyze the expression and interaction of proteins in a biological sample by utilizing an array-based platform to capture and quantify multiple proteins simultaneously.
proteomic profiling design: Proteomic profiling design refers to the strategic planning and methodology used to systematically analyze and compare the complete set of proteins expressed in a cell, tissue, or organism under specific conditions, often to understand biological processes or disease mechanisms.
prothrombin time assay: A prothrombin time assay is a blood test that measures the time it takes for blood to clot, used to evaluate the extrinsic pathway of coagulation and monitor anticoagulant therapy.
protocol optimization design: Protocol optimization design refers to the process of refining and improving the structure and procedures of a clinical trial or biomedical study to enhance its efficiency, effectiveness, and reliability in achieving its objectives.
protocol optimization objective: The "protocol optimization objective" refers to the specific goal or set of goals aimed at improving the efficiency, effectiveness, or accuracy of a biomedical protocol or procedure.
protocol testing objective: A protocol testing objective is a specific goal or purpose that guides the evaluation and validation of a biomedical protocol to ensure its effectiveness, reliability, and compliance with regulatory standards.
proton density magnetic resonance image: A proton density magnetic resonance image data set is a collection of MRI images that primarily reflect the concentration of hydrogen protons in tissues, providing contrast based on tissue density rather than relaxation times.
proximity extension assay: The proximity extension assay (PEA) is a method for detecting and quantifying the amount of many specific proteins present in a biological sample such as serum or plasma. The method is used in the research field of proteomics, specifically affinity proteomics, where in one searches for differences in the abundance of many specific proteins in blood for use as a biomarker. Biomarkers and biomarker signature combinations, are useful for determining disease states and drug efficacy. Most methods for detecting proteins involve the use of a solid phase for first capturing and immobilizing the protein analyte, where in one or a few proteins are quantified, such as ELISA. In contrast, PEA is performed without a solid phase in a homogeneous one tube reaction solution where in sets of antibodies coupled to unique DNA sequence tags, so called proximity probes, work in pairs specific for each target protein. PEA is often performed using antibodies and is a type of immunoassay. Target binding by the proximity probes increases their local relative effective concentration of the DNA-tags enabling hybridization of weak complementarity to each other which then enables a DNA polymerase mediated extension forming a united DNA sequence specific for each target protein detected. The use of 3'exonuclease proficient polymerases lowers background noise and hyper thermostable polymerases mediate a simple assay with a natural hot-start reaction. This created pool of extension products of DNA sequence forms amplicons amplified by PCR where each amplicon sequence corresponds to a target proteins identity and the amount reflects its quantity. Subsequently, these amplicons are detected and quantified by either real-time PCR or next generation DNA sequencing by DNA-tag counting. PEA enables the detection of many proteins simultaneously due to the readout requiring the combination of two correctly bound antibodies per protein to generate a detectable DNA sequence from the extension reaction. Only cognate pairs of sequence are detected as true signal, enabling multiplexing beyond solid phase capture methods limited at around 30 proteins at a time. The DNA amplification power also enable minute sample volumes even below one microliter. PEA has been used in over 1000 research publications.
proximity ligation-assisted ChIP-seq: Proximity ligation-assisted ChIP-seq is a genomic technique that combines chromatin immunoprecipitation (ChIP) with proximity ligation and sequencing to map protein-DNA interactions and chromatin conformation in a high-throughput manner.
proxy respondent role: A proxy respondent role refers to an individual who provides information or answers survey questions on behalf of another person who is unable to do so themselves, often due to health or cognitive limitations.
pseudovirus entry assay: A pseudovirus entry assay is a laboratory technique used to study the entry of viruses into host cells by utilizing non-replicating viral particles that mimic the virus of interest, allowing for safe and controlled analysis of viral entry mechanisms.
publication about an investigation: A "publication about an investigation" refers to a documented report or article detailing the methods, results, and conclusions of a scientific or medical research study.
pulse stable isotope labeling by amino a: Pulse stable isotope labeling by amino acids in cell culture (pSILAC) is a technique used to study protein synthesis and turnover by incorporating labeled amino acids into proteins within living cells over a short period.
pulsed amperometric detector: A pulsed amperometric detector is an analytical device used in liquid chromatography to measure the current produced by the oxidation or reduction of analytes at the electrode surface, with the potential being periodically pulsed to enhance sensitivity and selectivity.
pulsed-field gel electrophoresis system: A pulsed-field gel electrophoresis system is a laboratory technique used to separate large DNA molecules by applying an alternating electric field to a gel matrix, allowing for the analysis of complex genetic material.
pump function: Pump function refers to the ability of the heart to effectively circulate blood throughout the body by contracting and relaxing in a coordinated manner.
pump valve switch: A "pump valve switch" in a biomedical context refers to a mechanism that controls the flow of fluids or gases through a pump system by opening or closing valves, often used in medical devices or laboratory equipment.
pupal specimen collection process: The pupal specimen collection process involves gathering and preserving pupae, the developmental stage between larva and adult in insects, for scientific study or research.
purification: Purification is the process of rendering something pure, i.e. clean of foreign elements and/or pollution, and may refer to:
purification objective: The "purification objective" in a biomedical context refers to the specific goal or desired outcome of a process designed to isolate and concentrate a particular biomolecule or compound from a mixture, enhancing its purity for further study or application.
purified MHC molecule preparation: A purified MHC molecule preparation refers to a laboratory-produced sample of major histocompatibility complex (MHC) molecules that have been isolated and purified for research or therapeutic purposes.
purified material: Purified material refers to a substance that has been processed to remove impurities or contaminants, resulting in a high degree of purity for use in biomedical applications.
putamen: The putamen is a subcortical nucleus with a rounded structure, in the basal ganglia nuclear group. It is located at the base of the forebrain and above the midbrain.
pyrosequencing assay: A pyrosequencing assay is a DNA sequencing technique that detects nucleotide incorporation through the release of pyrophosphate, enabling real-time analysis of short DNA sequences.
q-value: Q value, Q factor, and Q score may refer to:Q factor, a measurement of a resonant system's relative bandwidth Radiation weighting factors used in ionizing radiation dosimetry Q factor (bicycles), the width between where a bicycle's pedals attach to the cranks q-value (statistics), the minimum false discovery rate at which the test may be called significant Q value, a difference of energies of parent and daughter nuclides Q Score, in marketing, a way to measure the familiarity of an item Fusion energy gain factor Q, the ratio of fusion power produced in a reactor to the power required to maintain the plasma in steady state Q, in number theory, a way of representing decimal numbers in a fixed-point math system Q factor, a way of representing bit error rates in dB
quality control testing design: Quality control testing design in biomedicine refers to the systematic planning and structuring of tests and procedures to ensure that biomedical products or processes meet specified standards of quality and performance.
quality of a gas: The "quality of a gas" refers to the purity and composition of a gas, including the presence and concentration of impurities or contaminants, which can affect its suitability for specific applications or processes.
quality of a liquid: The "quality of a liquid" refers to the characteristics or attributes of a liquid that determine its suitability for a particular use, including factors such as purity, composition, viscosity, and safety.
quality of a solid: "Quality of a solid" refers to the characteristics or attributes that determine the performance, stability, and suitability of a solid material for a specific biomedical application, including factors like purity, density, and structural integrity.
quality of a substance: The "quality of a substance" refers to the degree to which a substance meets specified standards or criteria, including its purity, potency, safety, and efficacy, often in relation to its intended use in biomedical applications.
quality of interaction of a substance wi: The "quality of interaction of a substance with electromagnetic radiation" refers to how a substance absorbs, emits, or scatters electromagnetic waves, influencing its spectroscopic and optical properties.
quantile calculation: Quantile calculation is a statistical method used to divide a dataset into equal-sized, contiguous intervals, allowing for the analysis of the distribution of data points within those intervals.
quantile number of false positives corre: The "quantile number of false positives correction method" is a statistical technique used to adjust for multiple comparisons in biomedical research by controlling the expected proportion of false positive results across different quantiles of data.
quantile proportion of false positives c: The quantile proportion of false positives correction method is a statistical technique used to adjust for multiple comparisons by controlling the proportion of false positive results across different quantiles in a dataset.
quantile transformation: Quantile transformation is a statistical technique used to map data to a uniform distribution by transforming the quantiles of the data to match those of a specified distribution, often to normalize the data.
quantitative binding datum: A quantitative binding datum is a numerical measurement that describes the strength or affinity of the interaction between two molecules, such as a ligand and a receptor, in a biological context.
quantitative confidence value: A quantitative confidence value is a numerical measure that indicates the degree of certainty or reliability associated with a particular result or estimate in biomedical research or analysis.
quantitative node degree calculation: Quantitative node degree calculation refers to the process of determining the number of direct connections or edges a particular node has within a network, often used in the analysis of biological systems or neural networks.
quantitative subgraph degree calculation: Quantitative subgraph degree calculation is a computational method used to measure and analyze the connectivity and interaction patterns of specific subgraphs within a larger biological network or graph.
quantitative venous blood IgA assay: A quantitative venous blood IgA assay is a laboratory test that measures the concentration of immunoglobulin A (IgA) in a blood sample drawn from a vein to assess immune function or diagnose certain medical conditions.
quantitative venous blood IgG assay: A quantitative venous blood IgG assay is a laboratory test that measures the concentration of immunoglobulin G (IgG) antibodies in a blood sample drawn from a vein, used to assess immune function or diagnose various conditions.
quantitative venous blood IgM assay: A quantitative venous blood IgM assay is a laboratory test that measures the concentration of immunoglobulin M (IgM) antibodies in a blood sample drawn from a vein to assess immune function or diagnose infections.
quartz crystal microbalance assay: A quartz crystal microbalance assay is a sensitive analytical technique used to measure minute changes in mass on a quartz crystal surface by detecting variations in its resonant frequency.
quartz crystal microbalance assay measur: A quartz crystal microbalance assay measuring the dissociation constant [KD] of a B cell epitope:antibody complex is a sensitive analytical technique used to quantify the binding affinity between a specific region of an antigen (epitope) and an antibody by detecting changes in frequency of a quartz crystal
quartz cuvette flow chamber: A quartz cuvette flow chamber is a laboratory device used for holding liquid samples in spectroscopic experiments, allowing continuous flow and optical analysis due to its transparent quartz construction.
quaternary pump system: A quaternary pump system in biomedical contexts refers to a type of liquid chromatography pump that can mix and deliver four different solvents in precise ratios for analytical and preparative applications.
quenching assay measuring binding of a B: A quenching assay measuring the binding of a B cell epitope:antibody complex is a laboratory technique used to evaluate the interaction between a specific region of an antigen (epitope) and an antibody by detecting changes in fluorescence or other signal reduction upon binding.
quenching assay measuring the associatio: A quenching assay measuring the association constant \([K_A]\) of a B cell epitope:antibody complex is a laboratory technique used to determine the strength and stability of the binding interaction between a specific epitope on a B cell and its corresponding antibody by observing changes in fluorescence or
quenching assay measuring the dissociati: A quenching assay measuring the dissociation constant (KD) of a B cell epitope:antibody complex is a laboratory technique used to determine the strength of the interaction between an antibody and its specific epitope by assessing how effectively the antibody can bind and release the epitope.
quenching assay measuring the off rate [: A quenching assay measuring the off rate [koff] of a B cell epitope:antibody complex is a laboratory technique used to determine the rate at which an antibody dissociates from its specific antigenic epitope on a B cell.
quenching assay measuring the on rate [k: A quenching assay measuring the on rate (\(k_{\text{on}}\)) of a B cell epitope:antibody complex is a laboratory technique used to determine the rate at which an antibody binds to its specific epitope on a B cell by monitoring the decrease in fluorescence as the
questionnaire: A questionnaire is a research instrument that consists of a set of questions for the purpose of gathering information from respondents through survey or statistical study. A research questionnaire is typically a mix of close-ended questions and open-ended questions. Open-ended, long-term questions offer the respondent the ability to elaborate on their thoughts. The Research questionnaire was developed by the Statistical Society of London in 1838.
rac-lactic acid: Rac-lactic acid is a racemic mixture of lactic acid, consisting of equal parts of its two enantiomers, D-lactic acid and L-lactic acid, commonly used in various industrial and pharmaceutical applications.
rac-lactic acid assay: A rac-lactic acid assay is a laboratory test used to measure the concentration of lactic acid, specifically the racemic mixture of its D- and L-isomers, in a biological sample.
radiation measurement device: A radiation measurement device is an instrument used to detect and quantify ionizing radiation levels in various environments for safety, diagnostic, or research purposes.
radiation treatment exclusion criteria: Radiation treatment exclusion criteria refer to specific conditions or factors that disqualify a patient from receiving radiation therapy due to potential risks or contraindications.
radiation treatment within the recent pa: The "radiation treatment within the recent past exclusion criterion" refers to a condition in clinical trials where individuals who have received radiation therapy within a specified recent timeframe are excluded from participating, to ensure safety and avoid confounding effects.
radio immuno assay: Radioimmunoassay is a sensitive laboratory technique used to measure the concentration of antigens in a sample by using antibodies and radioactively labeled substances.
radio immuno assay measuring epitope spe: Radioimmunoassay measuring epitope-specific interferon-gamma production by T cells is a laboratory technique used to quantify the amount of interferon-gamma produced by T cells in response to specific antigenic epitopes, utilizing radiolabeled antibodies for detection.
radioactive: Radioactive decay is the process by which an unstable atomic nucleus loses energy by radiation. A material containing unstable nuclei is considered radioactive. Three of the most common types of decay are alpha, beta, and gamma decay. The weak force is the mechanism that is responsible for beta decay, while the other two are governed by the electromagnetic and nuclear forces.
radioactivity detection: Radioactivity detection refers to the process of identifying and measuring the presence and intensity of radioactive substances through the use of specialized instruments and techniques.
radioactivity detection assay measuring: A radioactivity detection assay measuring the binding off rate (koff) is a technique used to determine the direct binding affinity and dissociation rate of a cell-lysate-MHC:ligand complex by tracking the loss of radioactively labeled ligands over time.

A radioactivity detection assay measuring competitive binding of a cell-bound-MHC:ligand complex is a laboratory technique used to quantify the binding affinity and competition between a labeled ligand and other molecules for a specific major histocompatibility complex (MHC) on the surface of cells, using radioactivity as

A radioactivity detection assay measuring competitive binding of a purified-MHC:ligand complex is a laboratory technique used to quantify the binding affinity and specificity of ligands to major histocompatibility complex (MHC) molecules by detecting changes in radioactivity as different ligands compete for binding sites.

A radioactivity detection assay measuring direct binding of a cell-bound-MHC:ligand complex is a laboratory technique used to quantify the interaction between a major histocompatibility complex (MHC) molecule on a cell surface and its ligand by detecting radioactive signals.

A radioactivity detection assay measuring direct binding of a cell-lysate-MHC:ligand complex is a laboratory technique used to quantify the interaction between a major histocompatibility complex (MHC) molecule and its ligand within a cell lysate by detecting emitted radioactivity.

A radioactivity detection assay measuring direct binding of a purified MHC:ligand complex is a laboratory technique used to quantify the interaction between a major histocompatibility complex (MHC) molecule and its ligand by detecting radioactive signals emitted from labeled components.

A radioactivity detection assay measuring the equilibrium dissociation constant (KD) is a technique used to determine the competitive binding affinity of a ligand to a cell-bound major histocompatibility complex (MHC) by quantifying the displacement of a radiolabeled ligand.

A radioactivity detection assay measuring the equilibrium dissociation constant (KD) is a method used to determine the competitive binding affinity of a ligand to a major histocompatibility complex (MHC) within a cell lysate by quantifying the displacement of a radiolabeled ligand.

A radioactivity detection assay measuring the equilibrium dissociation constant (KD) is a laboratory technique used to determine the competitive binding affinity between a purified major histocompatibility complex (MHC):ligand complex and other potential ligands by assessing the rate at which the complex dissociates.

A radioactivity detection assay measuring the equilibrium dissociation constant (KD) is a method used to determine the competitive binding affinity of a purified major histocompatibility complex (MHC):ligand complex, approximated by the half-maximal inhibitory concentration (IC50), to assess how well a ligand

A radioactivity detection assay measuring half-life to determine direct binding of a cell-bound MHC:ligand complex is a laboratory technique used to assess the stability and duration of interaction between a major histocompatibility complex (MHC) molecule on a cell surface and its ligand by tracking radioactive decay over

A radioactivity detection assay measuring half-life to determine direct binding of a cell-lysate-MHC:ligand complex is a laboratory technique used to assess the stability and duration of interaction between a major histocompatibility complex (MHC) molecule and a ligand in a cell lysate by tracking

A radioactivity detection assay measuring half-life to determine direct binding of a purified MHC:ligand complex is a laboratory technique used to assess the stability and duration of interaction between a major histocompatibility complex (MHC) molecule and its ligand by tracking radioactive decay over time.

A radioactivity detection assay measuring half maximal effective concentration (EC50) is a technique used to quantify the concentration of a ligand required to achieve half-maximal binding to a major histocompatibility complex (MHC) within a cell lysate, indicating the strength and specificity of the interaction.

A radioactivity detection assay measuring half maximal inhibitory concentration (IC50) is a laboratory technique used to quantify the concentration of a substance required to inhibit by half the binding of a ligand to a cell-bound major histocompatibility complex (MHC), thereby assessing the competitive binding affinity of the ligand.

A radioactivity detection assay measuring half maximal inhibitory concentration (IC50) is a laboratory technique used to quantify the concentration of a substance required to inhibit the binding of a ligand to a purified major histocompatibility complex (MHC) by 50%, indicating the substance's competitive binding affinity.
radiography instrument: A radiography instrument is a medical device used to capture images of the internal structures of the body using X-rays for diagnostic purposes.
radiolabel role: A radiolabel role refers to the function of a radioactive isotope or compound used to trace or label molecules in biological systems for imaging or analytical purposes.
random access memory: Random-access memory is a form of electronic computer memory that can be read and changed in any order, typically used to store working data and machine code. A random-access memory device allows data items to be read or written in almost the same amount of time irrespective of the physical location of data inside the memory, in contrast with other direct-access data storage media, where the time required to read and write data items varies significantly depending on their physical locations on the recording medium, due to mechanical limitations such as media rotation speeds and arm movement.
random access memory size: Random access memory size refers to the amount of data that can be temporarily stored and accessed quickly by a computer's RAM, impacting the system's ability to run applications and process information efficiently.
random electrolytes urine potassium assa: A random electrolytes urine potassium assay is a laboratory test that measures the concentration of potassium in a urine sample collected at a non-specific time to assess electrolyte balance and kidney function.
random electrolytes urine sodium assay: A random electrolytes urine sodium assay is a diagnostic test that measures the concentration of sodium and other electrolytes in a urine sample collected at a non-specific time to assess kidney function and electrolyte balance.
random mutagenesis: In molecular biology, mutagenesis is an important laboratory technique whereby DNA mutations are deliberately engineered to produce libraries of mutant genes, proteins, strains of bacteria, or other genetically modified organisms. The various constituents of a gene, as well as its regulatory elements and its gene products, may be mutated so that the functioning of a genetic locus, process, or product can be examined in detail. The mutation may produce mutant proteins with interesting properties or enhanced or novel functions that may be of commercial use. Mutant strains may also be produced that have practical application or allow the molecular basis of a particular cell function to be investigated.
random primed DNA labeling: Random primed DNA labeling is a molecular biology technique used to generate labeled DNA probes by synthesizing complementary DNA strands from a template using random oligonucleotide primers and labeled nucleotides.
random venous blood amikacin assay: A random venous blood amikacin assay is a laboratory test that measures the concentration of the antibiotic amikacin in a blood sample drawn from a vein at a non-specified time, to monitor therapeutic levels and avoid toxicity.
random venous blood tobramycin assay: A random venous blood tobramycin assay is a laboratory test that measures the concentration of the antibiotic tobramycin in a blood sample taken from a vein at a non-specified time, to monitor therapeutic levels and avoid toxicity.
random venous blood vancomycin assay: A random venous blood vancomycin assay is a laboratory test that measures the concentration of the antibiotic vancomycin in a blood sample taken at a non-specified time to monitor therapeutic levels and ensure safety.
randomized complete block design: A randomized complete block design is an experimental design in which subjects are divided into blocks based on certain characteristics, and within each block, treatments are randomly assigned to control for variability among the blocks.
randomized group participant role: A "randomized group participant role" refers to the assignment of an individual to a specific group within a study or clinical trial, where the group allocation is determined by a randomization process to ensure unbiased comparison of outcomes.
rapid alternating hands assessment: The rapid alternating hands assessment is a neurological test used to evaluate coordination and the ability to perform rapid, alternating movements, often by having a person quickly turn their hands back and forth on a surface.
rapid amplification of cDNA ends: Rapid amplification of cDNA ends (RACE) is a technique used in molecular biology to obtain the full length sequence of an RNA transcript found within a cell. RACE results in the production of a cDNA copy of the RNA sequence of interest, produced through reverse transcription, followed by PCR amplification of the cDNA copies. The amplified cDNA copies are then sequenced and, if long enough, should map to a unique genomic region. RACE is commonly followed up by cloning before sequencing of what was originally individual RNA molecules. A more high-throughput alternative which is useful for identification of novel transcript structures, is to sequence the RACE-products by next generation sequencing technologies.
rapid plasma reagin test: The rapid plasma reagin (RPR) test is a blood test used to screen for syphilis by detecting non-specific antibodies that may indicate a syphilis infection.
rapid resolution column: A rapid resolution column is a type of chromatography column designed to separate compounds quickly and efficiently, often used in high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) for analyzing complex mixtures.
rare earth metal atom: A rare earth metal atom refers to an atom of any of the 17 chemically similar metallic elements found in the periodic table's lanthanide series, plus scandium and yttrium, known for their unique magnetic, luminescent, and electrochemical properties.
rat MHC class I protein complex: The rat MHC class I protein complex is a molecular structure on the surface of rat cells that presents endogenous peptide antigens to cytotoxic T cells, playing a crucial role in the immune response.
rat MHC class II protein complex with RT: The rat MHC class II protein complex with RT1-A haplotype refers to a specific set of proteins involved in the immune response, encoded by the major histocompatibility complex (MHC) in rats, with the RT1-A haplotype denoting a particular genetic variant.
rate measurement datum: A "rate measurement datum" refers to a specific data point or value that quantifies the rate at which a particular biological or physiological process occurs.
rate unit: A "rate unit" in biomedical contexts refers to a standardized measure used to quantify the frequency or speed of a biological process or event over a specified period of time.
ratio of collected to emitted light: The "ratio of collected to emitted light" refers to the proportion of light that is captured by a detector compared to the total light originally emitted by a source, often used in contexts like fluorescence microscopy to assess efficiency or signal quality.
raw image data set: A raw image data set in biomedical contexts refers to unprocessed or minimally processed digital images collected from medical imaging devices, such as MRI or CT scanners, which contain detailed visual information for analysis and interpretation.
raw magnetic resonance image data set: A raw magnetic resonance image data set refers to the unprocessed collection of data acquired directly from an MRI scanner, containing detailed information about the magnetic properties of tissues, which can be reconstructed into visual images for diagnostic purposes.
raw magnetic resonance image data set re: Raw magnetic resonance image data set reconstruction refers to the process of converting raw data collected by an MRI scanner into interpretable images through computational algorithms and techniques.
reactant role: In biomedicine, the term 'reactant role' refers to the function of a substance that participates in and undergoes change during a chemical reaction.
reagent: A compound or mixture of compounds used to treat or test materials, samples, other compounds or reactants in a laboratory or sometimes an industrial setting.
reagent application function: The "reagent application function" refers to the specific role or purpose that a reagent serves in a biochemical or medical procedure, such as facilitating a reaction, indicating the presence of a substance, or measuring a particular component.
reagent role: In biomedical contexts, a "reagent role" refers to the function or purpose of a substance used in a chemical reaction or process to detect, measure, examine, or produce other substances.
real time polymerase chain reaction assa: A real-time polymerase chain reaction (PCR) assay is a laboratory technique used to amplify and simultaneously quantify a targeted DNA molecule, allowing for the detection and measurement of specific genetic material in real time.
real time reverse-transcription polymera: A real-time reverse-transcription polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) assay is a laboratory technique used to amplify and simultaneously quantify a specific RNA sequence by converting it into DNA and monitoring the amplification process in real-time.
real-time PCR machine: A real-time PCR machine is a laboratory instrument used to amplify and simultaneously quantify a targeted DNA molecule, allowing for the monitoring of the reaction in real-time through the use of fluorescent dyes or probes.
realizable entity: A realizable entity in biomedicine refers to a potential or latent capability or disposition within a biological system that can be actualized under certain conditions.
reason for lack of data item: "Reason for lack of data item" refers to the explanation or justification for the absence or unavailability of a specific piece of data within a dataset or study.
reasoned ontology module: A reasoned ontology module is a subset of an ontology that is logically consistent and self-contained, allowing for efficient reasoning and inference within a specific domain of knowledge.
recombinant BAC cloning: Recombinant BAC cloning is a molecular biology technique used to insert and propagate large DNA fragments within bacterial artificial chromosomes (BACs) for the purpose of studying and manipulating genes.
recombinant YAC cloning: Recombinant YAC (Yeast Artificial Chromosome) cloning is a technique used to clone large fragments of DNA by inserting them into a yeast artificial chromosome, which can replicate within a yeast cell, allowing for the analysis and manipulation of large genomic sequences.
recombinant phage cloning: Recombinant phage cloning is a molecular biology technique that involves inserting foreign DNA into a bacteriophage vector to replicate and manipulate the DNA within a bacterial host.
recombinant plasmid: A recombinant plasmid is a circular DNA molecule that has been genetically engineered to include foreign DNA sequences, allowing it to replicate and express specific genes within a host cell.
recombinant plasmid cloning: Recombinant plasmid cloning is a molecular biology technique used to insert a specific DNA fragment into a plasmid vector, which is then introduced into a host cell for replication and expression.
recombinant vector: A recombinant vector is a genetically engineered DNA molecule used to deliver genetic material into cells for research, therapeutic, or vaccine purposes.
recombinant vector cloning: Recombinant vector cloning is a molecular biology technique used to insert a DNA fragment of interest into a vector, such as a plasmid, which is then introduced into a host cell for replication and expression.
recombination enzyme based cloning: Recombination enzyme-based cloning is a molecular biology technique that uses enzymes to facilitate the insertion of DNA fragments into vectors through site-specific recombination, enabling the efficient and precise assembly of genetic constructs.
reconstitution assay: A reconstitution assay is an experimental technique used to study the function of biomolecules by combining purified components in vitro to recreate and analyze a biological process or pathway.
reconstructed magnetic resonance image d: A reconstructed magnetic resonance image data set refers to the processed collection of images generated from raw MRI data, which have been mathematically transformed to produce clear, interpretable visual representations of the scanned anatomical structures.
record function: In the biomedical context, "record function" typically refers to the process of documenting and tracking physiological data or medical information to monitor and assess the health status or function of a biological system or organ.
record of missing knowledge: A "record of missing knowledge" in biomedicine refers to a documented account of gaps or deficiencies in current scientific understanding or data, highlighting areas where further research is needed.
record of unknown sex: A "record of unknown sex" refers to a medical or biological data entry where the sex of the individual is not specified or determined.
rectal swab specimen: A rectal swab specimen is a sample collected from the rectum using a small, sterile swab for the purpose of diagnosing infections or other medical conditions.
rectum: The rectum is the final straight portion of the large intestine in humans and some other mammals, and the gut in others. Before expulsion through the anus or cloaca, the rectum stores the feces temporarily. The adult human rectum is about 12 centimetres (4.7 in) long, and begins at the rectosigmoid junction at the level of the third sacral vertebra or the sacral promontory depending upon what definition is used. Its diameter is similar to that of the sigmoid colon at its commencement, but it is dilated near its termination, forming the rectal ampulla. It terminates at the level of the anorectal ring or the dentate line, again depending upon which definition is used. In humans, the rectum is followed by the anal canal, which is about 4 centimetres (1.6 in) long, before the gastrointestinal tract terminates at the anal verge. The word rectum comes from the Latin rēctum intestīnum, meaning straight intestine.
reduced dimension data set: A reduced dimension data set is a simplified version of a larger data set where the number of variables or features has been decreased, often to enhance analysis or visualization while retaining essential information.
reduced representation bisulfite sequenc: Reduced representation bisulfite sequencing assay is a technique used to analyze DNA methylation patterns across a subset of the genome, providing a cost-effective and high-resolution method for studying epigenetic modifications.
reference design: A reference design is a technical design of a system that is intended for others to copy. It contains the essential elements of the system; however, third parties may enhance or modify the design as required. When discussing computer designs, the concept is generally known as a reference platform.
reference gene sequence start site: The "reference gene sequence start site" refers to the specific location in a reference genome where the transcription of a gene begins, often marked by the transcription start site (TSS).
reference gene sequence stop site: A reference gene sequence stop site is the location within a gene sequence where translation terminates, typically marked by a stop codon, serving as a standard for comparing genetic variations.
reference genome role: A "reference genome role" refers to the function or purpose of a reference genome, which serves as a standard or baseline genetic sequence used for comparison and analysis in genomic studies.
reference genome-transcriptome alignment: A reference genome-transcriptome alignment algorithm is a computational method used to map and compare RNA sequences (transcriptome) to a known reference genome to study gene expression and functional genomics.
reference protein sequence start site: A reference protein sequence start site is the specific position in a protein sequence where translation is initiated, typically corresponding to the first amino acid encoded by the start codon in the mRNA.
reference protein sequence stop site: A reference protein sequence stop site is the location within a protein sequence where translation terminates, typically marked by a stop codon in the corresponding mRNA.
reference subject role: The "reference subject role" in biomedicine refers to the function or position of an individual or entity that serves as a standard or benchmark for comparison in a study or experiment.
reference substance role: The term "reference substance role" refers to the function of a substance used as a standard or benchmark in scientific experiments or analyses to ensure consistency and accuracy in the measurement of other substances.
refractive index detector: A differential refractometer (DRI), or refractive index detector is a detector that measures the refractive index of an analyte relative to the solvent. They are often used as detectors for high-performance liquid chromatography and size exclusion chromatography. They are considered to be universal detectors because they can detect anything with a refractive index different from the solvent, but they have low sensitivity.
regression analysis method: Regression analysis method is a statistical technique used to model and analyze the relationships between a dependent variable and one or more independent variables, often to predict outcomes or identify trends.
regulation-assigned role: A "regulation-assigned role" refers to a specific function or responsibility designated to a biological molecule or process as determined by regulatory mechanisms within an organism.
regulator role: In biomedicine, a "regulator role" refers to the function of a molecule or entity that modulates or controls a biological process, ensuring it operates within a specific range or responds appropriately to changes in the environment.
regulatory agency: A regulatory agency or independent agency is a government authority that is responsible for exercising autonomous jurisdiction over some area of human activity in a licensing and regulating capacity. Examples of responsibilities include strengthening safety and standards, and/or to protect consumers in markets where there is a lack of effective competition. Examples of regulatory agencies that enforce standards include the Food and Drug Administration in the United States and the Medicines and Healthcare products Regulatory Agency in the United Kingdom; and, in the case of economic regulation, the Office of Gas and Electricity Markets and the Telecom Regulatory Authority in India.
regulatory role: A regulatory role refers to the function of controlling or influencing biological processes, often through the modulation of gene expression, protein activity, or cellular signaling pathways.
regulatory_region: A regulatory sequence is a segment of a nucleic acid molecule which is capable of increasing or decreasing the expression of specific genes within an organism. Regulation of gene expression is an essential feature of all living organisms and viruses.
relational quality: Relational quality in a biomedical context refers to the nature and strength of the interactions and connections between different biological entities, such as cells, tissues, or systems, and how these interactions influence their function and behavior.
remote patient assessment: Remote patient assessment refers to the evaluation and monitoring of a patient's health status from a distance using telecommunication technologies, allowing healthcare providers to gather data and make clinical decisions without requiring an in-person visit.
renal medulla: The renal medulla is the innermost part of the kidney. The renal medulla is split up into a number of sections, known as the renal pyramids. Blood enters into the kidney via the renal artery, which then splits up to form the segmental arteries which then branch to form interlobar arteries. The interlobar arteries each in turn branch into arcuate arteries, which in turn branch to form interlobular arteries, and these finally reach the glomeruli. At the glomerulus the blood reaches a highly disfavourable pressure gradient and a large exchange surface area, which forces the serum portion of the blood out of the vessel and into the renal tubules. Flow continues through the renal tubules, including the proximal tubule, the loop of Henle, through the distal tubule and finally leaves the kidney by means of the collecting duct, leading to the renal pelvis, the dilated portion of the ureter.
renal medulla specimen: A renal medulla specimen is a sample of tissue taken from the innermost part of the kidney, known as the medulla, for the purpose of examination or analysis.
repeated measure design: A repeated measure design is a type of experimental design in which the same subjects are exposed to multiple conditions or treatments, allowing for the assessment of changes over time or across different scenarios within the same individuals.
replicate analysis: Replicate analysis refers to the process of conducting repeated measurements or experiments under the same conditions to assess the consistency and reliability of the results.
replicate design: Replicate design in biomedical research refers to the experimental setup where multiple identical copies of a study or experiment are conducted to ensure reliability and reproducibility of the results.
report: A report is a document or a statement that presents information in an organized format for a specific audience and purpose. Although summaries of reports may be delivered orally, complete reports are usually given in the form of written documents. Typically reports relay information that was found or observed. The credible report enhances the previous beliefs while dishonest information can question the agency preparing the report. Reports from IPCC as IPCC reports, World Health Report and Global Gender Gap Report from World Economic Forums are few examples of reports highlighting important worldly affairs.
reporter cell line analyte detection bio: A reporter cell line analyte detection bioassay is a laboratory test that uses genetically engineered cells containing a reporter gene to detect and measure the presence or activity of specific biological molecules or analytes.
reporter gene assay: Reporter genes are molecular tools widely used in molecular biology, genetics, and biotechnology to study gene function, expression patterns, and regulatory mechanisms. These genes encode proteins that produce easily detectable signals, such as fluorescence, luminescence, or enzymatic activity, allowing researchers to monitor cellular processes in real-time. Reporter genes are often fused to regulatory sequences of genes of interest, enabling scientists to analyze promoter activity, transcriptional regulation, and signal transduction pathways. Common reporter gene systems include green fluorescent protein (GFP), β-galactosidase (lacZ), luciferase, and chloramphenicol acetyltransferase (CAT), each offering distinct advantages depending on the experimental application. Their versatility makes reporter genes invaluable in fields such as drug discovery, gene therapy, and synthetic biology.
reporting party role: The "reporting party role" in a biomedical context refers to the function or responsibility of an individual or entity that provides information or data about a specific event, condition, or observation, often for the purposes of monitoring, investigation, or regulatory compliance.
research organization: A research institute, research centre, or research organization is an establishment founded for doing research. Research institutes may specialize in basic research or may be oriented to applied research. Although the term often implies natural science research, there are also many research institutes in the social science as well, especially for sociological and historical research purposes.
respiratory system: The respiratory system is a biological system consisting of specific organs and structures used for gas exchange in animals and plants. The anatomy and physiology that make this happen varies greatly, depending on the size of the organism, the environment in which it lives and its evolutionary history. In land animals, the respiratory surface is internalized as linings of the lungs. Gas exchange in the lungs occurs in millions of small air sacs; in mammals and reptiles, these are called alveoli, and in birds, they are known as atria. These microscopic air sacs have a very rich blood supply, thus bringing the air into close contact with the blood. These air sacs communicate with the external environment via a system of airways, or hollow tubes, of which the largest is the trachea, which branches in the middle of the chest into the two main bronchi. These enter the lungs where they branch into progressively narrower secondary and tertiary bronchi that branch into numerous smaller tubes, the bronchioles. In birds, the bronchioles are termed parabronchi. It is the bronchioles, or parabronchi that generally open into the microscopic alveoli in mammals and atria in birds. Air has to be pumped from the environment into the alveoli or atria by the process of breathing which involves the muscles of respiration.
respiratory system fluid/secretion: Respiratory system fluid/secretion refers to the various liquids produced within the respiratory tract, such as mucus, that help to trap and expel foreign particles, pathogens, and debris, while also keeping the airways moist and facilitating gas exchange.
respiratory system specimen: A respiratory system specimen is a sample collected from the respiratory tract, such as sputum, nasal swabs, or bronchoalveolar lavage fluid, used for diagnostic testing or research purposes.
response to stimulus: "Response to stimulus" refers to a biological process in which an organism or a cell detects and reacts to a change or signal in its internal or external environment.
responsible party role: In the biomedical context, the "responsible party role" refers to the individual or organization accountable for the conduct of a clinical trial, including ensuring compliance with regulatory requirements and overseeing the trial's execution and reporting.
resting arthropod trap: A resting arthropod trap is a device used to capture arthropods, such as mosquitoes, in their resting habitats for the purpose of monitoring and studying their populations and behaviors.
resting box trap: A resting box trap is a device used in entomology to capture and monitor resting mosquitoes or other insects, typically for the purpose of studying their behavior, population, or disease-carrying potential.
resting bucket: The term "resting bucket" does not appear to be a recognized biomedical term or entity; it may be a misinterpretation or a term from a specific niche or context not widely documented in biomedical literature.
resting clay pot trap: A "resting clay pot trap" is a device used in entomology to capture and monitor mosquitoes, particularly those that rest in dark, humid environments, by mimicking their natural resting sites.
resting flight-capable arthropod specime: The "resting flight-capable arthropod specimen collection process" refers to the method of gathering arthropods, such as insects, that are capable of flight, while they are in a stationary or non-flying state.
resting state functional magnetic resona: A resting state functional magnetic resonance image (fMRI) data set refers to a collection of brain imaging data acquired while a subject is not performing any specific task, used to analyze brain activity and connectivity patterns during a resting state.
restricting MHC role: The "restricting MHC role" refers to the function of Major Histocompatibility Complex (MHC) molecules in presenting specific peptide antigens to T cells, thereby determining the specificity and activation of the immune response.
restriction enzyme: A restriction enzyme, restriction endonuclease, REase, ENase or restrictase is an enzyme that cleaves DNA into fragments at or near specific recognition sites within molecules known as restriction sites. Restriction enzymes are one class of the broader endonuclease group of enzymes. Restriction enzymes are commonly classified into five types, which differ in their structure and whether they cut their DNA substrate at their recognition site, or if the recognition and cleavage sites are separate from one another. To cut DNA, all restriction enzymes make two incisions, once through each sugar-phosphate backbone of the DNA double helix.
restriction enzyme based cloning: Restriction enzyme-based cloning is a molecular biology technique that involves using restriction enzymes to cut DNA at specific sequences, allowing for the insertion or removal of DNA fragments for cloning purposes.
restriction fragment length polymorphism: A restriction fragment length polymorphism (RFLP) assay is a molecular technique used to detect variations in DNA sequences by analyzing the lengths of fragments produced after digestion with specific restriction enzymes.
reticulocyte: In hematology, reticulocytes are immature red blood cells (RBCs). In the process of erythropoiesis, reticulocytes develop and mature in the bone marrow and then circulate for about a day in the blood stream before developing into mature red blood cells. Like mature red blood cells, in mammals, reticulocytes do not have a cell nucleus. They are called reticulocytes because of a reticular (mesh-like) network of ribosomal RNA that becomes visible under a microscope with certain stains such as new methylene blue and Romanowsky stain.
reticulocyte assay: A reticulocyte assay is a laboratory test used to measure the number and percentage of reticulocytes, which are immature red blood cells, in the blood to assess bone marrow function and red blood cell production.
