substance unit: A "substance unit" refers to a standardized measurement used to quantify the amount of a specific substance, often in terms of moles or molecules, within a given sample or context in biomedical and chemical sciences.
supercontig: An ordered and oriented set of contigs that still contains some gaps. See also scaffold.
supernatant collection system harvesting: A supernatant collection system harvesting frame is a device or structure used to support and facilitate the collection of the liquid supernatant from a mixture after the solid components have settled or been separated.
supernatant role: In a biomedical context, the "supernatant role" refers to the function or significance of the liquid portion that remains above the solid or precipitated material after centrifugation or settling in a mixture, often used for further analysis or experimentation.
supervised machine learning: In machine learning, supervised learning (SL) is a paradigm where a model is trained using input objects and desired output values, which are often human-made labels. The training process builds a function that maps new data to expected output values. An optimal scenario will allow for the algorithm to accurately determine output values for unseen instances. This requires the learning algorithm to generalize from the training data to unseen situations in a reasonable way. This statistical quality of an algorithm is measured via a generalization error.
supplying: present participle and gerund of supply
support service: In the biomedical context, "support service" refers to auxiliary services that assist in the delivery of healthcare, such as laboratory, radiology, and nutritional services, which help ensure comprehensive patient care.
support vector machine: In machine learning, support vector machines are supervised max-margin models with associated learning algorithms that analyze data for classification and regression analysis. Developed at AT&T Bell Laboratories, SVMs are one of the most studied models, being based on statistical learning frameworks of VC theory proposed by Vapnik and Chervonenkis (1974).
suppression subtractive hybridization: Subtractive hybridization is a technology that allows for PCR-based amplification of only cDNA fragments that differ between a control (driver) and experimental transcriptome. cDNA is produced from mRNA. Differences in relative abundance of transcripts are highlighted, as are genetic differences between species. The technique relies on the removal of dsDNA formed by hybridization between a control and test sample, thus eliminating cDNAs or gDNAs of similar abundance, and retaining differentially expressed, or variable in sequence, transcripts or genomic sequences.
suprapubic skin: The suprapubic skin refers to the area of skin located above the pubic bone in the lower abdomen.
suprapubic skin specimen: A suprapubic skin specimen is a sample of skin tissue taken from the area above the pubic bone for medical examination or diagnostic purposes.
surface HBV antibody assay: A surface HBV antibody assay is a laboratory test used to detect the presence of antibodies against the hepatitis B virus surface antigen, indicating immunity to the virus.
surface plasmon resonance assay measurin: A surface plasmon resonance assay measuring the association constant [KA] of a B cell epitope:antibody complex is a technique used to quantify the strength and stability of the interaction between a specific region on an antigen (epitope) and an antibody by detecting changes in the refractive index

A surface plasmon resonance assay measuring the dissociation constant [KD] of a B cell epitope:antibody complex is a technique used to quantify the strength and stability of the interaction between an antibody and its specific epitope on a B cell by determining the rate at which the complex diss

A surface plasmon resonance assay measuring the off rate [koff] of a B cell epitope:antibody complex is a technique used to quantify the rate at which an antibody dissociates from its specific antigenic epitope on a B cell surface.

A surface plasmon resonance assay measuring the on rate [kon] of a B cell epitope:antibody complex is a technique used to quantify the rate at which an antibody binds to a specific epitope on a B cell surface by detecting changes in refractive index near a sensor surface.
surface plasmon resonance binding assay: A surface plasmon resonance binding assay is a technique used to measure the interaction between molecules, such as the binding affinity and kinetics, by detecting changes in the refractive index near a sensor surface where one of the interacting partners is immobilized.
surface plasmon resonance instrument: A surface plasmon resonance instrument is a device used to measure the binding interactions between molecules by detecting changes in the refractive index near a sensor surface, which occur when molecules bind to a surface-bound partner.
surface plasmon resonance sensor chip: A surface plasmon resonance sensor chip is a device used to detect molecular interactions by measuring changes in the refractive index near a metal surface, typically gold, when biomolecules bind to it.
surface wipe: A surface wipe is a disposable cloth or pad pre-moistened with a disinfectant solution, used to clean and sanitize surfaces to reduce the presence of harmful microorganisms.
surgical biopsy: A surgical biopsy is a medical procedure in which a surgeon removes a sample of tissue from the body for diagnostic examination, typically to determine the presence or extent of a disease such as cancer.
surgical gown: A protective plastic gown worn by a surgeon when performing surgery.
surveillance process: The "surveillance process" in a biomedical context refers to the systematic and continuous collection, analysis, and interpretation of health-related data essential for planning, implementing, and evaluating public health practices.
survival analysis data transformation: Survival analysis data transformation refers to the process of modifying survival data, often involving censoring and time-to-event variables, to prepare it for analysis using statistical models that assess the time until an event of interest occurs.
survival analysis objective: Survival analysis objective refers to the goal of analyzing and interpreting time-to-event data to understand the duration until one or more events of interest occur, such as death, disease recurrence, or recovery, often accounting for censored data.
survival assessment assay: A survival assessment assay is a laboratory test used to evaluate the viability and longevity of cells or organisms under specific conditions, often to assess the effects of treatments or environmental factors.
survival curve: Survival analysis is a branch of statistics for analyzing the expected duration of time until one event occurs, such as death in biological organisms and failure in mechanical systems. This topic is called reliability theory, reliability analysis or reliability engineering in engineering, duration analysis or duration modelling in economics, and event history analysis in sociology. Survival analysis attempts to answer certain questions, such as what is the proportion of a population which will survive past a certain time? Of those that survive, at what rate will they die or fail? Can multiple causes of death or failure be taken into account? How do particular circumstances or characteristics increase or decrease the probability of survival?
survival rate: Survival rate is a part of survival analysis. It is the proportion of people in a study or treatment group still alive at a given period of time after diagnosis. It is a method of describing prognosis in certain disease conditions, and can be used for the assessment of standards of therapy. The survival period is usually reckoned from date of diagnosis or start of treatment. Survival rates are based on the population as a whole and cannot be applied directly to an individual. There are various types of survival rates. They often serve as endpoints of clinical trials and should not be confused with mortality rates, a population metric.
swab specimen: A swab specimen is a sample collected using a small, absorbent stick or pad to gather cells, fluids, or microorganisms from a specific area of the body for diagnostic testing.
sweat: Perspiration, also known as sweat, is the fluid secreted by sweat glands in the skin of mammals.
sweat specimen: A sweat specimen is a sample of sweat collected from the body, often used for diagnostic testing to analyze its composition for medical purposes, such as detecting cystic fibrosis or measuring electrolyte levels.
symbol: A symbol is a mark, sign, or word that indicates, signifies, or is understood as representing an idea, object, or relationship. Symbols allow people to go beyond what is known or seen by creating linkages between otherwise different concepts and experiences. All communication is achieved through the use of symbols: for example, a red octagon is a common symbol for "STOP"; on maps, blue lines often represent rivers; and a red rose often symbolizes love and compassion. Numerals are symbols for numbers; letters of an alphabet may be symbols for certain phonemes; and personal names are symbols representing individuals. The academic study of symbols is called semiotics.
synaptosome preparation process: The synaptosome preparation process is a laboratory technique used to isolate synaptosomes, which are pinched-off nerve endings containing synaptic components, from brain tissue for the study of synaptic function and neurochemical analysis.
synovial fluid: Synovial fluid, also called synovia,[help 1] is a viscous, non-Newtonian fluid found in the cavities of synovial joints. With its egg white–like consistency, the principal role of synovial fluid is to reduce friction between the articular cartilage of synovial joints during movement. Synovial fluid is a small component of the transcellular fluid component of extracellular fluid.
synovial fluid specimen: A synovial fluid specimen is a sample of the lubricating fluid found within the cavities of synovial joints, collected for diagnostic analysis to assess joint health or diagnose conditions.
synthesis: Synthesis or synthesize may refer to:
synthesizing function: The "synthesizing function" in a biomedical context refers to the process by which cells or organisms produce complex molecules from simpler ones, often involving enzymatic activity and energy consumption.
synthetic peptide: In organic chemistry, peptide synthesis is the production of peptides, compounds where multiple amino acids are linked via amide bonds, also known as peptide bonds. Peptides are chemically synthesized by the condensation reaction of the carboxyl group of one amino acid to the amino group of another. Protecting group strategies are usually necessary to prevent undesirable side reactions with the various amino acid side chains. Chemical peptide synthesis most commonly starts at the carboxyl end of the peptide (C-terminus), and proceeds toward the amino-terminus (N-terminus). Protein biosynthesis in living organisms occurs in the opposite direction.
syringe: A syringe is a simple reciprocating pump consisting of a plunger that fits tightly within a cylindrical tube called a barrel. The plunger can be linearly pulled and pushed along the inside of the tube, allowing the syringe to take in and expel liquid or gas through a discharge orifice at the front (open) end of the tube. The open end of the syringe may be fitted with a hypodermic needle, a nozzle or tubing to direct the flow into and out of the barrel. Syringes are frequently used in clinical medicine to administer injections, infuse intravenous therapy into the bloodstream, apply compounds such as glue or lubricant, and draw/measure liquids. There are also prefilled syringes.
syringe filter: A syringe filter is a single-use filter cartridge. It is attached to the end of a syringe for use. Syringe filters may have Luer lock fittings, though not universally so. The use of a needle is optional; where desired it may be fitted to the end of the syringe filter.
syringe pump: A syringe driver, also known as a syringe pump, is a small infusion pump, used to gradually administer small amounts of fluid to a patient or for use in chemical and biomedical research. Some syringe drivers can both infuse and withdraw solutions.
systematic evolution of ligands by expon: The systematic evolution of ligands by exponential enrichment (SELEX) assay is a laboratory technique used to identify and evolve nucleic acid sequences, such as aptamers, that have high affinity and specificity for a particular target molecule through iterative rounds of selection and amplification.
systematic review study design: A systematic review study design is a research method that involves a comprehensive and structured approach to identifying, evaluating, and synthesizing all available evidence on a particular research question or topic, often using predefined criteria and methodologies.
t cell epitope prediction: T cell epitope prediction refers to the computational process of identifying specific regions or sequences on antigens that are recognized by T cells, which is crucial for understanding immune responses and developing vaccines.
table: Table may refer to:Table (database), how the table data arrangement is used within the databases Table (furniture), a piece of furniture with a flat surface and one or more legs Table (information), a data arrangement with rows and columns Table (landform), a flat area of land Table Table (sports), a ranking of the teams in a sports league Tables Mathematical table Tables of the skull, a term for the flat bones Table, surface of the sound board (music) of a string instrument Al-Ma'ida, the fifth surah of the Qur'an, occasionally translated as “The Table” Calligra Tables, a spreadsheet application Water table
tacrolimus hydrate: Tacrolimus hydrate is an immunosuppressive drug used to prevent organ transplant rejection by inhibiting T-lymphocyte activation.
tail: The tail is the elongated section at the rear end of a bilaterian animal's body; in general, the term refers to a distinct, flexible appendage extending backwards from the midline of the torso. In vertebrate animals that evolved to lose their tails, the coccyx is the homologous vestigial of the tail. While tails are primarily considered a feature of vertebrates, some invertebrates such as scorpions and springtails, as well as snails and slugs, have tail-like appendages that are also referred to as tails.
tail biopsy: Tail biopsy is a procedure in which a small piece of tissue is removed from the tail of an animal, commonly used in laboratory mice, for genetic analysis or other research purposes.
tail probability for the proportion of f: The "tail probability for the proportion of false positives correction method" is a statistical approach used to adjust for multiple comparisons by controlling the probability of observing a certain proportion of false positives among significant results.
tandem mass spectrometer: Tandem mass spectrometry, also known as MS/MS or MS2, is a technique in instrumental analysis where two or more stages of analysis using one or more mass analyzer are performed with an additional reaction step in between these analyses to increase their abilities to analyse chemical samples. A common use of tandem MS is the analysis of biomolecules, such as proteins and peptides.
tandem mass spectrometry analysis: Tandem mass spectrometry analysis is a technique used to identify and quantify molecules by separating ions based on their mass-to-charge ratio through multiple stages of mass spectrometry.
tandem mass spectrometry assay: A tandem mass spectrometry assay is an analytical technique used to identify and quantify molecules in a sample by separating ions based on their mass-to-charge ratio through multiple stages of mass spectrometry.
tandem mass tag mass spectrometry assay: A tandem mass tag mass spectrometry assay is a technique used to quantify proteins in complex mixtures by labeling them with isotopic tags that allow for simultaneous identification and relative quantification through mass spectrometry.
tandem stance assessment: Tandem stance assessment is a balance test where an individual stands with one foot directly in front of the other to evaluate postural stability and coordination.
tandem walk assessment: A tandem walk assessment is a clinical test used to evaluate balance and coordination by having an individual walk in a straight line, placing the heel of one foot directly in front of the toes of the other foot.
target capture specification: Target capture specification refers to the detailed criteria and parameters set for isolating and enriching specific nucleic acid sequences from a complex sample in genomic research or diagnostics.
target gene specification: Target gene specification refers to the process by which specific genes are identified and selected for regulation or expression in response to particular signals or conditions within a biological system.
target material in specimen specificatio: "Target material in specimen specification" refers to the specific biological substance or component that is intended to be analyzed or measured within a collected specimen for diagnostic or research purposes.
target of material addition: "Target of material addition" refers to a specific site or location within a biological system where substances or materials are deliberately introduced or deposited to achieve a desired therapeutic or experimental effect.
target of material addition role: The "target of material addition role" refers to the function of a biological entity that serves as the recipient or site for the addition of material, such as a substrate or molecule, during a biochemical process.
target subfragment specification: "Target subfragment specification" refers to the precise identification and characterization of a specific segment or portion of a larger biological molecule, such as DNA or protein, for the purpose of study or manipulation in biomedical research.
targeted mutagenesis: Targeted mutagenesis is a genetic engineering technique used to introduce specific mutations into a particular DNA sequence to study gene function or create desired traits.
targeted, drug-modulated, mass spectrome: A targeted, drug-modulated, mass spectrometry-based protein phosphorylation-state assay is a specialized analytical technique used to measure changes in the phosphorylation state of specific proteins in response to drug treatment, utilizing mass spectrometry for precise quantification.
task-based functional magnetic resonance: A task-based functional magnetic resonance image (fMRI) data set is a collection of brain imaging data acquired while participants perform specific tasks, used to measure and analyze brain activity and function.
taxonomic bridge ontology module: A taxonomic bridge ontology module is a structured framework that facilitates the integration and alignment of different biological taxonomies by providing a standardized set of terms and relationships.
taxonomic diversity assessment by target: Taxonomic diversity assessment by targeted gene survey is a method used to evaluate the variety of species within a community by analyzing specific gene sequences, often through techniques like DNA barcoding or metagenomics.
technical replicate role: A "technical replicate role" refers to the function of repeated measurements or experiments conducted under identical conditions to assess the precision and reliability of the data in a biomedical study.
tecmag EAGLE probe: The Tecmag EAGLE probe is a specialized device used in nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectroscopy to enhance signal detection and resolution for various biomedical and chemical analyses.
tecmag NMR console: The Tecmag NMR console is a device used in nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectroscopy to control and process the signals from NMR experiments, facilitating the acquisition and analysis of molecular and structural information.
telencephalon: The cerebrum, telencephalon or endbrain is the largest part of the brain, containing the cerebral cortex as well as several subcortical structures, including the hippocampus, basal ganglia, and olfactory bulb. In the human brain, the cerebrum is the uppermost region of the central nervous system. The cerebrum develops prenatally from the forebrain (prosencephalon). In mammals, the dorsal telencephalon, or pallium, develops into the cerebral cortex, and the ventral telencephalon, or subpallium, becomes the basal ganglia. The cerebrum is also divided into approximately symmetric left and right cerebral hemispheres.
temperature control bath: A temperature control bath is a laboratory device used to maintain a consistent temperature for samples or reactions by immersing them in a fluid medium with precise temperature regulation.
temperature measurement assay: A temperature measurement assay is a procedure or test used to determine the temperature of a biological sample or system, often to assess physiological or biochemical processes.
temperature measurement datum: A temperature measurement datum is a recorded value or data point representing the temperature of a biological system or environment at a specific time and location.
temperature unit: A temperature unit is a standardized measure used to quantify the degree of heat or cold, typically expressed in degrees Celsius (°C), Fahrenheit (°F), or Kelvin (K).
temperature value specification: Temperature value specification refers to the precise determination or setting of a temperature measurement, often used in biomedical contexts to ensure accurate monitoring or control of physiological or experimental conditions.
template generated ontology module: A template generated ontology module is a structured framework created using predefined templates to systematically organize and represent knowledge within a specific domain in biomedical research.
temporal region: The temporal region refers to the area of the skull located on the sides of the head, near the temples, encompassing the temporal bone and housing structures such as the temporal lobe of the brain.
tendon of biceps brachii: The tendon of the biceps brachii is a fibrous connective tissue that attaches the biceps muscle to the bones of the shoulder and forearm, facilitating arm movement.
tendon of biceps brachii functionality: The functionality of the tendon of the biceps brachii refers to its role in connecting the biceps muscle to the shoulder and forearm, enabling flexion and supination of the forearm.
terbium atom: A terbium atom is a chemical element with the symbol Tb and atomic number 65, belonging to the lanthanide series of the periodic table, commonly used in various electronic and optical applications.
test substance role: The term "test substance role" refers to the function or purpose of a substance when it is used in a scientific experiment or study to evaluate its effects, properties, or interactions.
test tube: A test tube, also known as a culture tube or sample tube, is a common piece of laboratory glassware consisting of a finger-like length of glass or clear plastic tubing, open at the top and closed at the bottom.
testable hypothesis: A hypothesis is a proposed explanation for a phenomenon. A scientific hypothesis must be based on observations and make a testable and reproducible prediction about reality, in a process beginning with an educated guess or thought.
testis: A testicle or testis is the male gonad in all gonochoric animals, including humans, and is homologous to the ovary, which is the female gonad. Its primary functions are the production of sperm and the secretion of androgens, primarily testosterone.
testis specimen: A testis specimen is a sample of tissue or cells taken from the testicle for examination and analysis, often to diagnose medical conditions or conduct research.
testosterone: Testosterone is the primary male sex hormone and androgen in males. In humans, testosterone plays a key role in the development of male reproductive tissues such as testicles and prostate, as well as promoting secondary sexual characteristics such as increased muscle and bone mass, and the growth of body hair. It is associated with increased aggression, sex drive, dominance, courtship display, and a wide range of behavioral characteristics. In addition, testosterone in both sexes is involved in health and well-being, where it has a significant effect on overall mood, cognition, social and sexual behavior, metabolism and energy output, the cardiovascular system, and in the prevention of osteoporosis. Insufficient levels of testosterone in men may lead to abnormalities including frailty, accumulation of adipose fat tissue within the body, anxiety and depression, sexual performance issues, and bone loss.
testosterone assay: A testosterone assay is a laboratory test used to measure the levels of testosterone, a hormone, in a biological sample, typically blood, to assess hormonal balance or diagnose medical conditions.
testosterone concentration assay: A testosterone concentration assay is a laboratory test used to measure the level of testosterone in a biological sample, such as blood or saliva.
textual entity: A textual entity in the biomedical context refers to any discrete piece of written information or data, such as a word, phrase, or document, that is used for analysis or reference in research and documentation.
thermal conductivity detector: A thermal conductivity detector is a device used in gas chromatography to measure the concentration of a gas by detecting changes in thermal conductivity between the sample gas and a reference gas.
thermal cycler: The thermal cycler is a laboratory apparatus most commonly used to amplify segments of DNA via the polymerase chain reaction (PCR). Thermal cyclers may also be used in laboratories to facilitate other temperature-sensitive reactions, including restriction enzyme digestion or rapid diagnostics. The device has a thermal block with holes where tubes holding the reaction mixtures can be inserted. The cycler then raises and lowers the temperature of the block in discrete, pre-programmed steps.
thermostatic circulator: A thermostatic circulator is a laboratory device used to maintain a constant temperature by circulating a fluid, typically water or oil, through a closed system.
three-dimensional spatial region: A "three-dimensional spatial region" refers to a defined area or volume in space that has length, width, and height, allowing for the representation and analysis of objects or phenomena in three dimensions.
throat: In vertebrate anatomy, the throat is the front part of the neck, internally positioned in front of the vertebrae. It contains the pharynx and larynx. An important section of it is the epiglottis, separating the esophagus from the trachea (windpipe), preventing food and drinks being inhaled into the lungs. The throat contains various blood vessels, pharyngeal muscles, the nasopharyngeal tonsil, the tonsils, the palatine uvula, the trachea, the esophagus, and the vocal cords. Mammal throats consist of two bones, the hyoid bone and the clavicle. The "throat" is sometimes thought to be synonymous for the fauces.
throat specimen: A throat specimen is a sample collected from the throat, typically using a swab, to test for the presence of pathogens or other diagnostic markers.
thrombin time assay: A thrombin time assay is a laboratory test that measures the time it takes for a clot to form in a blood sample after adding thrombin, used to evaluate the conversion of fibrinogen to fibrin and to detect abnormalities in the clotting process.
thyroid gland: The thyroid, or thyroid gland, is an endocrine gland in vertebrates. In humans, it is a butterfly-shaped gland located in the neck below the Adam's apple. It consists of two connected lobes. The lower two thirds of the lobes are connected by a thin band of tissue called the isthmus. Microscopically, the functional unit of the thyroid gland is the spherical thyroid follicle, lined with follicular cells (thyrocytes), and occasional parafollicular cells that surround a lumen containing colloid.
thyroid gland specimen: A thyroid gland specimen is a sample of tissue taken from the thyroid gland, typically for the purpose of diagnostic examination or research.
thyroid stimulating hormone: Thyroid-stimulating hormone (also known as thyrotropin, thyrotropic hormone, or abbreviated TSH) is a pituitary hormone that stimulates the thyroid gland to produce thyroxine (T4), and then triiodothyronine (T3) which stimulates the metabolism of almost every tissue in the body. It is a glycoprotein hormone produced by thyrotrope cells in the anterior pituitary gland, which regulates the endocrine function of the thyroid.
thyroid stimulating hormone assay: A thyroid stimulating hormone assay is a laboratory test that measures the level of thyroid stimulating hormone (TSH) in the blood to assess thyroid function.
thyroid stimulating hormone concentratio: A thyroid stimulating hormone concentration assay is a laboratory test that measures the level of thyroid stimulating hormone (TSH) in the blood to assess thyroid function.
thyroxine: Thyroxine, also known as T4, is a hormone produced by the thyroid gland. It is the primary form of thyroid hormone found in the blood and acts as a prohormone of the more active thyroid hormone, triiodothyronine (T3). Thyroxine and its active metabolites are essential for regulating metabolic rate, supporting heart and muscle function, promoting brain development, and maintaining bone health.
thyroxine assay: A thyroxine assay is a laboratory test used to measure the levels of thyroxine (T4), a thyroid hormone, in the blood to assess thyroid function.
tibial artery: Tibial arteries may refer to:Anterior tibial artery Posterior tibial artery
tibial artery specimen: A tibial artery specimen refers to a sample of tissue or cells taken from the tibial artery, typically for the purpose of medical examination or research.
tibial nerve: The tibial nerve is a branch of the sciatic nerve. The tibial nerve passes through the popliteal fossa to pass below the arch of soleus.
tibial nerve specimen: A "tibial nerve specimen" refers to a sample of tissue taken from the tibial nerve, typically for the purpose of medical examination or research.
tiling microarray: A tiling microarray is a type of DNA microarray that contains overlapping probes designed to cover a genomic region comprehensively, allowing for detailed analysis of gene expression, transcription factor binding, or chromatin structure.
time measurement datum: A "time measurement datum" in the biomedical context refers to a specific point in time used as a reference for measuring or recording temporal events or intervals in a study or experiment.
time series design: A time series design is a research method that involves collecting and analyzing data points sequentially over time to identify patterns, trends, or effects of interventions.
time unit: A unit of time is any particular time interval, used as a standard way of measuring or expressing duration. The base unit of time in the International System of Units (SI), and by extension most of the Western world, is the second, defined as about 9 billion oscillations of the caesium atom. The exact modern SI definition is "[The second] is defined by taking the fixed numerical value of the cesium frequency, ΔνCs, the unperturbed ground-state hyperfine transition frequency of the cesium 133 atom, to be 9192631770 when expressed in the unit Hz, which is equal to s−1."
tissue embedding station: A tissue embedding station is a laboratory device used to encase biological tissue samples in a solid medium, typically paraffin wax, to facilitate their slicing into thin sections for microscopic examination.
tissue section thickness: Tissue section thickness refers to the measurement of how thick a slice of tissue is when prepared for microscopic examination, typically ranging from a few micrometers to several millimeters.
tissue-based protein localization assay: A tissue-based protein localization assay is a laboratory technique used to detect and visualize the presence and distribution of specific proteins within tissue samples.
to be treated with active ingredient rol: "To be treated with active ingredient role" refers to the administration of a substance specifically responsible for the therapeutic effects in a medication or treatment regimen.
to be treated with placebo role: "To be treated with placebo role" refers to the administration of an inactive substance or treatment to a patient, often in a clinical trial, to assess the psychological and physiological effects compared to an active treatment.
tobramycin: Tobramycin is an aminoglycoside antibiotic derived from Streptomyces tenebrarius that is used to treat various types of bacterial infections, particularly Gram-negative infections. It is especially effective against species of Pseudomonas.
tobramycin assay: A tobramycin assay is a laboratory test used to measure the concentration of the antibiotic tobramycin in a patient's blood to ensure therapeutic levels and avoid toxicity.
tolerance induction: Tolerance induction refers to the process by which the immune system is trained to recognize and accept specific antigens without eliciting an adverse immune response, thereby preventing autoimmune reactions or rejection of transplanted tissues.
tolerance induction intervention experim: A tolerance induction intervention experiment is a scientific study designed to evaluate methods or treatments that promote the immune system's acceptance of specific antigens, thereby preventing adverse immune responses.
tongue: The tongue is a muscular organ in the mouth of a typical tetrapod. It manipulates food for chewing and swallowing as part of the digestive process, and is the primary organ of taste. The tongue's upper surface (dorsum) is covered by taste buds housed in numerous lingual papillae. It is sensitive and kept moist by saliva and is richly supplied with nerves and blood vessels. The tongue also serves as a natural means of cleaning the teeth. A major function of the tongue is to enable speech in humans and vocalization in other animals.
tongue atrophy assessment: Tongue atrophy assessment is the evaluation of the tongue's muscle mass and function to identify signs of muscle wasting or degeneration.
tongue swab specimen: A tongue swab specimen is a sample collected from the surface of the tongue using a sterile swab, typically for the purpose of diagnosing infections or analyzing microbial flora.
top loading balance: A top loading balance is a type of laboratory scale used to measure the mass of substances with a high degree of precision, typically featuring a pan on top for placing samples.
topical administration: A topical medication is a medication that is applied to a particular place on or in the body. Most often topical medication means application to body surfaces such as the skin or mucous membranes to treat ailments via a large range of classes including creams, foams, gels, lotions, and ointments. Many topical medications are epicutaneous, meaning that they are applied directly to the skin. Topical medications may also be inhalational, such as asthma medications, or applied to the surface of tissues other than the skin, such as eye drops applied to the conjunctiva, or ear drops placed in the ear, or medications applied to the surface of a tooth. The word topical derives from Greek τοπικός topikos, "of a place".
topical application insecticide resistan: A topical application insecticide resistance bioassay is a laboratory test used to evaluate the resistance of insects to insecticides by applying the chemical directly onto the insect's surface and observing its effects.
topologically preserved clustered data s: A topologically preserved clustered data set refers to a collection of data points organized into clusters while maintaining the original spatial or relational structure of the data.
total RNA extract: Total RNA extract refers to the complete set of RNA molecules, including messenger RNA (mRNA), ribosomal RNA (rRNA), transfer RNA (tRNA), and other non-coding RNAs, isolated from a biological sample.
total RNA extraction: Total RNA extraction is the process of isolating all types of RNA molecules, including messenger RNA (mRNA), ribosomal RNA (rRNA), and transfer RNA (tRNA), from a biological sample for subsequent analysis or experimentation.
total bilirubin concentration assay: A total bilirubin concentration assay is a laboratory test that measures the amount of bilirubin, a yellow pigment produced during the breakdown of red blood cells, in a blood sample to assess liver function and diagnose conditions like jaundice or liver disease.
total bodily fluid protein assay: A total bodily fluid protein assay is a laboratory test used to measure the concentration of proteins present in a bodily fluid, such as blood, urine, or cerebrospinal fluid, to assess health or diagnose medical conditions.
total intensity transformation paired: "Total intensity transformation paired" refers to a process or method in biomedical imaging where the intensity values of paired images are adjusted or transformed to enhance or standardize their appearance for better analysis or comparison.
total intensity transformation single: "Total intensity transformation single" does not appear to be a standard term in biomedical literature; it may refer to a specific process or technique involving the transformation or analysis of intensity data from a single source or measurement in a biomedical context.
total lymphocyte count assay: A total lymphocyte count assay is a laboratory test that measures the number of lymphocytes, a type of white blood cell, in a blood sample to assess immune function.
total lymphocyte percentage assay: The total lymphocyte percentage assay is a laboratory test that measures the proportion of lymphocytes, a type of white blood cell, in a blood sample relative to the total number of white blood cells, providing insights into immune function.
total thyroxine concentration assay: A total thyroxine concentration assay is a laboratory test that measures the total amount of thyroxine (T4) hormone in the blood, including both the free and protein-bound forms, to assess thyroid function.
total venous blood IgE assay: A total venous blood IgE assay is a laboratory test that measures the total amount of immunoglobulin E (IgE) antibodies present in a blood sample drawn from a vein, often used to evaluate allergic responses or conditions.
total venous blood PSA assay: A total venous blood PSA assay is a laboratory test that measures the concentration of prostate-specific antigen (PSA) in a blood sample drawn from a vein, used primarily to screen for and monitor prostate health.
total venous blood T3 assay: A total venous blood T3 assay is a laboratory test that measures the total amount of triiodothyronine (T3) hormone in a sample of venous blood to assess thyroid function.
total venous blood calcium assay: A total venous blood calcium assay is a laboratory test that measures the total amount of calcium in a sample of venous blood, including both the free (ionized) and protein-bound forms.
total venous blood cholesterol assay: A total venous blood cholesterol assay is a laboratory test that measures the total amount of cholesterol present in a blood sample drawn from a vein, including low-density lipoprotein (LDL), high-density lipoprotein (HDL), and triglycerides.
total venous blood homocysteine assay: A total venous blood homocysteine assay is a laboratory test that measures the concentration of homocysteine, an amino acid, in a blood sample drawn from a vein to assess cardiovascular health and nutritional status.
total venous blood protein assay: A total venous blood protein assay is a laboratory test that measures the total amount of proteins, including albumin and globulin, present in a blood sample drawn from a vein.
trachea: The trachea, also known as the windpipe, is a cartilaginous tube that connects the larynx to the bronchi of the lungs, allowing the passage of air, and so is present in almost all animals' lungs. The trachea extends from the larynx and branches into the two primary bronchi. At the top of the trachea, the cricoid cartilage attaches it to the larynx. The trachea is formed by a number of horseshoe-shaped rings, joined together vertically by overlying ligaments, and by the trachealis muscle at their ends. The epiglottis closes the opening to the larynx during swallowing.
tracheal aspirate specimen: A tracheal aspirate specimen is a sample of mucus or secretions collected from the trachea, typically obtained through suctioning, for diagnostic analysis of respiratory infections or conditions.
training objective: In the biomedical context, a "training objective" refers to the specific goal or set of goals that guide the learning process of a machine learning model, often involving the optimization of a function to improve the model's performance on a given task, such as disease prediction or image classification.
training process: In the biomedical context, the "training process" refers to the systematic procedure of teaching or conditioning a biological system, such as a neural network or a group of individuals, to perform specific tasks or respond to stimuli through repeated practice and feedback.
training service: In the biomedical context, a "training service" refers to a program or initiative designed to enhance the skills and knowledge of healthcare professionals or researchers through structured educational activities and practical experiences.
transcript analysis by paired-end tag se: Transcript analysis by paired-end tag sequencing assay is a technique used to study gene expression by sequencing short tags from both ends of cDNA fragments, allowing for precise mapping and quantification of transcripts.
transcript analysis by single-end sequen: Transcript analysis by single-end sequencing assay is a technique used to sequence RNA transcripts from one end, allowing for the identification and quantification of gene expression levels in a sample.
transcript expression location detection: Transcript expression location detection by hybridization chain reaction assay is a technique used to visualize and quantify the spatial distribution of specific RNA transcripts within a tissue or cell by amplifying the signal through a chain reaction of hybridization events.
transcript leader sequencing assay: A transcript leader sequencing assay is a technique used to analyze the 5' untranslated regions (UTRs) of mRNA transcripts to understand their role in gene regulation and expression.
transcription cofactor activity region i: "Transcription cofactor activity region identification by ChIP-Seq assay" refers to the process of using Chromatin Immunoprecipitation followed by sequencing (ChIP-Seq) to locate and analyze regions of DNA where transcription cofactors bind, thereby influencing gene expression.
transcription factor binding site assay: A transcription factor binding site assay is a laboratory technique used to identify and characterize specific DNA sequences where transcription factors bind, thereby regulating gene expression.
transcription factor binding site identi: Transcription factor binding site identification by ChIP-Seq assay is a method used to determine the specific locations on the DNA where transcription factors bind, utilizing chromatin immunoprecipitation followed by high-throughput sequencing.

Transcription factor binding site identification by ChIP-chip assay is a technique used to determine the specific DNA sequences where transcription factors bind within the genome, combining chromatin immunoprecipitation (ChIP) with microarray technology (chip) to analyze protein-DNA interactions on a genomic scale.
transcription profiling assay: A transcription profiling assay is a laboratory technique used to measure the expression levels of multiple genes simultaneously to understand gene activity and regulation in a given sample.
transcription profiling by MPSS assay: Transcription profiling by MPSS (Massively Parallel Signature Sequencing) assay is a high-throughput technique used to quantitatively analyze gene expression by sequencing short signature tags from mRNA transcripts.
transcription profiling by RT-PCR assay: Transcription profiling by RT-PCR assay is a technique used to measure and compare the expression levels of specific genes by converting RNA into complementary DNA (cDNA) and amplifying it through reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR).
transcription profiling by RT-PCR design: Transcription profiling by RT-PCR design is a technique used to measure and analyze the expression levels of specific genes by converting RNA into complementary DNA (cDNA) and amplifying it through reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR).
transcription profiling by array assay: Transcription profiling by array assay is a technique used to measure the expression levels of multiple genes simultaneously by hybridizing cDNA to a microarray containing probes for specific gene sequences.
transcription profiling by array design: Transcription profiling by array design is a technique used to measure the expression levels of multiple genes simultaneously by hybridizing cDNA or RNA samples to a pre-designed array of complementary DNA probes.
transcription profiling by high throughp: Transcription profiling by high throughput sequencing design refers to the process of systematically analyzing and quantifying RNA transcripts in a biological sample using advanced sequencing technologies to understand gene expression patterns comprehensively.
transcription profiling by tiling array: Transcription profiling by tiling array assay is a genomic technique used to measure the expression levels of RNA transcripts across a genome by hybridizing them to a high-density array of overlapping probes that cover the entire genome or specific regions of interest.

Transcription profiling by tiling array design is a genomic technique used to measure the expression levels of RNA transcripts across a genome by using high-density microarrays that cover the entire genome or specific regions with overlapping probes.
transcription profiling design: Transcription profiling design refers to the experimental setup and methodology used to measure and analyze gene expression levels across different conditions or time points, typically using techniques like microarrays or RNA sequencing.
transcription profiling identification o: Transcription profiling identification objective refers to the goal of analyzing and identifying the patterns of gene expression across different conditions or cell types by measuring the abundance of RNA transcripts.
transcription start site identification: The "transcription start site identification objective" refers to the goal of pinpointing the exact location on the DNA where the process of transcription begins, marking the initiation of RNA synthesis.
transcription start site mapping by prim: Transcription start site mapping by primer extension assay is a molecular biology technique used to determine the exact location of the transcription start site of a gene by extending a labeled primer annealed to an RNA template with reverse transcriptase.
transfection: Transfection is the process of deliberately introducing naked or purified nucleic acids into eukaryotic cells. It may also refer to other methods and cell types, although other terms are often preferred: "transformation" is typically used to describe non-viral DNA transfer in bacteria and non-animal eukaryotic cells, including plant cells. In animal cells, transfection is the preferred term, as the term "transformation" is also used to refer to a cell's progression to a cancerous state (carcinogenesis). Transduction is often used to describe virus-mediated gene transfer into prokaryotic cells.
transfer function: In engineering, a transfer function of a system, sub-system, or component is a mathematical function that models the system's output for each possible input. It is widely used in electronic engineering tools like circuit simulators and control systems. In simple cases, this function can be represented as a two-dimensional graph of an independent scalar input versus the dependent scalar output. Transfer functions for components are used to design and analyze systems assembled from components, particularly using the block diagram technique, in electronics and control theory.
transfer line: A transfer line is a manufacturing system which consists of a predetermined sequence of machines connected by an automated material handling system and designed for working on a very small family of parts. Parts can be moved singularly because there’s no need for batching when carrying parts between process stations. The line can synchronous, meaning that all parts advance with the same speed, or asynchronous, meaning buffers exist between stations where parts wait to be processed. Not all transfer lines must geometrically be straight lines, for example circular solutions have been developed which make use of rotary tables, however using buffers becomes almost impossible.
transferrin assay: A transferrin assay is a laboratory test used to measure the level of transferrin, a protein that binds and transports iron in the blood, to assess iron metabolism and diagnose related disorders.
transforming growth factor beta producti: Transforming growth factor beta production refers to the process by which cells synthesize and release transforming growth factor beta (TGF-β), a multifunctional cytokine involved in regulating cell growth, differentiation, and immune responses.
transforming growth factor beta1 product: Transforming growth factor beta1 (TGF-β1) production refers to the process by which cells synthesize and release TGF-β1, a cytokine involved in regulating cell growth, differentiation, and immune responses.
transforming growth factor beta2 product: Transforming growth factor beta2 production refers to the process by which cells synthesize and release the cytokine TGF-β2, a protein involved in regulating cell growth, differentiation, and immune responses.
transforming growth factor beta3 product: Transforming growth factor beta3 production refers to the process by which cells synthesize and release the cytokine TGF-β3, a protein involved in regulating cell growth, differentiation, and repair in various tissues.
transgenic mutagenesis: Transgenic mutagenesis is a genetic engineering technique that involves introducing foreign DNA into an organism to create mutations for studying gene function and disease mechanisms.
transgenic organism: A transgene is a gene that has been transferred naturally, or by any of a number of genetic engineering techniques, from one organism to another. The introduction of a transgene, in a process known as transgenesis, has the potential to change the phenotype of an organism. Transgene describes a segment of DNA containing a gene sequence that has been isolated from one organism and is introduced into a different organism. This non-native segment of DNA may either retain the ability to produce RNA or protein in the transgenic organism or alter the normal function of the transgenic organism's genetic code. In general, the DNA is incorporated into the organism's germ line. For example, in higher vertebrates this can be accomplished by injecting the foreign DNA into the nucleus of a fertilized ovum. This technique is routinely used to introduce human disease genes or other genes of interest into strains of laboratory mice to study the function or pathology involved with that particular gene.
translation profiling assay: A translation profiling assay is a technique used to analyze and quantify the translation of mRNA into proteins within a cell, often by measuring ribosome occupancy on mRNA transcripts.
translation profiling design: Translation profiling design refers to a research approach used to analyze and quantify the translation of mRNA into proteins within a cell, often employing techniques like ribosome profiling to gain insights into gene expression and regulation at the translational level.
translation-associated transcript leader: The translation-associated transcript leader sequencing assay is a technique used to analyze and map the untranslated regions (UTRs) of mRNA transcripts, particularly focusing on the sequences that influence the initiation and regulation of protein translation.
translational bias design: Translational bias design refers to the strategic planning and execution of research studies aimed at minimizing biases and enhancing the applicability of preclinical findings to clinical settings, thereby improving the translation of scientific discoveries into effective medical treatments.
transparent droplet barrier: A transparent droplet barrier is a clear protective shield designed to prevent the transmission of respiratory droplets, often used in medical or public settings to reduce the spread of infectious diseases.
transplantation: Transplant or Transplantation may refer to:
transposase-mediated analysis of chromat: Transposase-mediated analysis of chromatin looping assay is a technique used to study the three-dimensional organization of chromatin by identifying interactions between distant genomic regions facilitated by transposase activity.
transposon-induced mutagenesis: Transposon-induced mutagenesis is a genetic technique that involves the insertion of transposons into a genome to disrupt gene function and study the resulting phenotypic changes.
transthyretin: Transthyretin (TTR or TBPA) is a transport protein in the plasma and cerebrospinal fluid that transports the thyroid hormone thyroxine (T4) and retinol to the liver. This is how transthyretin gained its name: transports thyroxine and retinol. The liver secretes TTR into the blood, and the choroid plexus secretes TTR into the cerebrospinal fluid.
trap column: A trap column is a short chromatography column used in liquid chromatography systems to capture and concentrate analytes from a sample before they are introduced into the main analytical column for separation.
trap for emerging adult arthropods: A "trap for emerging adult arthropods" is a device or method used to capture arthropods as they transition from their immature stages to adulthood, often for study or pest control purposes.
treatment intervention experiment: A treatment intervention experiment is a research study designed to evaluate the effects and efficacy of a specific therapeutic approach or intervention on a particular condition or disease in a controlled setting.
treatment portion of study execution: The "treatment portion of study execution" refers to the phase in a clinical study where participants receive the specific interventions or therapies being tested, following the study protocol.
trial monitor role: A trial monitor role involves overseeing the conduct of a clinical trial to ensure compliance with regulatory requirements, protocol adherence, and data integrity.
trial statistician role: A trial statistician role involves designing, analyzing, and interpreting data from clinical trials to ensure the validity and reliability of the study's findings.
triglyceride: A triglyceride is an ester derived from glycerol and three fatty acids. Triglycerides are the main constituents of body fat in humans and other vertebrates as well as vegetable fat. They are also present in the blood to enable the bidirectional transference of adipose fat and blood glucose from the liver and are a major component of human skin oils.
triglyceride assay: A triglyceride assay is a laboratory test used to measure the concentration of triglycerides, a type of fat, in a blood sample to assess lipid metabolism and cardiovascular health.
triglyceride concentration assay: A triglyceride concentration assay is a laboratory test used to measure the amount of triglycerides, a type of fat, present in a blood sample.
trimmed sequence data: Trimmed sequence data refers to nucleotide or protein sequences from which low-quality or non-biological regions, such as adapters or primers, have been removed to improve the accuracy of subsequent analyses.
tris: Tris, or tris(hydroxymethyl)aminomethane, or known during medical use as tromethamine or THAM, is an organic compound with the formula (HOCH2)3CNH2. It is extensively used in biochemistry and molecular biology as a component of buffer solutions such as in TAE and TBE buffers, especially for solutions of nucleic acids. It contains a primary amine and thus undergoes the reactions associated with typical amines, e.g., condensations with aldehydes. Tris also complexes with metal ions in solution. In medicine, tromethamine is occasionally used as a drug, given in intensive care for its properties as a buffer for the treatment of severe metabolic acidosis in specific circumstances. Some medications are formulated as the "tromethamine salt" including Hemabate (carboprost as trometamol salt), and "ketorolac trometamol". In 2023 a strain of Pseudomonas hunanensis was found to be able to degrade TRIS buffer.
tritiated thymidine: Tritiated thymidine is a radioactive form of the nucleoside thymidine, labeled with tritium, used primarily as a tracer in molecular biology to measure DNA synthesis and cell proliferation.
tritiated thymidine incorporation assay: The tritiated thymidine incorporation assay is a laboratory technique used to measure cell proliferation by quantifying the incorporation of radioactive thymidine into newly synthesized DNA strands during cell division.
trough venous blood tobramycin assay: A trough venous blood tobramycin assay is a laboratory test that measures the lowest concentration of the antibiotic tobramycin in a patient's bloodstream, typically just before the next dose, to ensure therapeutic levels and avoid toxicity.
trough venous blood vancomycin assay: A trough venous blood vancomycin assay is a laboratory test that measures the lowest concentration of the antibiotic vancomycin in a patient's bloodstream, typically just before the next dose, to ensure therapeutic levels and avoid toxicity.
tube 1 count cerebrospinal fluid cell co: The "tube 1 count cerebrospinal fluid cell count assay" is a laboratory test that measures the number of cells present in the first tube of cerebrospinal fluid collected during a lumbar puncture, used to help diagnose conditions affecting the central nervous system.
tube 4 count cerebrospinal fluid cell co: The "tube 4 count cerebrospinal fluid cell count assay" is a diagnostic test that measures the number of cells, such as white blood cells and red blood cells, in the fourth tube of cerebrospinal fluid collected during a lumbar puncture to help diagnose conditions affecting the central nervous system.
tumor challenge: A tumor challenge refers to an experimental procedure in which tumor cells are introduced into an organism to study the immune response or evaluate the efficacy of potential cancer treatments.
tumor grading: In pathology, grading is a measure of the cell appearance in tumors and other neoplasms. Some pathology grading systems apply only to malignant neoplasms (cancer); others apply also to benign neoplasms. The neoplastic grading is a measure of cell anaplasia in the sampled tumor and is based on the resemblance of the tumor to the tissue of origin. Grading in cancer is distinguished from staging, which is a measure of the extent to which the cancer has spread.
tumor necrosis factor (ligand) superfami: Tumor necrosis factor (ligand) superfamily member 11 production refers to the biological process in which cells synthesize and release a specific protein involved in bone metabolism and immune system regulation, also known as RANKL (Receptor Activator of Nuclear Factor κB Ligand).
tumor necrosis factor production: Tumor necrosis factor production refers to the process by which cells synthesize and release tumor necrosis factor (TNF), a cytokine involved in systemic inflammation and the regulation of immune cells.
tumor necrosis factor superfamily cytoki: Tumor necrosis factor superfamily cytokine production refers to the process by which cells synthesize and release cytokines that belong to the tumor necrosis factor (TNF) superfamily, which are involved in regulating immune responses, inflammation, and cell death.
two electrode voltage clamp assay: A two-electrode voltage clamp assay is an experimental technique used to measure ionic currents across the membrane of a cell by controlling the membrane potential with two electrodes, allowing for the study of ion channel function.
two-dimensional continuant fiat boundary: A two-dimensional continuant fiat boundary is a conceptual boundary that exists in a two-dimensional plane, delineating or demarcating regions or entities without a physical manifestation, often used in biomedical ontologies to describe spatial relationships.
two-dimensional spatial region: A two-dimensional spatial region refers to a flat, defined area that has length and width but no depth, existing within a plane.
two-photon laser/detector: A two-photon laser/detector is a specialized optical system used in microscopy that allows for the excitation and detection of fluorescent signals from biological samples using two photons of lower energy, enabling high-resolution imaging with reduced photodamage and deeper tissue penetration.
type I interferon production: Type I interferon production refers to the process by which cells produce type I interferons, a group of cytokines that play a crucial role in the immune response by helping to protect against viral infections and modulating the activity of immune cells.
type II interferon production: Type II interferon production refers to the process by which immune cells, primarily T cells and natural killer cells, produce interferon-gamma (IFN-γ), a cytokine crucial for immune response modulation and pathogen defense.
type III interferon production: Type III interferon production refers to the process by which cells produce a specific class of interferons, known as lambda interferons, that play a crucial role in the immune response against viral infections, particularly at mucosal surfaces.
type IV hypersensitivity: Type IV hypersensitivity is a delayed immune response mediated by T cells that occurs 24-72 hours after exposure to an antigen, often resulting in tissue damage.
tyramide signal amplification sequencing: Tyramide signal amplification sequencing assay is a sensitive molecular technique used to enhance the detection of nucleic acids or proteins in biological samples by amplifying the signal of target molecules through the enzymatic deposition of labeled tyramide substrates.
ultrasound machine: Medical ultrasound includes diagnostic techniques using ultrasound, as well as therapeutic applications of ultrasound. In diagnosis, it is used to create an image of internal body structures such as tendons, muscles, joints, blood vessels, and internal organs, to measure some characteristics or to generate an informative audible sound. The usage of ultrasound to produce visual images for medicine is called medical ultrasonography or simply sonography, or echography. The practice of examining pregnant women using ultrasound is called obstetric ultrasonography, and was an early development of clinical ultrasonography. The machine used is called an ultrasound machine, a sonograph or an echograph. The visual image formed using this technique is called an ultrasonogram, a sonogram or an echogram.
ultrasound-guided needle biopsy: An ultrasound-guided needle biopsy is a medical procedure in which a needle is precisely inserted into a specific area of the body to collect tissue samples for examination, using ultrasound imaging to guide the needle's placement.
ultraviolet light source: An ultraviolet light source is a device that emits ultraviolet radiation, which is used in various biomedical applications for sterilization, imaging, and therapeutic purposes.
umbilical cord blood: Cord blood is blood that remains in the placenta and in the attached umbilical cord after childbirth. Cord blood is collected because it contains stem cells, which can be used to treat hematopoietic and genetic disorders such as cancer.
umbilical cord blood assay: An umbilical cord blood assay is a laboratory test conducted on blood collected from the umbilical cord at birth to assess various health indicators, including genetic, hematological, and immunological parameters.
umbilical cord blood assay datum: An "umbilical cord blood assay datum" refers to a specific piece of data or measurement obtained from testing the blood collected from the umbilical cord at birth, often used for medical analysis or research purposes.
umbilical cord blood microbiology assay: An umbilical cord blood microbiology assay is a laboratory test used to detect and analyze microbial presence and composition in the blood collected from the umbilical cord at birth.
umbilical cord blood microbiology datum: Umbilical cord blood microbiology datum refers to the microbiological data or information obtained from the analysis of microorganisms present in the blood collected from the umbilical cord at birth.
umbilical cord blood specimen: An umbilical cord blood specimen is a sample of blood collected from the umbilical cord and placenta after childbirth, which contains stem cells and other components useful for medical research and treatments.
unblinding process: The unblinding process in a clinical trial refers to the revealing of which participants received the experimental treatment and which received a placebo or control, typically occurring after the trial's conclusion to ensure unbiased results.
uncle clinical history of cancer: "Uncle clinical history of cancer" refers to the medical record or background information indicating that an individual's uncle has been diagnosed with or treated for cancer.
unilateral oophorectomy history: Unilateral oophorectomy history refers to a medical history indicating that a person has undergone a surgical procedure to remove one of their two ovaries.
unit-variance scaling: Unit-variance scaling is a data preprocessing technique in which each feature of a dataset is scaled so that it has a variance of one, often used to standardize data for machine learning algorithms.
unknown clinical history of cancer: "Unknown clinical history of cancer" refers to a situation where a patient's past medical records or details regarding any previous cancer diagnosis or treatment are not available or have not been documented.
unplanned occurrence effecting an invest: An "unplanned occurrence affecting an investigation" refers to an unexpected event or incident that disrupts or influences the course and outcomes of a scientific or clinical study.
unsupervised machine learning: Unsupervised learning is a framework in machine learning where, in contrast to supervised learning, algorithms learn patterns exclusively from unlabeled data. Other frameworks in the spectrum of supervisions include weak- or semi-supervision, where a small portion of the data is tagged, and self-supervision. Some researchers consider self-supervised learning a form of unsupervised learning.
upper limb coordination assessment: Upper limb coordination assessment is a clinical evaluation of a person's ability to perform precise and controlled movements with their arms and hands, often used to identify neurological or musculoskeletal impairments.
upper limb coordination efficacy: Upper limb coordination efficacy refers to the effectiveness and precision with which an individual can control and synchronize movements of the arms and hands to perform tasks.
upper limit of detection: The "upper limit of detection" refers to the highest concentration or level of a substance that can be accurately measured by a specific analytical method or instrument without saturation or loss of linearity.
upper respiratory tract: The respiratory tract is the subdivision of the respiratory system involved with the process of conducting air to the alveoli for the purposes of gas exchange in mammals. The respiratory tract is lined with respiratory epithelium as respiratory mucosa.
upper respiratory tract specimen: An upper respiratory tract specimen is a sample collected from the upper part of the respiratory system, such as the nasal passages, throat, or nasopharynx, used for diagnostic testing of respiratory infections.
upright stability assessment: Upright stability assessment refers to the evaluation of an individual's ability to maintain balance and stability while standing or moving in an upright position, often used to identify balance disorders or fall risks.
urethra: The urethra is the tube that carries urine from the urinary bladder to the outside of the body through the penis or vulva in placental mammals. In males, it carries semen through the penis during ejaculation.
urethra specimen: A urethra specimen is a sample collected from the urethra, typically for the purpose of diagnosing infections, diseases, or other medical conditions.
urethral administration: Urethral administration is a method of delivering medication directly into the urethra for localized treatment or absorption.
uric acid: Uric acid is a heterocyclic compound of carbon, nitrogen, oxygen, and hydrogen with the formula C5H4N4O3. It forms ions and salts known as urates and acid urates, such as ammonium acid urate. Uric acid is a product of the metabolic breakdown of purine nucleotides, and it is a normal component of urine. High blood concentrations of uric acid can lead to gout and are associated with other medical conditions, including diabetes and the formation of ammonium acid urate kidney stones.
uric acid assay: A uric acid assay is a laboratory test used to measure the concentration of uric acid in a biological sample, typically blood or urine, to assess metabolic function and diagnose conditions such as gout or kidney disease.
urinary bladder: The bladder is a hollow organ in humans and other vertebrates that stores urine from the kidneys. In placental mammals, urine enters the bladder via the ureters and exits via the urethra during urination. In humans, the bladder is a distensible organ that sits on the pelvic floor. The typical adult human bladder will hold between 300 and 500 ml before the urge to empty occurs, but can hold considerably more.
urinary bladder specimen: A urinary bladder specimen is a sample of tissue or fluid collected from the urinary bladder for diagnostic examination or analysis.
urine: Urine is a liquid by-product of metabolism in humans and many other animals. In placental mammals, urine flows from the kidneys through the ureters to the urinary bladder and exits the urethra through the penile meatus (males) or urethral meatus of the vulva (females) during urination. In other vertebrates, urine is excreted through the cloaca.
urine assay: A urine assay is a laboratory test that analyzes a urine sample to detect and measure various substances, such as drugs, hormones, or metabolic byproducts, to assess health or diagnose medical conditions.
urine assay datum: A urine assay datum is a single piece of data or measurement obtained from analyzing a urine sample to assess various biochemical or physiological parameters.
urine creatinine assay: A urine creatinine assay is a laboratory test that measures the concentration of creatinine in urine to assess kidney function and muscle metabolism.
urine microbiology assay: A urine microbiology assay is a laboratory test used to detect and identify microorganisms, such as bacteria, fungi, or viruses, present in a urine sample to diagnose infections or other medical conditions.
urine microbiology datum: Urine microbiology datum refers to a piece of information or measurement obtained from the analysis of microorganisms present in a urine sample, often used to diagnose infections or other medical conditions.
urine osmolality assay: A urine osmolality assay is a laboratory test that measures the concentration of solutes in urine to assess the kidney's ability to concentrate or dilute urine.
urine protein assay: A urine protein assay is a diagnostic test that measures the amount of protein present in a urine sample to assess kidney function and detect potential kidney disease.
urine sodium assay: A urine sodium assay is a diagnostic test that measures the concentration of sodium in a urine sample to assess kidney function and fluid balance in the body.
urine specimen: A urine test is any medical test performed on a urine specimen. The analysis of urine is a valuable diagnostic tool because its composition reflects the functioning of many body systems, particularly the kidneys and urinary system, and specimens are easy to obtain. Common urine tests include the routine urinalysis, which examines the physical, chemical, and microscopic properties of the urine; urine drug screening; and urine pregnancy testing.
use of medication inclusion criterion: The "use of medication inclusion criterion" refers to a specific requirement in clinical trials or studies that participants must be using a particular medication or class of medications to be eligible for inclusion.
uterine cervix: The cervix or cervix uteri is a dynamic fibromuscular sexual organ of the female reproductive system that connects the vagina with the uterine cavity. The human female cervix has been documented anatomically since at least the time of Hippocrates, over 2,000 years ago. The cervix is approximately 4 cm long with a diameter of approximately 3 cm and tends to be described as a cylindrical shape, although the front and back walls of the cervix are contiguous. The size of the cervix changes throughout a woman's life cycle. For example, women in the fertile years of their reproductive cycle tend to have larger cervixes than postmenopausal women; likewise, women who have produced offspring have a larger cervix than those who have not.
uterine cervix specimen: A uterine cervix specimen is a sample of tissue taken from the cervix, the lower part of the uterus that opens into the vagina, typically for diagnostic purposes such as screening for cervical cancer or other abnormalities.
uterus: The uterus or womb is the organ in the reproductive system of most female mammals, including humans, that accommodates the embryonic and fetal development of one or more fertilized eggs until birth. The uterus is a hormone-responsive sex organ that contains glands in its lining that secrete uterine milk for embryonic nourishment.
uterus specimen: A uterus specimen refers to a sample of uterine tissue that is collected for examination and analysis, often to diagnose or study medical conditions affecting the uterus.
vaccination: Vaccination is the administration of a vaccine to help the immune system develop immunity from a disease. Vaccines contain a microorganism or virus in a weakened, live or killed state, or proteins or toxins from the organism. In stimulating the body's adaptive immunity, they help prevent sickness from an infectious disease. When a sufficiently large percentage of a population has been vaccinated, herd immunity results. Herd immunity protects those who may be immunocompromised and cannot get a vaccine because even a weakened version would harm them. The effectiveness of vaccination has been widely studied and verified. Vaccination is the most effective method of preventing infectious diseases; widespread immunity due to vaccination is largely responsible for the worldwide eradication of smallpox and the elimination of diseases such as polio and tetanus from much of the world. According to the World Health Organization (WHO), vaccination prevents 3.5–5 million deaths per year. A WHO-funded study by The Lancet estimates that, during the 50-year period starting in 1974, vaccination prevented 154 million deaths, including 146 million among children under age 5. However, some diseases have seen rising cases due to relatively low vaccination rates attributable partly to vaccine hesitancy.
vaccine: A vaccine is a biological preparation that provides active acquired immunity to a particular infectious or malignant disease. The safety and effectiveness of vaccines has been widely studied and verified. A vaccine typically contains an agent that resembles a disease-causing microorganism and is often made from weakened or killed forms of the microbe, its toxins, or one of its surface proteins. The agent stimulates the body's immune system to recognize the agent as a threat, destroy it, and recognize further and destroy any of the microorganisms associated with that agent that it may encounter in the future.
vaccine production: Vaccine production is the process of developing, manufacturing, and distributing vaccines, which are biological preparations that provide immunity against specific infectious diseases.
vacuum degasser: A vacuum degasser is a device used in biomedical and laboratory settings to remove dissolved gases from liquids by applying a vacuum, thereby preventing gas-related issues in analytical processes.
vacuum dryer: A vacuum dryer is a device used to remove moisture from materials by reducing the pressure around them, allowing drying to occur at lower temperatures.
vacuum manifold: In quantum field theory, the term moduli is sometimes used to refer to scalar fields whose potential energy function has continuous families of global minima. Such potential functions frequently occur in supersymmetric systems. The term "modulus" is borrowed from mathematics, where it is used synonymously with "parameter". The word moduli first appeared in 1857 in Bernhard Riemann's celebrated paper "Theorie der Abel'schen Functionen".
vacuum oven: In chemistry, a vacuum oven is an oven that can also apply a vacuum to its contents. Such devices are useful for removing solvent or dehydrating samples. They are equivalent to Abderhalden's drying pistol in some ways, but vacuum ovens typically can accommodate large samples. A characteristic operation for a vacuum oven is the activation or regeneration of molecular sieves. Vacuum furnaces are related devices that operate at much higher temperatures and much lower pressures.
vacuum-assisted biopsy: A vacuum-assisted biopsy is a minimally invasive procedure that uses a vacuum-powered instrument to collect tissue samples for diagnostic examination, often used in breast cancer detection.
vacuum-assisted biopsy needle: A vacuum-assisted biopsy needle is a medical device used to obtain tissue samples for diagnostic purposes, utilizing vacuum suction to assist in the collection of the sample.
vagina: In mammals and other animals, the vagina is the elastic, muscular reproductive organ of the female genital tract. In humans, it extends from the vulval vestibule to the cervix. The vaginal introitus is normally partly covered by a thin layer of mucosal tissue called the hymen. The vagina allows for copulation and birth. It also channels menstrual flow, which occurs in humans and closely related primates as part of the menstrual cycle.
vagina specimen: A vagina specimen is a sample of cells or tissue collected from the vaginal area for the purpose of medical examination or testing.
vagina swab specimen: A vagina swab specimen is a sample collected from the vaginal area using a sterile swab for the purpose of medical testing or diagnosis.
